nodes.label: Space propulsion
nodes.desc: Spacecraft propulsion is any method used to accelerate spacecraft and artificial satellites. In-space propulsion exclusively deals with propulsion systems used in the vacuum of space and should not be confused with space launch or atmospheric entry.

nodes.label: In-space servicing
nodes.desc: Operating while in orbit is the next big challenge for the space sector, be it manufacturing, assembly, satellite servicing, or debris removal. In-Orbit Servicing and Manufacturing (IOSM) covers a range of activities focusing on in-space capabilities which include repairing and fixing spacecraft, as well as refueling.

nodes.label: Space telecommunications
nodes.desc: Space communication is the transmission of data between space and Earth-bound mission centers, usually called ground segments.

nodes.label: Earth observation
nodes.desc: An Earth observation (EO) mission architecture where raw EO data are processed on-board in order to produced reduced volume secondary derivative data to downlink. Thus downlink volume is reduced, but on-board computing requirements are increased.

nodes.label: Space robotics
nodes.desc: Space robotics is considered one of the most promising approaches for on-orbit servicing (OOS) missions such as docking, berthing, refueling, repairing, upgrading, transporting, rescuing, and orbital debris removal. Many enabling techniques have been developed in the past two decades and several technology demonstration missions have been completed. Space robotics has also played a major role in the exploration of celestial bodies in our solar system such as Mars, Titan, and the Moon.

nodes.label: Asteroid and comet mining
nodes.desc: Asteroid mining is the exploitation of materials from asteroids and other minor planets, including near-Earth objects.

nodes.label: In-space manufacturing
nodes.desc: Space manufacturing is the production of tangible goods beyond Earth.  The ability to perform In-Space Manufacturing (ISM) provides a solution toward sustainable, flexible missions. It is the first step toward independent crewed missions to Mars and beyond.

nodes.label: In-situ resources utilization (ISRU)
nodes.desc: In-situ resource utilization (ISRU) is the use of local materials to support exploration, usually human exploration. This may involve extracting or generating consumables for autonomous or human activities from raw materials found in situ on the Moon or other planetary bodies.

nodes.label: Space power
nodes.desc: Power systems that provide significant mass and volume savings (3-4 x SOP).

nodes.label: Debris mitigation
nodes.desc: With today’s rate of 70–90 launches a year, an increasing number of launches injecting 30 or more small satellites into orbit at once, and assuming future break-ups will continue at mean historical rates of four to five per year, the number of objects in space is expected to increase steadily. As a consequence of the rising object count, the probability of catastrophic collisions will also grow. Space debris mitigation is the field focusing on the mitigation of the risks caused by debris and the limitation of the spread and numbers of debris.

nodes.label: Agriculture
nodes.desc:
The agricultural sector is not only responsible for feeding the world’s population, but also comprises an important source of income and a major component of the global economy. Estimates suggest that over a billion people work in agriculture around the world, with approximately one-third of the economically active population deriving their livelihoods through farming or related activities.

Agricultural techniques in leading economies are less labour-intensive and make greater use of mechanisation, bioscience and digital technology, with the sector contributing to national prosperity, jobs, innovation, exports, food security and safety, and environmental management. In 2019, agriculture provided around 1.45% of jobs in the UK, but the agri-food sector accounted for a Gross Value Added (GVA) of £120bn, or 6.3% of national GVA, as well as exports of £23.6bn.

Space-based products and services are already beginning to have a significant and growing effect on the agricultural sector. Out to 2050, the impact of space on agriculture is expected to increase substantially, both in terms of breadth and depth. This includes new developments in space-based food production, hydroponics and closed-loop ecosystems, as well as the use of space-based products and services such as Earth Observation (EO), Satellite Communications (SATCOM) and Precision, Navigation and Timing (PNT) in the terrestrial agriculture sector. For example, space may enable innovations in precision agriculture and the use of remote monitoring, yield and risk modelling, and autonomous and robotic systems to increase agricultural productivity in a range of environments. Future uses of space for space-based as well as terrestrial agriculture could therefore also have extensive knock-on benefits for environmental sustainability and the growth of the net-zero economy.

Furthermore, they could enable future space-based habitats and long-duration space exploration missions through in-situ production of food and other supplies, as well as one day supporting colonisation and terraforming efforts on Mars or other celestial bodies. While space-based markets may face greater technical and financial barriers given the difficulties and costs associated with production of food in conditions of microgravity and limited space (e.g. on spacecraft or lunar/Martian habitats), the use of space to support terrestrial agriculture may be hindered more by varying levels of awareness among end users concerning costs and benefits of applying novel space-based applications [Globalagriculture.com, 2020; UK Government, 2020].

nodes.label: Climate and environmental protection
nodes.desc:
This cluster comprises all those activities in or enabled by space that are focused on managing the impact of human activity on the climate, weather, environment and ecosystems, to protect biodiversity, boost habitability and ultimately ensure the long-term sustainability of life on Earth.

Climate change, global warming and environmental degradation continue to produce adverse effects for organisations, communities and individuals in the UK and worldwide, including through rising sealevels, declining biodiversity and increasing frequency of extreme weather events. As governments, industry and civil society seek to identify novel ways to support climate and environmental protection, space-based technologies may have several applications offering a mix of both incremental as well as potentially ground-breaking impacts.

Taken to an extreme, growing exploitation of space out to 2050 may provide an ‘insurance policy’ to sustain humanity as a species if ecological collapse, climate disaster or some other event (e.g. use of weapons of mass destruction) were ever to render the Earth uninhabitable in future.

nodes.label: Stationary plasma thruster (SPT)
nodes.desc:
Stationary plasma thrusters are ion thrusters whose properties make them especially suitable for satellite station keeping or orbit transfer. In these thrusters, a magnetic field transverse to the electron flow towards the anode increases the electron collision frequency and makes possible the generation of a plasma at relatively low gas flow and gas density. The decrease of the plasma conductivity due to the magnetic field induces a large electric field in the plasma which accelerates the quasicollisionless ions whose trajectories are not significantly affected by the magnetic field.

Reference: [_Low frequency oscillations in a stationary plasma thruster_ by J. P. Boeuf and L. Garrigues](https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.368529)

nodes.label: On-board autonomous molecules separation
nodes.desc: One of the trickiest things to get right in space flight is the chemical properties of the propellant, and there’s a dizzying array of recipes. With a higher specific impulse, the quantity of methane required for lift off is less, meaning smaller fuel tanks. There is also easier storage of the fuel before launch, and simpler and lighter fuel pumps on the rocket itself. Methane also pressurizes itself in its tanks by a process called autogenous pressurization, which means complex and heavy systems pressurization systems can be dispensed with.

nodes.label: Harsh conditions withstanding fuel
nodes.desc: Fuel form withstanding conditions >2800 K in hydrogen environment characterization.

nodes.label: Uranium processing
nodes.desc: Kovarex enrichment process

nodes.label: Creation of low enriched uranium propellant
Einsteinian Relativistic Systems (ERS)
nodes.desc: Achieving relativistic flight to enable extrasolar exploration is one of the dreams of humanity and the long-term goal of our NASA Starlight program. Developing propulsion systems based on the relativistic effects can provide new solutions toward far-fetched destinations for space exploration missions.

nodes.label: Gravity control propulsion
nodes.desc: Some conceptual devices idealize a form of propulsion without any reaction mass that would somehow manipulate space-time and matter to create propulsive forces. One of the possible energy sources for such a device is gravitational potential energy.

nodes.label: Chemical propulsion
nodes.desc: Chemical propulsion uses chemical reactions to release energy and accelerate gases to generate thrust.

nodes.label: Gelled space propulsion
nodes.desc: Gelled and metallized fuels are a class of thixotropic (shear-thinning) fuels that improve the performance of rocket and air-breathing systems.

nodes.label: Monopropellant
nodes.desc: A monopropellant rocket is a rocket that uses a single chemical as its propellant.

nodes.label: Cryogenic propulsion
nodes.desc:
Cryogenic propulsion systems or subsystems operate with propellants that are liquefied gases at low temperatures.
Examples of technologies include liquid oxygen (LO2), methane (CH4) pressure-fed main engine LO2, CH4 pump-fed main engine LO2, liquid hydrogen (LH2) reaction and attitude control engine, LOX/RP, LH2/LOX based engine.

nodes.label: Bipropellant
nodes.desc: A bipropellant rocket engine is a rocket engine that uses two propellants (very often liquid propellants) which are kept separately prior to reacting to form a hot gas to be used for propulsion.

nodes.label: Deep throtting cryo engine
nodes.desc: Deep-throttling capability means that the cryogenic engine can quickly throttle up and down. Advancement in space exploration necessitates deep throttling of liquid cryogenic rocket engines.

nodes.label: Cold gas space propulsion
nodes.desc: A cold gas thruster (or a cold gas propulsion system) is a type of rocket engine which uses the expansion of a (typically inert) pressurized gas to generate thrust.

nodes.label: Liquid propulsion
nodes.desc: A liquid-propellant rocket utilizes a rocket engine that uses liquid propellants. Liquids are desirable because they have a reasonably high density and high specific impulse (Isp).

nodes.label: Solids space propulsion
nodes.desc: This area covers propulsion systems that operate with solid propellants, where the propellants are pre-mixed oxidizers and fuels.

nodes.label: Hybrids space propulsion
nodes.desc: Hybrid propulsion systems or subsystems operate with propellants that utilize a hybrid of solid fuel and liquid oxidizer.

nodes.label: Hydrogene peroxide-based propulsion
nodes.desc: Storage and usage of hydrogene peroxide. Hydrogene peroxide chemical notation is H2O2.

nodes.label: PMMA fuel engine characterization
nodes.desc: PMMA fuel engine characterization of regression rate for multiple engine restarts.

nodes.label: Hybrid nozzle and TVC evaluation
nodes.desc: Hybrid nozzle and TVC evaluation accounts for nozzle shape variation and thermal vacuum chamber evaluation.

nodes.label: Contamination analysis and prevention
nodes.desc: Contamination analysis and prevention studies are necessary to comply with planetary exploration requirements.

nodes.label: Reduction of spacecraft environmental impact
nodes.desc: Reduction of spacecraft landing impact on planetary environment will become an important aspect of space exploration to fight global warming and in-orbit debris creation.

nodes.label: Reduction of launchers impact
nodes.desc: Reduction of the impact of launchers on the atmosphere will become an important aspect of space exploration to fight global warming.

nodes.label: Chemical thermal propulsion
nodes.desc: Chemical thermal propulsion is a conceptual type of propulsion engines mixing chemical reactions and thermal properties to generate thrust.

nodes.label: Advanced propulsion
nodes.desc: This node accounts for advanced propulsion concepts.

nodes.label: Solar sailing
nodes.desc: Sail propulsion uses lightweight structures with a large surface area to produce thrust by reflecting solar photons (solar) or atmospheric molecules (drag), thereby transferring much of their momentum to the sail.

nodes.label: Extreme solar sailing for space exploration
nodes.desc:
Extreme solar sailing for deep space exploration is an advancement of solar sailing for deep space missions.

Reference: [Extreme Solar Sailing for Breakthrough Space Exploration​](https://techport.nasa.gov/view/106027)

nodes.label: Laser thermal propulsion
nodes.desc:
The laser thermal rocket (heat exchanger (HX) thruster) is a thermal rocket in which the propellant is heated by energy provided by an external laser beam.

Reference: [H. Krier and R. J. Glumb. _Concepts and status of laser-supported rocket propulsion_, Journal of Spacecraft and Rockets, Vol. 21, No. 1 (1984), pp. 70-79]( https://dx.doi.org/10.2514/3.8610)

nodes.label: Solar thermal propulsion
nodes.desc:
Solar thermal propulsion utilizes solar light to heat a propellant up to 2000 K. The gaseous propellant is then fed through a conventional rocket nozzle to produce thrust. A solar propelled rocket only needs a means by which it can capture solar energy. No electrical generator is needed.

Reference : [Solar Thermal Propulsion, Imperial College, United Kingdom](http://www2.ee.ic.ac.uk/derek.low08/yr2proj/solarthermal.htm)

nodes.label: Pure Electro-Magnetic Thrust (PEMT) propulsion
nodes.desc: A PEMT propulsion thruster is a concept propulsion engine that produces thrust as a solar sail, but uses a nuclear reactor as the power source.

nodes.label: Water-based engines
nodes.desc: The goal of a water-based propulsion system is to electricity to produce gas propellants – hydrogen and oxygen – from liquid water and to burn these gases in a rocket nozzle to generate thrust.

nodes.label: Nuclear Thermal Propulsion (NTP)
nodes.desc: Nuclear Thermal Propulsion (NTP) engines use a fission reactor (solid, liquid or gas) in the thrust chamber to heat large mass flow of propellant to extremely high temperatures for high specific impulse at high thrust.

nodes.label: Fission-fusion hybrid propulsion concepts
nodes.desc:
A fusion-fission hybrid reactor would use a fusion reactor to provide neutrons to an encapsulating ‘blanket’ of fissile materials, so fusion is essentially used as a stable fuel source for traditional fission-based energy generation. For a start, using fusion-derived neutrons to feed fission reactions would massively expand the fuel available to run plants.

Reference: [_Project Icarus: Fission-Fusion Hybrid Fuel for Interstellar Propulsion_ by R. M. Freeland II](https://bis-space.com/shop/product/project-icarus-fission-fusion-hybrid-fuel-for-interstellar-propulsion/)

nodes.label: Radioisotope thermal propulsion
nodes.desc: A radioisotope thermal rocket is a type of thermal rocket engine that uses the heat generated by the decay of radioactive elements to generate thrust.

nodes.label: Fusion thermal propulsion
nodes.desc: A fusion rocket is a theoretical design for a rocket driven by fusion propulsion that could provide efficient and sustained acceleration in space without the need to carry a large fuel supply. The design requires fusion power technology beyond current capabilities, and much larger and more complex rockets.

nodes.label: Antimatter thermal propulsion
nodes.desc: An antimatter rocket is a proposed class of rockets that use antimatter as their power source.

nodes.label: Electric propulsion
nodes.desc: Electric propulsion converts electric energy to interact with and accelerate a reaction mass to generate thrust.

nodes.label: Electrostatic thrust technology
nodes.desc: This area covers electric propulsion systems that use electrostatic fields to ionize and accelerate a propellant. The propellant is ionized and accelerated through a voltage potential by Coulomb force.

nodes.label: Electrothermal thrust technology
nodes.desc: Electrothermal thrust is electric heating-based thrust technologies. They are extensively utilized by several U.S. geosynchronous commercial satellite vendors for North-South station-keeping and orbit transfer functions.

nodes.label: Hydrazine thrusters
nodes.desc:
Monopropellant engines generate thrust by liquid hydrazine flowing through an open propellant valve into a catalytic decomposition chamber where the propellant goes through a highly energetic decomposition process and the hot decomposition gases are then accelerated through a converging-diverging nozzle.

Reference: https://www.rocket.com/space/space-power-propulsion/monopropellant-rocket-engines

nodes.label: Resistance thrusters (resistojets)
nodes.desc:
A resistojet is a method of spacecraft propulsion (electric propulsion) that provides thrust by heating a, typically non-reactive, fluid. Heating is usually achieved by sending electricity through a resistor consisting of a hot incandescent filament, with the expanded gas expelled through a conventional nozzle.

Reference:  _Electric Propulsion article in Encyclopedia of Physical Science and Technology_, 3rd Edition, Academic Press, San Diego, v.5, pp. 125-141, 2002

nodes.label: Arc thrusters (arcjets)
nodes.desc:
An arcjet thruster is a form of electrically powered spacecraft propulsion, in which an electrical discharge (arc) is created in a flow of propellant.

Reference: [John, R. R., Bennett, S., and Connors, J. P., "Arcjet Engine Performance: Experiment and Theory", AIAA Journal, Vol. 1, No. 11, Nov. 1963](http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/pdf/10.2514/3.2103)

nodes.label: Microwave electric thrusters (MET)
nodes.desc: Microwave electrothermal thruster, also known as MET, is a propulsion device that converts microwave energy into thermal (or heat) energy.

nodes.label: Ammonia thrusters
nodes.desc:
Ammonia is readily space storable, considered as a green propellant by NASA due to its low toxicity, and, because of its low molecular mass, can offer high exhaust velocity at the same power. Ammonia thrusters could therefore become very useful for space exploration missions, such as satellites and CubeSats.

Reference: [_A Study of a Low-Power Microwave Arcjet Thruster Using
Ammonia Propellant_ by Jorge Delgado](https://gradschool.psu.edu/diversity/mcnair/papers2003/delgadopdf/)

nodes.label: Hydrogen thrusters
nodes.desc: Hydrogren thrusters are powerful (yet conceptual as of today) thrusters burning hydrogen gas to propel a starship in the desired direction.

nodes.label: Electromagnetic thrust technology
nodes.desc: Electromagnetic thrusters accelerate propellant gas that has been heated to a plasma via a Lorentz force (a body force that is generated by a current magnetic field interaction).

nodes.label: Electrodynamic tethers
nodes.desc:
Electrodynamic tethers (EDTs) are long, thin, conductive wires deployed in space that could be used
to generate power and thrust. Currents conducted through the wire combined with the strength of the
Earth’s magnetic field could be harnessed to produce a force that could be used as propellant-less
propulsion. The most important benefit of such a system is that it does not require any fuel.

nodes.label: Magnetoplasmadynamic (MPD) thrusters
nodes.desc: A magnetoplasmadynamic thruster (MPDT) is a form of electrically powered spacecraft propulsion which uses the Lorentz force to generate thrust.

nodes.label: Steady state
nodes.desc: With a steady-state operating MPD arc thruster, the discharge current cannot be made as large as is possible with its quasi-steady counterpart.

nodes.label: Pulsed
nodes.desc: Pulsed magnetoplasmadynamic (MPD) thrusters offer ease of power scaling, reduced test facility requirements, and the potential of launch cost reductions through efficient high specific impulse operation at power levels which make them attractive for several primary propulsion missions.

nodes.label: Electron cyclotron thrusters
nodes.desc: Electron cyclotron thrusters are thrusters that use one of several methods for ionizing and heating a plasma using electromagnetic (EM) waves.

nodes.label: Pulsed inductive thrusters
nodes.desc:
The Pulsed Inductive Thruster (PIT) is an electromagnetic plasma accelerator that has demonstrated, in single-shot or burst mode, efficiency of greater than 50%, and a specific impulse (Isp) range of 2,000 to 9,000 lbfs/lbm at nearly constant efficiency.

Reference: [Robert H. Frisbee and Ioannis G. Mikellides, _The Nuclear-Electric Pulsed Inductive Thruster (NuPIT): Mission Analysis for Prometheus_, 41st AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference and Exhibit, 2005](http://www-personal.umich.edu/~ianrit/PIT/PIT2.pdf)

nodes.label: Pulsed plasma thrusters
nodes.desc:
Pulsed plasma thrusters (PPTs) are high-specific-impulse, low-power electric thrusters. Pulsed plasma thrusters are ideal for applications in small spacecraft for attitude control, precision spacecraft control, and low-thrust maneuvers. 

Reference: https://www.nasa.gov/centers/glenn/about/fs23grc.html

nodes.label: Gridded ion thrusters
nodes.desc:
A gridded ion thruster (GIE) is a type of ion thrusters with a highly efficient low-thrust spacecraft propulsion running on electrical power. Gridded ion thrusters offer very attractive specific impulse, in the range of 1500-4000 seconds, with exhaust velocities up to about 100 km/s. 

Reference: J. S. Sovey, V. K. Rawlin, and M. J. Patterson, _Ion Propulsion Development Projects in U. S.: Space Electric Rocket Test 1 to Deep Space 1_, Journal of Propulsion and Power, Vol. 17, No. 3, May–June 2001, pp. 517-526.

nodes.label: Pulsed inductive thruster
nodes.desc:
A pulsed inductive thruster (PIT) is a form of ion thruster, used in spacecraft propulsion. It is a plasma propulsion engine using perpendicular electric and magnetic fields to accelerate a propellant with no electrode. It operates by pulsing high current through an inductor, typically a coil of some type, producing an electromagnetic field that drives current in a plasma, accelerating it to high speed.

Reference: [K. Polzin, et al., _State-of-the-Art and Advancement Paths for Inductive Pulsed Plasma Thrusters_, MDPI Aerospace, 2020](https://www.mdpi.com/2226-4310/7/8/105/pdf)

nodes.label: Xenon feed system (XFS)
nodes.desc:
A xenon feed system (XFS) is designed for storing and supplying the required amount of working substance to the thruster. Xenon feed systems are currently under development at NASA (TRL 6) for the NEXT-C thruster.

Reference: [Gridded Ion Thrusters (NEXT-C) - NEXT Ion Engine Test Firing](https://www1.grc.nasa.gov/space/sep/gridded-ion-thrusters-next-c/)

nodes.label: 7-kW power processor unit (PPU)
nodes.desc: The development of powerful power processor unit will be on par with the development of more powerful ion thrusters.

nodes.label: Advanced xenon PMS
nodes.desc: This node accounts for highly flexible advanced xenon propellant management systems (PMS).

nodes.label: 7-kW ion thruster
nodes.desc: This node accounts for the production of a 7-kW ion thruster.

nodes.label: Hall-effect thrusters
nodes.desc:
In spacecraft propulsion, a Hall-effect thruster (HET) is a type of ion thruster in which the propellant is accelerated by an electric field.

Reference: [Hofer, Richard R. (June 2004). _Development and Characterization of High-Efficiency, High-Specific Impulse Xenon Hall Thrusters_. NASA/CR – 2004-21309. NASA STI Program](https://ntrs.nasa.gov/citations/20040084644)

nodes.label: Atmosphere-breathing electric propulsion
nodes.desc: Atmosphere-breathing electric propulsion, or air-breathing electric propulsion, shortly ABEP, is a propulsion technology for spacecraft, which could allow thrust generation in low orbits without the need of on-board propellant, by using residual gases in the atmosphere as propellant. Atmosphere-breathing electric propulsion could make a new class of long-lived, low-orbiting missions feasible.

nodes.label: Electron bombardment thrusters
nodes.desc:
An electron bombardment thruster is one of the most promising forms of electric space propulsion and one of only two forms of ion propulsion currently employed aboard spacecraft, the other being the Hall effect thruster. In an electron bombardment thruster, a gas propellant enters a discharge chamber at a controlled rate. A hot, hollow cathode (negative electrode) at the center of the chamber emits electrons, which are attracted to a cylindrical anode (positive electrode) around the walls of the chamber. Some of the electrons collide with and ionize atoms of the propellant, creating positively-charged ions. These ions are then drawn toward a high-voltage electric field set up between two closely-spaced grids at the downstream end of the chamber.

Reference: [Electron Bombardment Thruster by David Darling](https://www.daviddarling.info/encyclopedia/E/electronbomthruster.html)

nodes.label: > 150 µN thrust ionic liquid electrospray
nodes.desc:
Ionic liquid electrospray thrusters are capable of producing microNewton precision thrust
at a high thrust–power ratio but have yet to demonstrate lifetimes that are suitable for most missions.
Accumulation of propellant on the extractor and accelerator grids is thought to be the most significant
life-limiting mechanism.

Reference: [A. Thuppul, et al., _Lifetime Considerations for Electrospray Thrusters_, MDPI Aerospace, doi:10.3390/aerospace7080108, 2020](https://www.mdpi.com/2226-4310/7/8/108/pdf)

nodes.label: Electrospray Colloid Electric Propulsion System (ECEPS)
nodes.desc:
An Electrospray Colloid Electric Propulsion System (ECEPS) consists of many subsystems including a colloid thrust head (CTH), a propellant supply and feed system (PSFS) and a power processing unit (PPU). The main interest in electrospray devices is their use on CubeSats and other forms of nanosatellites for attitude control applications. These systems may also extend the spacecraft’s lifetime by counteracting the drag force experienced in low Earth orbit.

Reference: [_Further developments of electrospray colloid electric propulsion system_ by the European Space Agency](https://www.esa.int/Enabling_Support/Space_Engineering_Technology/Shaping_the_Future/Further_developments_of_electrospray_colloid_electric_propulsion_system)

nodes.label: Variable specific impulse electrospray thruster
nodes.desc: Having electrospray thrusters with a variable specific impulse (Isp) will provide extensive support for manned missions to Mars, and has enormous potential for a deep space missions.

nodes.label: 1 MW thruster for deep space
nodes.desc: 1 MegaWatt thrusters are a key evolution for deep space exploration missions in lesser time. This could, for example, minimize the duration of a travel to Mars.

nodes.label: Pulsed
nodes.desc: Pulsed reactors attempt to transfer the energy directly from the neutrons to the working mass, allowing the exhaust to reach temperatures far beyond the melting point of the reactor core. As specific impulse varies directly with temperature, capturing the energy of the relativistic neutrons allows for a dramatic increase in performance. In other words, pulse systems drive specific impulse amplifications.

nodes.label: Non-antimatter
nodes.desc: https://www.markdownguide.org/cheat-sheet/

nodes.label: Antimatter "catalyzed"
nodes.desc: Antimatter-catalyzed nuclear pulse propulsion is a variation of nuclear pulse propulsion based upon the injection of antimatter into a mass of nuclear fuel to initiate a nuclear chain reaction for propulsion when the fuel does not normally have a critical mass.

nodes.label: Antimatter "catalyzed"
nodes.desc: Antimatter-catalyzed nuclear steady-state propulsion is a variation of nuclear propulsion based upon the injection of antimatter into a mass of nuclear fuel to initiate a nuclear chain reaction for propulsion.

nodes.label: Variable thrust and multi-burn motor
nodes.desc: A multi-burn motor is a restartable solid rocket fuel engine that has the capability to increase or decrease the thrust based on a given situation at a certain time of the lifespan.

nodes.label: 4.5-kW hall thruster
nodes.desc:
This node accounts for the development of 4.5-kW Hall Thruster Propulsion Systems (HTPS). Aerojet has been developing a family of Hall thrusters and PPUs since the mid 1990’s. This development has included both 2 kW and 4 kW class HTs designated as the BPT-2000 and BPT-4000. The next step was the design of a 4.5 kW HTPS.

Reference: [Jack Fisher et al., _The Development and Qualification of a 4.5 kW Hall Thruster Propulsion System for GEO Satellite Applications_, 28th IEPC, 2021](http://electricrocket.org/IEPC/0295-0303iepc-full.pdf)

nodes.label: Electric thruster with anode layer (TAL)
nodes.desc:
Among Hall thruster technologies, the thruster with anode layer (TAL) has much wider technical capabilities, especially in the high-power regime of operation.

Reference: [Michael Keidar and Iain D. Boyd, _Modeling of a high-power thruster with anode layer_, Physics of Plasmas, 11, 1715 (2004)](https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.1668642)

nodes.label: Field Emission Electric Propulsion systems
nodes.desc: Field-emission electric propulsion (FEEP) is an advanced electrostatic space propulsion concept, a form of ion thruster, that uses a liquid metal as a propellant – usually either caesium, indium, or mercury. Field launcher thrusters (FEEP) have a power ranging in the kW, with a specific impulse of 6000 seconds.

nodes.label: Colloid micro-propulsion
nodes.desc: A colloid or electrospray thruster is a type of low thrust electric propulsion rocket engine that uses electrostatic acceleration of charged liquid droplets for propulsion.

nodes.label: Radio-frequency ion technology
nodes.desc:
Radio-frequency ion thrusters belong to the class of gridded ion engines. Radio frequency thrusters ionize the propellant in an oscillating electro-magnetic field. The propellant enters the ionizer via an integrated insulator a nd gas distributor. The ionizer vessel is made of an insulating material (quartz or alumina), and it is surrounded by the induction coil.

Reference: [H. J. Leiter et al., _Evolution of the AIRBUS DS GmbH Radio Frequency Ion
Thruster Family_, 34th International Electric Propulsion Conference and 6th Nano-satellite Symposium, 2015](https://www.space-propulsion.com/brochures/radio_frequency_ion_propulsion_evolution.pdf)

nodes.label: Microscope FEEP Electric Propulsion System (FEPS)
nodes.desc:
FEPS is an evolution of the FEEP thruster. It was used by CNES's MICROSCOPE mission which aimed at verifying the Equivalence Principle between the inertial mass and the gravitational mass of two different
bodies.

nodes.label: 50 kW hall thruster
nodes.desc:
An experimental investigation was conducted on a laboratory model Hall thruster designed to operate at power levels up to 50 kW.

Reference: [David T. Jacobson and Robert S. Jankovsky, _Performance Evaluation of a 50kW Hall Thruster_, January 2000, DOI: 10.2514/6.1999-457](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/24303494_Performance_Evaluation_of_a_50kW_Hall_Thruster)

nodes.label: 100 kW hall thruster
nodes.desc: Hall thrusters are an attractive EP technology to be scaled to 50- to 100-kW class devices for these high-power missions.

nodes.label: 100 W electrospray
nodes.desc: A colloid or electrospray thruster is a type of low thrust electric propulsion rocket engine that uses electrostatic acceleration of charged liquid droplets for propulsion.

nodes.label: Ion thruster miniaturization
nodes.desc: Electric propulsion capability helps a remote sensing satellite to combine high resolution with short revisit times. Using miniaturized systems results in gains in terms of volume and mass.

nodes.label: 8-cm Xenon Ion Propulsion System (XIPS)
nodes.desc: The 8-cm XIP thruster is based on space-qualified in-orbit flight heritage technology of bigger thrusters and is designed for small satellite applications.

nodes.label: Ion Control System (ICS) maturation
nodes.desc: This node accounts for the ICS maturation for satellites, including nanosatellites and CubeSats.

nodes.label: Hall thruster specific impulse increase
nodes.desc: Increase specific impulse, throttle-ability and lifetime to make Hall propulsion systems applicable to deep space science missions.

nodes.label: Multi-mission reusable EP systems
nodes.desc: Electric propulsion systems should be developed such that the products can support multiple missions or destinations with a broad performance and application spectrum.

nodes.label: Leveraging and consolidation of EP products
nodes.desc: Leveraging and consolidation of Electric Propulsion products to take advantage of development investments and higher flight rate of the community as a whole. This may take the form of a reusable SEP stage. This will reduce system costs, and reduce the time and cost for future qualifications.

nodes.label: Continued emphasis on utilization of flight data
nodes.desc: Continued emphasis on utilization of the current flight data (Artemis, Deep Space 1, Dawn, Smart-1, GOCE, commercial telecommunication satellites, etc.) to validate the models that will be used by the spacecraft designers in the future. This also implies an increased focus on instrumenting future missions to gain additional flight data and reduce future risk.

nodes.label: Higher power electric propulsion
nodes.desc: Development of operational electric propulsion systems at significantly higher power levels, from 10 to 150 kW, requires a coordinated research, design, and systems engineering effort.

nodes.label: Krypton usage investigation
nodes.desc: Investigate replacing Xenon with Krypton. Krypton is attractive for missions requiring both high Isp and high-propellant throughput. An issue for further investigation is whether Krypton would be preferred to Xenon at the thruster power levels now chosen for Xenon Hall thrusters.

nodes.label: Hall thruster life span increase
nodes.desc: The life of Hall thrusters is being limited by the erosion of the discharge chamber in which the plasma is ionized and accelerated. Erosion is attributed to ion bombardment of the chamber by energetic particles. Erosion of the magnetic circuit elements alters the topography and changes the thruster’s operational characteristics.

nodes.label: Propellant management technologies development
nodes.desc: For all electric propulsion thrusters at any power level there is a need for developing PPUs and propellant management technologies and for assessing spacecraft integration issues.

nodes.label: Reducing the mass of PPUs
nodes.desc: The most promising approach to this appears to be a solar-electric drive that uses a high-voltage solar array to provide power directly to a Hall thruster. Increased funding is needed to advance this technology.

nodes.label: Standardization of EP engineering processes
nodes.desc: Standardization of engineering processes and testing facilities employed in the design, manufacturing and qualification of the current electric propulsion systems. Test and validation processes should be better documented and perhaps made more formal to increase result confidence. This will be particularly important for performance parameters that push our measurement abilities such as microNewton thrusters.

nodes.label: Rapid, efficient, and affordable propulsion systems
nodes.desc:
Develop systems that provide rapid, efficient, and affordable transportation to, from, and around space destinations. Once in space, the ability to travel to a particular destination is a function of the laws of orbital mechanics, vehicle mass, and propulsion system efficiency. Human and robotic exploration requires transportation throughout the solar system and is limited by the performance of today’s propulsion systems.

Addressing the above will pave the way for the ultimate goal of an all electric propulsion spacecraft where the benefits of electric propulsion can be fully brought to bear on the appropriate space missions.

nodes.label: Nanometer-level precision propulsion systems
nodes.desc: Reach nanometer-level precision positioning control requirements for missions such as LISA.

nodes.label: Aneutronic fusion spacecraft architecture
nodes.desc:
The goal of this project is to provide framework to realize fusion propulsion for long-range space travel; analyze "hybrid" schemes with a solar or fission primary energy source along with a sub-critical fusion reactor used as a plasma space propulsion system Objective: conduct a feasibility study for a novel, fusion-powered, space propulsion architecture that can ultimately change drastically the potential for human and robotic space exploration. The object of this proposal is to conduct a feasibility study for a novel, fusion-powered, space propulsion architecture that can ultimately change drastically the potential for human and robotic space exploration. The proposed design is based on neutron-free nuclear fusion as the primary energy source. An innovative beam conditioning/nozzle concept enables useful propulsive thrust directly from the fusion products, while some fraction of the energy is extracted via direct conversion into electricity for use in the reactor and spacecraft systems. This study focuses on providing the framework required to make fusion propulsion an appealing proposition for long-range space travel (by integrating the power generation and propulsion systems) rather than on the development of a specific fusion reactor concept. However, the scope of this study is not constrained by the immediate availability of fusion energy since it also analyzes "hybrid" schemes with a solar or fission primary energy source along with a sub-critical fusion reactor used as a plasma space propulsion system.

Reference: [Aneutronic Fusion Spacecraft Architecture](https://techport.nasa.gov/view/4373)

nodes.label: Bimodal ion-chemical thruster system
nodes.desc:
A top candidate “green” monopropellant proposed as a safe replacement for hydrazine in spacecraft systems is also shown in tests to be a high performance propellant for ion electrospray thrusters. The proposed effort is to take full advantage of these remarkable characteristics to develop an efficient bimodal ion-chemical thruster system using a common propellant supply tank. This proposal responds directly to the Dual Mode Propulsion focus area in the T2.03 STTR topic.  The expected mass and volume savings, increased propellant use efficiency and the added flexibility in thrusting options (high thrust with moderate Isp and lower thrust with high Isp) will significantly augment the operational propulsion and attitude control ranges, especially in small spacecraft applications. Phase I demonstrated and tested an efficient propellant management system interfacing the high pressure monopropellant tank with the ion electrospray thruster arrays. This allows the development in Phase II of a complete protoflight system, including multiple thruster arrays and control electronics, that can be integrated into a space mission. The Phase II development will leverage the existing ion electrospray thruster technology, and integrate it with the new propellant management system to provide a multi-thruster ion propulsion system. The assembly will be designed to interface with an existing compact chemical thruster to achieve a complete proto-flight bi-modal propulsion system, ready for integration and flight testing on a space platform.

Reference: [Bimodal Ion-Chemical Thruster System](https://techport.nasa.gov/view/113121)

nodes.label: Project Orion
nodes.desc: Thermonuclear devices exploded against a pusher plate.

nodes.label: Pulsed fission fusion propulsion (PuFF)
nodes.desc:
The pulsed fission fusion propulsion (PuFF) system envisions using a pulsed z-pinch to compress a fission-fusion target. The resulting deflagration expands against a magnetic nozzle to produce thrust and generate recharge energy for the next pulse. A z-Pinch is a device that is commonly used to compress laboratory plasmas to high pressures (~1 Mbar) for very short timescales (~100 ns). An electrical discharge produces a high axial current along the outer surface of a column of plasma; this current in turn generates a very strong toroidal magnetic field. This self-generated magnetic field interacts with the axial current via the Lorentz force and radially compresses the plasma column, bringing it to very high densities and temperatures. This team is exploring a modified Z-pinch geometry as a propulsion system by encasing the fission- fusion target in a sheath of liquid lithium, providing a current return path. Numerical esults have been promising, the level of compression is sufficient to reach fission criticality. The fission energy boosts the fusion reaction rate, generating more neutrons which boost the fission process. This concept will potentially reach specific impulses of 30,000 sec with thrust levels sufficient to travel to Mars in a month and to interstellar space in a few decades.

Reference: [_Pulsed Fission-Fusion (PuFF) Propulsion Concept_ by Robert Adams (NASA)](https://www.nasa.gov/directorates/spacetech/niac/2018_Phase_I_Phase_II/PulsedFission-Fusion_Propulsion_Concept/)

nodes.label: External compression systems
nodes.desc: Antiproton catalyzed inertial confinement fusion: externally-compressed pellet containing both fusion and fission

nodes.label: Systems without external compression
nodes.desc: Antiproton catalyzed fusion: pellet with both fission and fusion fuel elements. No external compression, but possible explosive outer layer to pellet.

nodes.label: Toroidal hybrid reactor
nodes.desc: A toroidal hybrid reactor is a fusion reactor jacketed by a fission reactor.

nodes.label: Antiproton gas dynamic mirror systems
nodes.desc:
A gasdynamic mirror is a type of magnetic mirror confinement system with a large aspect ratio (length >> radius) operating at a high plasma density to overcome the major instability modes found in classical mirror machines. In contrast to a classical mirror for which the ion mean free path is much greater than the system length, the ion confinement time in a gasdynamic mirror is a much stronger function of the mirror ratio. Thus, increasing the mirror ratio in a gasdynamic mirror produces a much greater effect on plasma confinement, and as such gasdynamic mirrors are usually operated at high mirror ratios.

Reference: [_Study of the Gasdynamic Mirror (GDM)
Propulsion System_, PhD thesis by Ricky Tang](https://pepl.engin.umich.edu/pdf/2011_Tang_Thesis.pdf)

nodes.label: Autonomous vehicle system management
nodes.desc: This autonomy is necessary to manage a large, complex spacecraft with limited crew members and skills available.

nodes.label: Autonomous in-space 3D printing
nodes.desc: 3D printing could revolutionize space exploration by helping astronauts create objects in space and on-demand.

nodes.label: Autonomous proximity operations
nodes.desc:
Future space debris removal and on-orbit servicing missions to refuel, repair or deorbit end-of-life and defunct satellites require proximity operations and, eventually, docking to non-cooperative space vehicles.

Reference: [J. Ventura, _Autonomous Proximity Operations for Noncooperative Space Target_, Munich Technical University (TUM) Dissertation, 2016](https://mediatum.ub.tum.de/doc/1324836/1324836.pdf)

nodes.label: Oxygen and methane production
nodes.desc: This node accounts for Oxygen and methane production via electrolysis and Sabatier systems.

nodes.label: Mission consumables production
nodes.desc: ISRU system concept for autonomous robotic excavation and processing of Mars soil to extract water for use in exploration missions. Resource processing for production of mission consumables (fuel, polymers, ...), and manufacturing and repair with in-situ resources are two majors utilities.

nodes.label: Asteroids volatile capture
nodes.desc: Capture of volatiles will be a major milestone for ISRU activities. Examples of volatiles include Nitrogen, Iron, etc.

nodes.label: ECLS consumables
nodes.desc: This node focused on ECLS consumables covers all technologies for collecting and processing fluids and gases to be used as consumables for ECLS in human habitats (e.g. oxygen, hydrogen, nitrogen, water).

nodes.label: Limited knowledge on existing resources
nodes.desc: There is a lack of knowledge on the existing resources that can be used at the site of exploration. Besides, there are unknown uncertainties associated with these resources (form, amount, distribution, contaminants, terrain).

nodes.label: Lack of autonomous robots for long duration, autonomous operations
nodes.desc: Lack of autonomous robots for long duration, autonomous operation and failure recovery with no crew, non-continuous monitoring, and time delay.

nodes.label: In-space consumables production
nodes.desc: In-Situ Resource Utilization (ISRU) is a key enabler for the expansion of space activities beyond low Earth orbit and ISRU for consumables production will drive the crewed missions to the different celestial bodies.

nodes.label: Rocket fuel synthesis
nodes.desc: This node accounts for rocket fuel synthesis using the Fisher-Tropsch Process, for example. Developing an innovative, efficient and robust reactor that will use CO2 to produce oxygen, but also methane and obtain fuel for space rockets will lead to missions toward further destinations.

nodes.label: Oxygen production using solar concentrator systems
nodes.desc:
This node accounts for Oxygen production using solar concentrator systems.

Reference: https://techport.nasa.gov/view/103072

nodes.label: Methane-powered rocket engine
nodes.desc: The main benefit of using methane for propulsion is that it has a higher performance than other fuels, meaning the rocket can be smaller. Its lower cost, too, means the total cost of launching can be brought down.

nodes.label: Resource management
nodes.desc: This node accounts for resource acquisition, isolation, and preparation.

nodes.label: Ceramic microchannel reactor technology
nodes.desc:
Microchannel reactors show fast mass transfer and heat transfer while limited active surface area, which can be greatly increased by reducing channel sizes. However, conventional extrusion makes honeycomb ceramics with channel sizes above 100 μm. This study has prepared ceramic microchannel reactors with channel sizes in the range of 1–100 μm by a one-step phase-inversion process, and channels are formed through the convection between coagulant and solvent. The effect of channel size on reaction performance was investigated by comparing two reactors with different channel sizes in dry reforming of methane. In addition, the microstructure of the reactors can be further tuned via sintering temperature to achieve high catalytic performance owing to the balanced active surface and mass transfer. Therefore, the microchannel reactors developed in this study represent a diagram-shift in the preparation of microchannel reactors by making channels with sizes less than 100 μm, which has potential applications in many catalytic reactions.

Reference: [Zhibo Zhao et al., _Ceramic microchannel reactors with channel sizes less than 100 μm prepared by a mesh-assisted phase-inversion process_, Ceramics International, 2021](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0272884221016722)

nodes.label: Proton-conducting ceramics technology
nodes.desc: This node accounts for proton-conducting ceramics for methane and oxygen production. Proton-conducting ceramics, which selectively separate H2 from any hydrogen-containing gas could play a role in the future of the growing hydrogen market.

nodes.label: Resource processing
nodes.desc: This node accounts for resource processing for production of storage feedstock materials, Suitable processing can transform the collected raw resources into useful materials and products.

nodes.label: Resource storage and distribution
nodes.desc: This node focused on resource storage and distribution covers all technologies required for storing and distributing fluids and gases.

nodes.label: Resource excavation
nodes.desc: The resources of space offer a means to enable sustainable exploration of the Moon and Solar. Excavating resources for means of becoming independent from Earth is a key milestone for long-term human presence on the Moon and Mars.

nodes.label: Optical mining
nodes.desc:
This node accounts for optical mining solutions. Optical mining is an approach for excavating an asteroid and extracting water and other volatiles into an inflatable bag, NASA's Mini Bee prototype is a great example of optical mining project.

Reference: [_Optical Mining of Asteroids, Moons, and Planets to Enable Sustainable Human Exploration and Space Industrialization_ by NASA](https://www.nasa.gov/directorates/spacetech/niac/2017_Phase_I_Phase_II/Sustainable_Human_Exploration/)

nodes.label: Planetary protection issues
nodes.desc: Lack of well established planetary protection requirements to be addressed. Forward contamination/sterilization, operating in a special region, creating a special region are key aspects to consider during resource excavation or utilization.

nodes.label: Limited systems withstanding extreme conditions
nodes.desc: There is a lack of efficient systems able to operate in extreme environments (temperature, pressure/vacuum, dust, radiation, grounding). Besides, there is also a lack of efficient systems able to operate in low gravity or micro-gravity environments (drill/excavation force vs mass, soil/liquid motion, thermal convection/radiation).

nodes.label: System survival capabilities
nodes.desc: Lack of capabilities to survive and operate after long duration dormancy or repeated start/stop cycles with lunar sun/shadow cycles.

nodes.label: Cryogenic fluid production, management, and transfer
nodes.desc: Demonstrate the applicability of technologies using chemical-physical processes for the gas of interest extraction and storage (liquefaction) for the Surface Cryogenic Production and Management (Storage & Transfer).

nodes.label: Dust mitigation
nodes.desc: Dust mitigation strategies for hardware are important for ISRU hardware life/performance. Dust mitigation strategies to mitigate dust due to landers and surface movement may be tied to In-Situ Construction. Test conceptual mitigation strategies for hardware interactions with lunar fines to reduce dust prevalence need to be performed with high accuracy.

nodes.label: Economic barriers
nodes.desc: Economic barriers to collecting, extracting, and processing the resources due to the energy, life, and performance of a system.

nodes.label: System barriers
nodes.desc: System barriers to manage the physical interfaces and interactions between ISRU and other systems. Technology enhancements are necessary.

nodes.label: Power generation and storage barriers
nodes.desc: ISRU processes can be extremely power-intensive as well as needing to be performed in challenging locations and environments.

nodes.label: Lack of system autonomy
nodes.desc: Technologies for Autonomous Operation need to be demonstrated and validated. Operation facilities that enable ISRU hardware to operate with no crew present and minimal or no support from human control. This includes communication needs, situational awareness, failure recovery, and remote maintenance capabilities. Sensors and dedicated hardware/software devices need to be demonstrated. Robotic systems operating autonomously need to communicate and cooperate among them and with the central control system.

nodes.label: ISRU processing system versatility
nodes.desc: Lack of various, versatile systems designed to incorporate ISRU products.

nodes.label: CO2 separation and methanation
nodes.desc:
This node accounts for carbon dioxide (CO2) collection, separation, and pressurization, and methanation for oxygen and fuel production. It is necessary to design and construct innovative, low mass, low power separation devices to recover carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide for on-site ISRU, in particular for Mars ISRU. Such a technology will have broad implications for gas storage and separations for gas-solid systems that are ideally suited for reduced gravitational environments.

Reference: [K. Walton and M. Douglas LeVan, _Separation of Carbon Monoxide and Carbon Dioxide for Mars ISRU_, NTRS, 2004](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/24391884_Separation_of_Carbon_Monoxide_and_Carbon_Dioxide_for_Mars_ISRU)

nodes.label: Data retrieval algorithm improvements
nodes.desc: The quality of a remote-sensing retrieval algorithm is another critical aspect that affects the quality of the final product. In fact, once the instrument has been deployed, the quality of the resulting observational data cannot be radically improved, while retrieval algorithms remain under constant improvement. In this regard, remote sensing retrieval algorithms constantly need significant advancements.

nodes.label: Solar cell integrated modulating retroreflector
nodes.desc:
An example of modulating retroreflector is the "DataCell". This DataCell device allows for simultaneous electrical energy harvesting (photovoltaic effect) and high-speed optical data communication (quantum-confined Stark effect) for free-space optical (FSO) links up to GHz rates in a single integrated device.

Reference: [R. Hoheisel et al., _DataCell - A Solar Cell Integrated Modulating Retroreflector_, 2020 47th IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference (PVSC), 2020](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/9300531)

nodes.label: THZ passive/active remote sensing
nodes.desc: Terahertz remote sensing is currently a primary research focus. Using a type of electromagnetic wave, it is possible to see various kinds of matter on Earth. Remote sensing systems which measure energy that is naturally available are called passive sensors. Examples of remote sensing assets include radiometers, visual systems, etc.

nodes.label: Multi-beam payloads calibration
nodes.desc:
Most multi-beam GEO satellites work on the low-inclination
GEO orbit. Due to various unexpected factors, e.g., the imperfect satellite orbit, attitude, and antenna deformation, the practical satellite beam pointing on the Earth surface will deviate unfortunately from its designed
theoretical location. In the satellite beam calibration system that utilizes downlink calibration, the satellite multi-beam antenna pointing
measurement system is generally composed of the reference
beam transmitted from the satellite and the ground calibration
station. The satellite transmits calibration beams to the group until power points (one point per beam) coincide on ground for calibration.

Reference: [C. Sun et al., _Modeling and Calibrating the Ground-Surface
Beam Pointing of GEO Satellite_, IEEE Access, doi:10.1109/ACCESS.2019.2931573, 2019](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=8778655)

nodes.label: Submillimeter-wave antenna
nodes.desc:
The millimeter-wave region of the electromagnetic spectrum is commonly defined as the 30- to 300-GHz frequency band or the 1-cm to 1-mm wavelength range. Thus, submillimeter-wave antennae use 0.1-10 THz bands. Utilization of such frequency bands for the design of data transmission and sensing systems has a number of advantages:

1. The very large bandwidth resolves the spectrum crowding problem and permits communication at very high data rates.

2. The short wavelength allows the design of antennas of high directivity but reasonable size, so that high-resolution radar and radiometric systems and very compact guidance systems become feasible.

3. Millimeter waves can travel through fog, snow, and dust much more readily than infrared or optical waves.

4. Finally, millimeter-wave transmitters and receivers lend themselves to integrated and, eventually, monolithic design approaches, resulting in RF heads which are rugged, compact, and inexpensive.

Reference: [F. Schwering and A. A. Oliner, _Millimeter-Wave Antennas_, Antenna Handbook, DOI: 10.1007/978-1-4615-2638-4_1, 1993](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-1-4615-2638-4_1)

nodes.label: Optical telecommunications
nodes.desc:
Laser communication in space is the use of free-space optical communication in outer space. Communication may be fully in space (an inter-satellite laser link) or in a ground-to-satellite or satellite-to-ground application. The main advantage of using laser communications over radio waves is increased bandwidth, enabling the transfer of more data in less time.

One of the main challenges is maintaining the necessary pointing accuracy over long distances.

nodes.label: Ground-based data processing architecture
nodes.desc: An Earth observation (EO) mission architecture where a large volume of raw EO data is first downlinked and then undergoes significant processing on the ground, e.g. to automatically extract insights from that data.

nodes.label: Fractional architecture
nodes.desc: Fractional architecture is defined as a "Uberized" model for ground station networks. In the fractionated architecture paradigm a satellite is split into physically independent, formation-flying fractions that are connected. The same can be applied for network antennae.

nodes.label: Distributed architecture
nodes.desc:
A distributed architecture is a network of ground stations placed globally connected via the internet and performing an automatic scan of satellite (and other beacon) signals, storing and sending them back to a central server, where they can be accessed by the satellite owner.

Ground station network is not "owned" by the mission operator but is "leased" as a service.

Reference: [You are welCOMe! ](https://2014.spaceappschallenge.org/project/you-are-welcome/)

nodes.label: High throughput communications architecture
nodes.desc: A high throughput communications architecture is a communications architecture that is able to transmit a large amount of data (in the context of an EO mission) with ata rates in the order of X Mbps.

nodes.label: Space-based data processing architecture
nodes.desc: An Earth observation (EO) mission architecture where raw EO data are processed on-board in order to produced reduced volume secondary derivative data to downlink. Thus downlink volume is reduced, but on-board computing requirements are increased.

nodes.label: Ka-band objects observation and monitoring
nodes.desc:
NASA has embarked on a path to implement a high power, higher resolution radar system to:
• Track Near Earth Objects (NEOs)- asteroids and comets -100,000 times more accurately than optical telescopes, as part of a system to defend the Earth from major impacts.
• Characterize the size, shape, spin rate, and surface properties of these NEOs to determine which are suitable for eventual visits by crews or mining companies.
• Track orbital debris to ensure crew and spacecraft safety.

The path to the high-power radar will take evolutionary steps to lead to revolutionary capability.  The first step is KaBOOM.

NASA is pursuing a demonstration of coherent uplink arraying at 7.145-7.190 GHz (X-band) and 30-31 GHz (Ka-band) using three 12m diameter commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) antennas separated by 60m at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.  In addition, the Agency has demonstrated uplink arraying using up to three 34m antennas separated by ~250m at the Goldstone Deep Space Communication Complex in California and at X-band 7.1 GHz incorporating real-time correction for tropospheric phase fluctuations.  Such a successful demonstration would then enable NASA to design and establish a high power, high resolution, 24/7 availability radar system for
1. tracking and characterizing observations of Near Earth Objects,
2. tracking, characterizing and determining the statistics of small-scale (≤10cm) orbital debris,
3. incorporating the capability into the Agency's space communication and navigation tracking stations for emergency spacecraft commanding in the Ka-band era that NASA is entering, and
4. fielding capabilities of interest to other US government agencies.
The Ka-band radar offers the possibility of high range resolution (5 cm) and high spatial resolution, also 5 cm for orbital debris in geosynchronous orbit (GEO) around the Earth (about 22,000 miles above the surface).  The project will consist of three phases or evolutionary steps that will lead to the new revolutionary capability.  The beginning is KaBOOM.

NASA's KaBOOM is a space communication system at 8 and 30 GHz, currently in development at Kennedy Space Center, as the prelude to a high-power radar array. It aims to demonstrate a phased array uplink of widely spaced antennas with real-time compensation for atmospheric phase fluctuations.

nodes.label: Novel Ka-band high gain antenna design
nodes.desc:
Such a concept is in the best interest for future Earth Observing (EO) missions at Low Earth Orbit (LEO) that have stringent jitter requirements, and where a HGA with a dual axis gimbal seems unacceptable due to the jitter that could be induced to the observatory. 

NASA missions like for example Deformation, Ecosystem Structure and Dynamics of Ice (DESDynI), could benefit from the Ka band allocated bandwidth for data rates in the order of 1 Gbps, which is more than twice of what is available at X-band.

nodes.label: Scientific data collection in constellation configurations
Direct link communications between payloads
nodes.desc: Direct link communications between multiple payload bodies.

nodes.label: Automated support
nodes.desc: Automated support to management and operations.

nodes.label: Data analytical processing and data security
Intelligent data mining
nodes.desc: Intelligent data mining is to use the intelligent search to discover information within data warehouses those queries and reports cannot effectively reveal and to find the patterns in the data and infer rules from them, and use these patterns and rules to guide for decision making and forecasting. Intelligent data mining for ground data processing incorporates advantages of both knowledge acquisitions from data, and knowledge acquisition from experts.

nodes.label: Multi-level security architectures
nodes.desc:
Multilevel security or multiple levels of security (MLS) is the application of a computer system to process information with incompatible classifications (i.e., at different security levels), permit access by users with different security clearances and needs-to-know, and prevent users from obtaining access to information for which they lack authorization. Various system architectures have been proposed for high assurance enforcement of multilevel security.

Reference: [Multilevel security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilevel_security)

nodes.label: Distributed Spacecraft Mission (DSM) modeling
nodes.desc: A Distributed Spacecraft Mission (DSM) is a mission that involves multiple spacecraft to achieve one or more common goals.

nodes.label: Wave interaction and propagation models
nodes.desc: This node accounts for optimization of wave interaction and propagation models.

nodes.label: Circuitry for deployable sub payloads
nodes.desc: Circuitry for modulation, data transmission, and power amplification.

nodes.label: Microelectronics for digital and analog applications
nodes.desc: Microelectronics for digital and analog applications.

nodes.label: Quantum optical communications
nodes.desc:
Quantum optical communications is an emerging space-based technology that could potentially increase the information capacity of communications networks significantly and provide fundamentally secure communication links between trusted nodes within the network using Quantum Key Distribution (QKD). The Deep Space Quantum Link (DSQL) will develop the  technology to perform pioneering experiments on gravitational effects on quantum systems, test the basic assumptions of quantum theory, and demonstrate QKD at deep space distances.

The scientific objectives of the DSQL is to test the coupling of General Relativity, the physics most often associated with cosmology, with Quantum Field Theory, the physics of wave-like particles.  The DSQL will perform three experiments.

nodes.label: LEO-to-GEO optical intersatellite communications
nodes.desc: LEO-to-GEO optical intersatellite communications using laser communication terminals or other technologies may help boost resilience and reliability of broadband connectivity for end users by switching between LEO and GEO communication.

nodes.label: Mobile satellite communication services
nodes.desc: In contrast to fixed satellite services, mobile satellite services may be moved from one location to another (e.g. on moving vehicles). Though conventionally these have been utilised in the maritime and other transport sectors and mobile telecommunications, existing research projects a potential future convergence in markets provided by fixed and mobile satellite services.

nodes.label: Space-based global broadband communication services
nodes.desc: Current perspectives on future applications of satelliteenabled connectivity services envision the potential for global broadband (5G/6G) coverage. Current forecasts estimate global broadband to be a fast-growing $45bn market.

nodes.label: Quantum-encrypted communications
nodes.desc: Advances in quantum technologies offer the prospect of ‘unconditionally secure’ encrypted long-distance satellite-to-ground and inter-satellite optical communications using quantum key distribution.

nodes.label: Flexible satellite infrastructure
nodes.desc: Telecommunications has seen an increasing demand for flexible or ‘reprogrammable’ satellite technologies from operators. Flexible satellites may provide flexibility for providers by shifting between different services, e.g. television broadcasting and broadband connectivity, based on fluctuating demand.

nodes.label: Autonomous space traffic management
nodes.desc: Space Traffic Management (STM) encompasses the means and the rules to access, conduct activities in, and return from outer space safely, sustainably and securely. It is defined by the International Academy of Astronautics (IAA) as "the set of technical and regulatory provisions for promoting safe access into outer space, operations in outer space and return from outer space to Earth free from physical or radio-frequency interference."

nodes.label: Radar-based measurements
nodes.desc:
Radar technologies for debris detection and situational awareness: A prototype radar that will help Europe to develop capabilities in space-debris surveillance is performing above expectations, and is showing its capability to detect objects in low orbits.

Reference: [ESA debris radar detects first space objects](https://www.esa.int/Space_Safety/ESA_debris_radar_detects_first_space_objects)

nodes.label: Passive debris removal
nodes.desc: Active debris removal is typically used for large debris, while passive debris removal (PDR) is used for small debris.

nodes.label: Stored energy depletion and passivation
nodes.desc: Stored energy depletion and passivation technology development.

nodes.label: Spacecraft end of life passivation
nodes.desc: The passivation of a spacecraft is the removal of any internal energy contained in the vehicle at the end of its mission or useful life.

nodes.label: PMD (direct) with 99% end-of-life reliability
nodes.desc: A high post-mission disposal (PMD) success rate will be needed in the near future to stabilize the evolution of the space debris population.

nodes.label: On-orbit contactless debris removal
nodes.desc: The space debris removal is one of the most important challenges of astronautics. The creation of contactless transportation systems based on the ion beam is a promising direction for solving this problem. The orientation of the debris object in the ion beam has a great influence on the magnitude and direction of the force transmitted by this beam.

nodes.label: Autonomous orbit maintenance
nodes.desc: Orbit maintenance encompasses the means to take care of the global situational awareness for a specific orbit, for instance dealing with the debris issues. Autonomous orbit maintenance will provide support to the ground using spacecraft awareness on orbit.

nodes.label: Passive atmospheric reentry support systems
nodes.desc: This node accounts for the development of passive atmospheric reentry support systems.

nodes.label: Space object shape characterization
nodes.desc:
Space object shape characterization using light magnitude measurements from multiple observers.
Reference: https://techport.nasa.gov/view/96184

nodes.label: D4D technologies development
nodes.desc: This node accounts for the development of Design for demise (D4D) technologies. “Design for Demise” are solutions at different design levels to meeting the space debris mitigation requirement to minimize the risk to human population following uncontrolled re-entry of spacecraft.

nodes.label: In-orbit risk assessment and analysis
nodes.desc: This node accounts for in-orbit risk assessment, conjunction detection and analysis.

nodes.label: Design for demise technologies
nodes.desc:
Design for demise (D4D) is the solution proposed at system design level to ensure compliance to the risk requirement using uncontrolled entry.

Reference: [D. Riley et al., _Design for Demise Techniques to Reduce Re-Entry Casulaty Risk_, 66th International Astronautical Congress, 2015](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/293824337_DESIGN_FOR_DEMISE_TECHNIQUES_TO_REDUCE_RE-ENTRY_CASUALTY_RISK)

nodes.label: Reentry windows prediction
nodes.desc: Ground safety computation and reentry windows prediction is essential for safe reentry of debris: a landing in a town would cause important damage. Prediction windows narrow closer to the reentry event. However, improvements to predict the reentry earlier than we can today are being carried out.

nodes.label: Laser technologies development
nodes.desc:
Laser Debris Removal (LDR) by ground-based lasers is intended to clean the Low Earth Orbits (LEO) from hazardous small and medium size debris.

The LDR concept uses a beam of closely directed laser energy projected from the ground to modify the trajectory of debris objects in low Earth orbits (LEO). When the pulsed laser beam hits the object, it ablates and vaporizes a thin layer of material, and then it creates plasma and an exhaust plume, which leaves the debris surface at such high velocities it generates enough force to push the object into a new orbit or to cause debris to re-enter the atmosphere.

Reference: [_Laser-Based Space Debris Removal: An Approach for Protecting the Critical Infrastructure Space_ by Dr. Hans-Albert Eckel and Dr.-Ing. Dennis Göge](https://www.japcc.org/articles/laser-based-space-debris-removal/)

nodes.label: Ground-based optical measurements
nodes.desc:
High-altitude surveys for faint objects. Follow-up and catalogue
maintenance of objects in high-altitude orbits. Development and
operation of planning and processing software for optical
measurements of artificial objects. Orbit determination and
observations for anomaly resolution. Planning and performance
analysis for optical space-based sensors. For example, Earth-based telescopes used for debris monitoring.

nodes.label: Mitigation models creation
nodes.desc: Models creation for traffic and mitigation actions is the first step toward debris-free orbits. Using traffic models and possible mitigation practices, the future evolution of the space debris environment will be forecast, thus ensuring a safe future for orbital systems.

nodes.label: Electrostatic accelerators development
nodes.desc:
Micrometeoroid detection in space usually involves high-velocity impact phenomena. In-situ dust detectors should be calibrated by a microparticle accelerator with a mass and velocity range comparable to micrometeoroids. Electrostatic accelerators development for micro-debris detection is the next step following macro-debris detection.

Reference: [S. Hasegawa et al., _Design of electrostatic accelerators for the development of microparticle detectors in Japan_, Advances in Space Research, Volume 23, Issue 1, 1999](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0273117798002385)

nodes.label: Active debris removal
nodes.desc: Active debris removal (ADR) implies missions with the capability to interact with debris, and potentially collect or mitigate them to secure safe orbits. Active debris removal is typically used for large debris, while passive debris removal (PDR) is used for small debris.

nodes.label: In-space debris mitigation
nodes.desc: Space debris mitigation is the field focusing on the mitigation of the risks caused by debris and the limitation of the spread and numbers of debris. In-space mitigation focuses on debris mitigation using mitigation methods on orbit.

nodes.label: Debris lifetime prediction tools
nodes.desc: This node accounts for the orbital lifetime predictions of a debris, and the development of more accurate debris mitigation analysis software.

nodes.label: Debris monitoring
nodes.desc: Debris monitoring consists in surveilling dangerous debris to avoid collisions and the creation of new debris. It is extremely useful for debris remediation and for the protection of active systems.

nodes.label: Space-based optical measurements
nodes.desc:
Space-based radar and optical detection techniques to characterize
the small-particle environment. Development, flight and data
evaluation. For example, in-space telescopes used for debris monitoring.

nodes.label: Medium-powered (5 kW) ground-based laser
nodes.desc:
The threat of catastrophic or debilitating collisions between active spacecraft and orbital debris is gaining increased attention as prescient predictions of population
evolution are confirmed.

Scientists investigate the feasibility of using a medium-powered (5 kW) ground-based laser combined with a ground-based telescope to prevent collisions between debris objects in low-Earth orbit (LEO), for which there is no current, effective mitigation strategy. The scheme utilizes photon pressure alone as a means to perturb the orbit of a debris object. Applied over multiple engagements, this alters the debris orbit sufficiently to reduce the risk of an upcoming conjunction.

Reference: [J. Mason et al., _Orbital Debris-Debris Collision Avoidance_, Advances in Space Research, 2011](https://cisac.fsi.stanford.edu/publications/orbital_debrisdebris_collision_avoidance)

nodes.label: Ion beam technologies development
nodes.desc: Actively removing existing manmade debris from high-altitude crowded regions in low earth orbit is a necessary step for the sustainability of space. Yet, no active debris removal (ADR) mission has been flown to date and there is still no consensus on the best way to implement large-scale, reliable ADR operations in the future. One way to tackle the formidable technical challenges of such missions is to exploit removal methods not requiring hard mechanical contact with the target such as ion beam technologies.

nodes.label: On-ground debris mitigation
nodes.desc: With today’s rate of 70–90 launches a year, an increasing number of launches injecting 30 or more small satellites into orbit at once, and assuming future break-ups will continue at mean historical rates of four to five per year, the number of objects in space is expected to increase steadily. Space debris mitigation guidelines provide a framework for ‘what’ needs to be done. The ‘how’ mitigation measures must be implemented is specified in a more formal manner, via international standards, or via binding national requirements for the design and operation of space systems.

nodes.label: HVI test techniques development and evaluation
nodes.desc:
Hypervelocity impact (HVI) test techniques are focused on debris impact. HVI testing simulates micrometeoroids and orbital debris impacts on spacecraft shielding, components, and materials in various test configurations.

With over two decades of extensive testing for NASA, DOD, other government agencies, and commercial industry our team has developed expertise and testing methods that allow us to complete over 600 shots per year with low costs.

HVI improvement and evaluation could there help reaching a safe, sustainable LEO, NEO, or GEO.

nodes.label: PMD laws and regulations
nodes.desc: This node accounts for post-mission disposal (PMD) laws and regulations. Strong compliance with post-mission disposal guidelines is the most effective long-term means of stabilizing the space debris environment.

nodes.label: Reliable post-mission disposal technologies
nodes.desc: Reliability lies at the heart of successful satellite Post Mission Disposal (PMD) assuming satellites have been designed for PMD.

nodes.label: Autonomous formation flying
nodes.desc:
Formation flying is commonly identified as the collective usage of two or more cooperative spacecraft to exercise the function of a single monolithic virtual instrument. The distribution of tasks and payloads among fleets of coordinated smaller satellites offers the possibility to overcome the classical limitations of traditional single-satellite systems. The science return is enhanced through observations made with larger, configurable baselines and an improved degree of redundancy can be achieved in the event of failures. Different classes of formation flying missions are currently under discussion within the engineering and science community: technology demonstration missions, synthetic aperture interferometers and gravimeters for Earth observation, multi-spacecraft interferometers in the infrared and visible wavelength regions as a key to new astrophysics discoveries and to the direct search for terrestrial exoplanets. These missions are characterized by different levels of complexity, mainly dictated by the payload metrology and actuation needs, and require a high level of on-board autonomy to satisfy the continuously increasing demand of relative navigation and control accuracy.

Reference: [S. D'Amico, _Autonomous formation flying in low earth orbit_, Delft Technical University (TU Delft) Dissertation, 2010](https://repository.tudelft.nl/islandora/object/uuid%3Aa10e2d63-399d-48e5-884b-402e9a105c70)

nodes.label: Health monitoring and FDIR enhancements
nodes.desc:
Fault detection, isolation, and recovery (FDIR) is a subfield of control engineering which concerns itself with monitoring a system, identifying when a fault has occurred, and pinpointing the type of fault and its location. FDIR is designed to identify errors in real time through ongoing sensor cross-checks, to isolate them as needed then making up for them by triggering sensor or actuator reconfigurations – or even, in case of extreme emergency, triggering an autonomous collision avoidance maneuver.
