One aspect of neurorobotics is the development of robotic systems that can interact with the environment in a similar way as living organisms do. This can be achieved by incorporating sensors and actuators, as well as AI algorithms that allow the robot to process information from its environment and make decisions about how to act.

Another aspect of neurorobotics is the use of robots as a tool for investigating the nervous system. Robots can be used to simulate different aspects of the nervous system, such as the movement of joints or the processing of sensory information, and can help researchers to understand how the nervous system works.

Some of the applications of neurorobotics include:

Rehabilitation robotics: using robots to aid in the recovery of motor function in individuals with neurological disorders or injuries
Biomedical research: Using robots to study the biology of the nervous system, and how to replicate it.
Prosthetics: Creating robotic limbs that can be controlled by the nervous system.
Intelligent transportation: implementing neurorobotics in vehicles to improve their safety, efficiency, and ability to adapt to changing conditions.
Assistive technology: Developing robots to assist people with disabilities or elderly people.
It's important to note that neurorobotics is a rapidly evolving field, and researchers are still exploring ways to integrate neural models and AI into robotic systems. Also, there's a need for cross-disciplinary collaboration to fully leverage the potential of neurorobotics and to address the ethical implications of the field.

nodes.label: Mobile Apps
nodes.desc:
Mobile apps can be beneficial for brain disorders because they allow individuals to access treatment and support from anywhere, at any time, using their smartphones or other mobile devices. Some ways mobile apps could be used to benefit individuals with brain disorders include:

Remote monitoring and treatment: Mobile apps can be used to track symptoms, administer assessments, and deliver treatment interventions remotely. This allows individuals to receive treatment and support while they are at home or on the go, and can make it easier for them to stick to their treatment plan.

Medication reminders: Many brain disorders require individuals to take medications on a regular basis. Mobile apps can be used to set reminders for medication doses and help individuals to stay on schedule.

Education and self-help: Mobile apps can provide individuals with information about their condition and strategies for managing their symptoms. This can help to increase individuals' understanding of their condition and empower them to take an active role in managing their symptoms.

Social support: Mobile apps can provide individuals with a sense of connection to others who are going through similar experiences. They can also connect individuals with mental health professionals who can provide support and guidance.

Data collection: Mobile apps can be used to collect data on an individual's symptoms and daily activities, which can be used to better understand the condition and evaluate the effectiveness of treatment interventions.

Cognitive training: There are mobile apps that aim to improve cognitive abilities like memory, attention, and problem-solving by providing brain training exercises. This kind of apps could be beneficial for conditions such as dementia, ADHD, and traumatic brain injuries.

It's important to note that mobile apps should be used under the guidance of a healthcare professional, as they are not intended to replace traditional treatments and should be used in conjunction with other forms of therapy. Additionally, it's always good to read reviews, check for certifications and ensure the app is backed by scientific evidence before using it.

nodes.label: Brain Replacement
nodes.desc:
A futuristic view on brain replacement would involve significant advances in technology and science that would allow for the preservation of the brain after death, and the ability to connect the brain to a new body in such a way that the brain can control the body's movements and sensations.

In this hypothetical future, a brain would be able to be removed from a deceased person and be placed in a preservation solution, in order to keep it alive and functionable. After that, the brain would be connected to a new body, which would be either biological or robotic, that would provide the brain with the necessary support systems and input-output interfaces, such as sensors and actuators, allowing the brain to communicate with the body and control its movements.

However, such a view is highly speculative, and it is not clear if such a technology will ever be possible. Even if it was, there would be an immense amount of ethical and moral questions that would arise from the ability to replace brains, and how it would affect our understanding of personal identity, consciousness, and human nature. Additionally, it would require significant advances in other fields such as neuroscience, computer science and materials science to make it happen.

As for now, it is important to note that the idea of brain replacement is purely speculative, and there are many significant scientific and ethical challenges that would need to be overcome before it could be considered a viable option. And even if it ever becomes possible, it's likely that its use would be highly regulated, and the benefits and drawbacks will be carefully weighed before being made available to the public.

nodes.label: Focused Ultrasound
nodes.desc:
Focused ultrasound is a rapidly evolving, noninvasive therapeutic technology using ultrasonic energy to target tissue deep in the body without incisions or radiation. 

With focused ultrasound, an acoustic lens is used to concentrate multiple intersecting beams of ultrasound on a target deep in the body with extreme precision and accuracy. 

Currently, clinical research is ongoing for the treatment of brain tumors, essential tremor, and Parkinson’s disease.

Source: Focused ultrasound Foundation, Learn about ongoing clinical trials [here](https://www.fusfoundation.org/diseases-and-conditions/category/neurological/)

nodes.label: Psychotherapy
nodes.desc:
"Psychotherapy, or talk therapy, is a way to help people with a broad variety of mental illnesses and emotional difficulties. Psychotherapy can help eliminate or control troubling symptoms so a person can function better and can increase well-being and healing."

[What is psychotrapy](https://psychiatry.org/patients-families/psychotherapy)

nodes.label: Nutrition & Supplements
nodes.desc:
Many brain supplements focus on omega-3 fatty acids (such as those found in fish oil), vitamin E, various B vitamins, or various combinations. Why these?

There’s strong evidence that certain diets — like the Mediterranean diet, the DASH diet, and the MIND diet — can help improve cognitive function.

These diets contain foods with large amounts of these vitamins and minerals. But what is not clear is whether it’s the combination of nutrients in these diets that’s beneficial, or whether it’s specific ones or even certain amounts, or some other factors. Researchers have tried to answer these questions by testing how these individual nutrients affect cognitive health. So far limited studies have found no evidence they help, with a few rare exceptions.

[Don’t buy into brain health supplements](https://www.health.harvard.edu/mind-and-mood/dont-buy-into-brain-health-supplements

nodes.label: Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS)
nodes.desc: "Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) is a form of neuromodulation that uses constant, low direct current delivered via electrodes on the head. It was originally developed to help patients with brain injuries or neuropsychiatric conditions such as major depressive disorder." [Wiki]()

nodes.label: Antibodies
nodes.desc:
"Monoclonal antibodies (also called moAbs or mAbs) are proteins made in laboratories that act like proteins called antibodies in our bodies. Antibodies are parts of your immune system. They seek out the antigens (foreign materials) and stick to them in order to destroy them. Laboratory-made monoclonal antibodies help stimulate your own immune system.

The word “monoclonal” refers to the fact that the antibodies created in the laboratory are clones. They are exact copies of one antibody. The generic names of the products often include the letters “mab” at the end of the name."

[Source: Cleveland clinic](https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/treatments/22246-monoclonal-antibodies)

nodes.label: Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS)
nodes.desc: "Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is a neurosurgical procedure involving the placement of a medical device called a neurostimulator, which sends electrical impulses, through implanted electrodes, to specific targets in the brain (the brain nucleus) for the treatment of movement disorders, including Parkinson's disease, essential tremor, dystonia,[1] and other conditions such as obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and epilepsy. While its underlying principles and mechanisms are not fully understood, DBS directly changes brain activity in a controlled manner." [Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_brain_stimulation)

nodes.label: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)
nodes.desc:
Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a noninvasive form of brain stimulation in which a changing magnetic field is used to cause electric current at a specific area of the brain through electromagnetic induction. 

[Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transcranial_magnetic_stimulation)

nodes.label: Neurofeedback
nodes.desc: a form of biofeedback in which subjects respond to a display of their own brainwaves or other electrical activity of the nervous system.

nodes.label: Acting on Neurotransmitters
nodes.desc:
Most current drugs in Neurology and psychiatry act on neurotransmitters, and their receptors or reuptake mechanisms. 

A great overview of medication groups and respective neurotransmitter targets can be found [here](http://web.mit.edu/zakf/www/drugchart/drugchart11.html)

### Articles:

[Yang and Tsai, 2017 New Targets for Schizophrenia Treatment beyond the Dopamine Hypothesis](https://www.mdpi.com/1422-0067/18/8/1689)

[Ferreira-Vieira et al., 2016  Alzheimer's Disease: Targeting the Cholinergic System](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4787279/)

nodes.label: Non-invasive BCI's
nodes.desc: Noninvasive BCIs record information from sensors placed on or very close to the head. No surgery is required to implant recording devices, and noninvasive BCIs do not use any painful or hazardous methods.\" \n\n[Allison & Krusienski, Noninvasive Brain-Computer Interfaces, Encyclopedia of Computational Neuroscience, 2014](https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007%252F978-1-4614-7320-6_707-1.pdf)

nodes.label: Prosthetics
nodes.desc:
A neuroprosthetic is any device that can enhance the input or output of a neural system. Although some neuroprosthetics, such as cochlear implants and visual prosthetics, have been around since the 1950s, they are just beginning to emerge as viable interventions in the field of brain injury.
[Source: Neuroprosthetics]
(https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/neuroprosthetics#:~:text=A%20neuroprosthetic%20is%20any%20device,the%20field%20of%20brain%20injury.)

nodes.label: Clinical Trials
nodes.desc:
Clinical research is medical research involving people. There are two types, observational studies, and clinical trials.

Observational studies observe people in normal settings.

Clinical trials are research studies performed on people that are aimed at evaluating a medical, surgical, or behavioral intervention. 

All drugs and neurotech devices that are aimed to improve certain symptoms in patients need to undergo clinical trials. 

### Articles and official resources: 

[ClinicalTrials.gov](ClinicalTrials.gov)

[Phases of clinical trials](https://www.nia.nih.gov/health/what-are-clinical-trials-and-studies)

nodes.label: Platform Clinical Trials
nodes.desc:
"Platform trials are a type of randomized clinical trial that allow simultaneous comparison of multiple intervention groups against a single control group that serves as a common control based on a prespecified interim analysis plan. The platform trial design enables introduction of new interventions after the trial is initiated to evaluate multiple interventions in an ongoing manner using a single overarching protocol called a master (or core) protocol" 

### Articles and official resources:
[Source: How to Use and Interpret the Results of a Platform Trial
Users’ Guide to the Medical Literature](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/2787723#:~:text=Platform%20trials%20are%20a%20type,a%20prespecified%20interim%20analysis%20plan.)

nodes.label: Clinical Trial Endpoints
nodes.desc:
"Clinical endpoints or clinical outcomes are outcome measures referring to occurrence of disease, symptom, sign or laboratory abnormality constituting a target outcome in clinical research trials. " [1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinical_endpoint)

Identifying clinical trial endpoints is crucial for many psychiatric disorders and neurological diseases. Pharma companies are constantly looking for more sensitive biomarkers as clinical endpoints. 

### Articles and official resources:

[Kruizinga et al., The Future of Clinical Trial Design: The Transition from Hard Endpoints to Value-Based Endpoints, Handb Exp Pharmacol
. 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31707472/)

nodes.label: Safety, Regulatory
nodes.desc:
"Monitoring patient safety during clinical trials is a critical component throughout the drug development life-cycle. Pharmaceutical sponsors must work proactively and collaboratively with all stakeholders to ensure a systematic approach to safety monitoring. The regulatory landscape has evolved with increased requirements for risk management plans, risk evaluation and minimization strategies."
### Articles and official sources:
[Source: Safety Monitoring in Clinical Trials](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3834937/)

[EU: Reporting safety information on clinical trials](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/human-regulatory/research-development/clinical-trials/reporting-safety-information-clinical-trials)

[USA: Clinical Trials Guidance Documents](https://www.fda.gov/regulatory-information/search-fda-guidance-documents/clinical-trials-guidance-documents)

nodes.label: Cognitive and Behavioral Models
nodes.desc:
"Theory-driven approaches, in contrast, use models that instantiate prior knowledge of, or explicit hypotheses about disease mechanisms, possibly at multiple levels of analysis and abstraction. " 

[Adapted from Computational psychiatry as a bridge from neuroscience to clinical applications](https://www.nature.com/articles/nn.4238)

nodes.label: Mechanistic Understanding of Disease Mechanisms
nodes.desc: Mechanistic understanding of disease mechanisms will allow fin/tuning therapies and brain stimulation.

nodes.label: Acceptance by community
nodes.desc:
there are several challenges related to the acceptance of BCIs by the community:

Safety concerns: BCIs involve the implantation of devices in the brain, which raises concerns about the potential risks of surgery and the long-term effects of the implants. Additionally, there may be concerns about the potential for hackers to access the BCI, which could compromise the user's privacy and security.

Cost: The cost of developing and implementing BCIs can be high, which may limit their accessibility for many people, especially for low-income or underprivileged populations.

Limited effectiveness: While BCIs show a lot of promise as a technology, their effectiveness is still limited, and they may not work as well for all individuals or in all situations. This may lead to a lack of confidence in the technology among some users and potential users.

Stigma: There may be a perception that BCIs are only for people with severe disabilities or conditions, and that people who don't have those conditions should not use it.

Ethical concerns: BCIs raise a number of ethical concerns, including questions about personal autonomy, privacy, and the implications of people having access to other's thoughts and emotions. Additionally, there may be concerns about the implications of using BCIs to enhance human capabilities, which could lead to disparities in society.

Lack of regulation: BCIs

nodes.label: Predictive Models
nodes.desc:
Predictive models use a set of features to predict outcomes. Currently, lots of models are being tested in the lab. But few of those actually translate to clinical routine. 

The most important outcomes for brain disorders include diagnostic subgroups, symptoms prognosis, treatment response, and conversion into a more severe disorder. 

### Articles

[Fusar-Poli et al., The Science of Prognosis in Psychiatry: A Review, JAMA Psychiatry, 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30347013/)

[Gonzalo Salazar de Pablo et al., Implementing Precision Psychiatry: A Systematic Review of Individualized Prediction Models for Clinical Practice, Schizophr Bull. 2021](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7965077/)

[Tejavibulya st al., Predicting the future of neuroimaging predictive models in mental health, Mol Psychiatry
. 2022](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9708554/)

nodes.label: Patient Stratification
nodes.desc:
"Patient stratification is the division of a patient population into distinct subgroups based on the presence or absence of particular disease characteristics." [1](https://alzres.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13195-022-01055-y#:~:text=Patient%20stratification%20is%20the%20division,absence%20of%20particular%20disease%20characteristics.)

In psychiatric diseases Patient stratification is an essential step for making progress in treatment because a large number of patients 
do not respond to therapies.

Stratification into responders/non-responders, converters/non-converters, as well as specific risk groups and adverse drug reactions are current bottlenecks of the field. 


### Articles:

[Cearns et al., Using polygenic scores and clinical data for bipolar disorder patient stratification and lithium response prediction: machine learning approach, Br J Psychiatry, 2022](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35225756/)

nodes.label: Personalized Treatments
nodes.desc:
Personalized treatments, also known as precision medicine or personalized medicine, are medical treatments that are tailored to the specific needs of an individual patient. Personalized treatments are based on the idea that different people may respond differently to the same treatment due to differences in their genetics, environment, and other factors.

In the field of neuroscience, personalized treatments may involve the use of drugs or other therapies that are specifically tailored to the needs of an individual patient. For example, a personalized treatment for depression might involve the use of a specific antidepressant medication based on the patient's genetic profile or other factors.

There are several advantages to personalized treatments. For example, personalized treatments may be more effective than standard treatments because they are tailored to the specific needs of the patient. Personalized treatments may also have fewer side effects because they are specifically designed for the individual patient.

nodes.label: Dynamic Control of Treatment Efficacy
nodes.desc:
Dynamic control of treatment efficiency refers to the ability to adjust the dosage or other aspects of a treatment in real-time based on the patient's response. This approach is designed to optimize the effectiveness of the treatment and to minimize the risk of side effects.

Dynamic control of treatment efficiency is particularly important in the field of neuroscience, where conditions such as depression, anxiety, and epilepsy can be complex and may require frequent adjustments to treatment. For example, a patient with epilepsy may need to have their dosage of antiepileptic medication adjusted based on the frequency and severity of their seizures. Similarly, a patient with depression may need to have their dosage of antidepressant medication adjusted based on their response to treatment.

Dynamic control of treatment efficiency can be achieved through the use of monitoring technologies, such as wearable sensors, that can provide real-time data on the patient's response to treatment. This data can be used to make adjustments to the treatment in real-time, allowing the healthcare provider to optimize the effectiveness of the treatment while minimizing the risk of side effects.

Overall, dynamic control of treatment efficiency is an important approach that can help to optimize the effectiveness of treatments for neurological and psychiatric conditions.

nodes.label: Suicide Risk Prediction
nodes.desc:
Suicide risk prediction refers to the use of various tools and techniques to identify individuals who may be at risk of attempting suicide. Suicide risk prediction is important because it can help healthcare providers to identify and intervene with individuals who may be at risk of suicide, potentially saving lives.

There are several factors that may increase the risk of suicide, including a history of suicidal thoughts or behaviors, a family history of suicide, a history of substance abuse, a history of mental health conditions such as depression or anxiety, and social isolation. Healthcare providers may use various tools and techniques to assess an individual's risk of suicide, including standardized assessments, clinical interviews, and the use of predictive algorithms.

It is important to note that suicide risk prediction is not a perfect science, and there are limitations to the accuracy of risk prediction tools. However, identifying individuals who may be at risk of suicide and providing appropriate interventions can be an important step in preventing suicide and saving lives.

nodes.label: Personalized Disease Risk Prediction
nodes.desc:
Personalized disease risk prediction refers to the use of various tools and techniques to identify individuals who may be at risk of developing a specific disease. Personalized disease risk prediction is important because it can help healthcare providers to identify individuals who may be at risk of developing a specific disease and to provide appropriate interventions, potentially preventing the development of the disease or delaying its onset.

There are several factors that may increase an individual's risk of developing a specific disease, including genetic factors, environmental factors, and lifestyle factors. Personalized disease risk prediction may involve the use of various tools and techniques, including genetic testing, risk assessment tools, and the use of predictive algorithms.

Personalized disease risk prediction is an emerging field that has the potential to revolutionize healthcare. By identifying individuals who may be at risk of developing a specific disease and providing appropriate interventions, personalized disease risk prediction has the potential to improve the health and well-being of individuals and to reduce healthcare costs. However, it is important to note that personalized disease risk prediction is not a perfect science, and there are limitations to the accuracy of risk prediction tools.

nodes.label: Prevention of Diseases
nodes.desc:
Prevention of brain diseases is becoming an increasingly important focus in healthcare, as the prevalence of brain disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, and stroke is increasing globally, due to aging populations and other factors. Prevention is considered the future for several reasons:

Cost-effective: Preventing brain diseases is more cost-effective than treating them, as it is cheaper to prevent the onset of a disease than to treat it once it has developed.

Improve quality of life: Preventing brain diseases can help to improve the quality of life for individuals by maintaining cognitive function, and preserving independence and autonomy.

Personalized approach: By identifying and addressing risk factors for brain diseases early, prevention can be tailored to individual needs and lifestyles.

Development of technology: Advancements in technology and research have allowed for the development of new tools and techniques for identifying and monitoring brain diseases at an early stage, which is crucial for prevention.

Lifestyle modification: Simple and effective lifestyle changes, such as a healthy diet, regular physical activity, avoiding smoking, and managing stress, have been found to be beneficial in reducing the risk of brain diseases.

Multidisciplinary collaboration: preventing brain diseases requires a multidisciplinary approach, and collaboration between various fields such as neuroscience, geriatrics, epidemiology and psychology to develop effective strategies for prevention.

nodes.label: GOAL 2. Developing scalable biomarkers
nodes.desc: Biomarkers are measurable indicators of some biological state or condition. The goal of biomarker development for brain sciences is to achieve highly reliable, yet cheap, and scalable markers for the early diagnostics of diseases. Traditional biomarkers are measured in blood, cerebrospinal fluid. The large part of neuroimaging biomarkers is developed using MRI, EEG combined with neuropsychological experiments.

nodes.label: Cognition
nodes.desc:
Cognition is one of the core functions of human brain. This is a broad category uniting learning, memory, attention, executive functioning, language,perception and motor planning, visuo-construction, and social functioning. 

Cognitive decline is the main symptom of neurodegenerative diseases, therefore measuring cognitive functions plays a central role in the development of neurotech devices.

nodes.label: Omics Techniques
nodes.desc:
-omics is a broad term for various molecular biology techniques, which aim to study human genes (genomics), epigenetic changes that regulate gene expression (epigenetics), proteins (proteomics),  and other metabolites (lipidomics, metabolomics). 

In neurosciences, omics techniques are mainly serving biomarker development and drug target identification.

nodes.label: Molecular, cellular neuroscience
nodes.desc:
Molecular neuroscience is a branch of neuroscience that observes concepts in molecular biology applied to the nervous systems of animals. The scope of this subject covers topics such as molecular neuroanatomy, mechanisms of molecular signaling in the nervous system, the effects of genetics and epigenetics on neuronal development, and the molecular basis for neuroplasticity and neurodegenerative diseases.[1] As with molecular biology, molecular neuroscience is a relatively new field that is considerably dynamic. 

[Wiki]()

nodes.label: Digital Phenotyping
nodes.desc:
Digital phenotyping or digital biomarkers  is a “moment-by-moment quantification of the individual-level human phenotype in situ using data from personal digital devices." The data can be divided into two subgroups, called active data and passive data, where the former refers to data that requires active input from the users to be generated, whereas passive data, such as sensor data and phone usage patterns, are collected without requiring any active participation from the user. 

Source: [Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_phenotyping)

nodes.label: Sleep Patterns
nodes.desc: Sleep duration, stages, and quality are related to mood disorders, neurodegeneration, and psychoses. However, establishing a clear path between these markers and clinical symptoms remains to be established.

nodes.label: Heart Rate Variability
nodes.desc:
"Heart rate variability is where the amount of time between your heartbeats fluctuates slightly. Even though these fluctuations are undetectable except with specialized devices, they can still indicate current or future health problems, including heart conditions and mental health issues like anxiety and depression."

[Source: Cleveland clinic](https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/symptoms/21773-heart-rate-variability-hrv#:~:text=Heart%20rate%20variability%20is%20where,issues%20like%20anxiety%20and%20depression.)

nodes.label: Smell
nodes.desc:
Although smell seems to be unrelated to brain disorders a number of studies have shown that smell alterations can be an early biomarker of neurodegenerative disorders. 

[Smell, an Underrated Early Biomarker for Brain Aging](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnins.2020.00792/full)

nodes.label: Motion, Gate, Geopositioning
nodes.desc: MOtion and gate parameters have been widely assessed as biomarkers of movement disorders.  In addition, they seem to be very good biomarkers of the aging process in general.  Further movement and geopositioning have been used to identify relapse in depression, however, their replicability in this field remains unclear.

nodes.label: Speech analysis
nodes.desc:
Speech analysis using Natural language processing "...offer an opportunity to detect subclinical language changes, that may be present several years before the clinical phase of the disease and can be considered as one of the prodromal (or preclinical) manifestations of the disease."

[Source: Speech Analysis by Natural Language Processing Techniques: A Possible Tool for Very Early Detection of Cognitive Decline?](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnagi.2018.00369/full)

nodes.label: Genomics
nodes.desc:
Genomics is the study of all of a person's genes (the genome), including interactions of those genes with each other and with the person's environment.

[Source: A Brief Guide to Genomics](https://www.genome.gov/about-genomics/fact-sheets/A-Brief-Guide-to-Genomics)

nodes.label: Epigenomics
nodes.desc:
Epigenomics is the study of the complete set of epigenetic modifications on the genetic material of a cell, known as the epigenome. The field is analogous to genomics and proteomics, which are the study of the genome and proteome of a cell.[1][2] Epigenetic modifications are reversible modifications on a cell's DNA or histones that affect gene expression without altering the DNA sequence.

[Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epigenomics)

nodes.label: Proteomics
nodes.desc:
Proteomics is the large-scale study of proteomes. A proteome is a set of proteins produced in an organism, system, or biological context. 

[Source](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/training/online/courses/proteomics-an-introduction/what-is-proteomics/#:~:text=Proteomics%20is%20the%20large%2Dscale,for%20example%2C%20the%20liver).)

nodes.label: Metabolomics
nodes.desc:
Metabolomics is the large-scale study of small molecules, commonly known as metabolites, within cells, biofluids, tissues or organisms. Collectively, these small molecules and their interactions within a biological system are known as the metabolome.

[Source](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/training/online/courses/metabolomics-introduction/what-is/#:~:text=Metabolomics%20is%20the%20large%2Dscale,are%20known%20as%20the%20metabolome.)

nodes.label: Brain Banks, Postmortem Tissues
nodes.desc:
Brain banks collect postmortem brain samples which can be later delivered to research lab for conducting experiments. 

Some brain banks perform analyses themselves and publish data online, becoming online atlases.

nodes.label: Functional Connectivity
nodes.desc: Functional connectivity is measured using resting-state functional MRI. The patient stays in the scanner doing nothing with eyes closed. The resulting image is assessed with correlation matrices of the BOLD signal, which allows for measuring co-activation patterns.

nodes.label: Neuroimaging Biomarkers
nodes.desc: "Neuroimaging biomarkers use brain imaging techniques in order to image the morphology (e.g., MRI), the function (e.g. fMRI), the microenvironment (e.g., perfusion MRI), the metabolism (e.g., PET-FDG), or the molecular content (e.g., MR spectroscopy) of the brain and its lesions (Boland. 2014)." [Source: Imagylis](https://www.imagilys.com/neuroimaging-biomarkers-CNS-clinical-trials#:~:text=Neuroimaging%20Biomarkers-,Neuroimaging%20biomarkers%20use%20brain%20imaging%20techniques%20in%20order%20to%20image,brain%20and%20its%20lesions%20(Boland.)

nodes.label: Standardized Test Scores
nodes.desc: Test score standardization is required for the direct comparison of data between people of different origins. Development of such standardized tests requires well-labeled data and large datasets.

nodes.label: International Classifications
nodes.desc:
International classifications were developed to standardize the research and treatment protocols. 

Currently, the major classification used for research purposes for psychiatry is DSM-5 (diagnostic statistical manual). The major clinical classification for clinical work accepted worldwide is ICD-11 (international classification of diseases)

nodes.label: Cognitive, Psychiatric Areas
nodes.desc: Six cognitive domains (complex attention, executive function, learning and memory, language, perceptual-motor control, and social cognition) and a range of psychopathologic symptoms constitute the basis for diagnostic criteria.

nodes.label: Diagnostic Criteria
nodes.desc: Diagnostic criteria are developed by experts in specific domains. Over time diagnostic criteria may change: be extended to new categories or reduced if they are redundant.

nodes.label: Comorbidities
nodes.desc: Comorbidity is a simultaneous presence of two or more diseases or medical conditions. Comorbidities affect diagnostics and treatment. Therefore, accounting for comorbidities is essential for individual monitoring.

nodes.label: Individual Cognitive Monitoring
nodes.desc: Individual cognitive monitoring is required for controlling the progression of cognitive decline and the efficacy of interventions

nodes.label: Longitudinal Testing
nodes.desc: A challenge of longitudinal testing is the learning effect: when participants perform the test once, the second time they show improved performance. Tests controlling for this effect are required for clinical use.

nodes.label: Regulatory Challenges
nodes.desc:
[Ethical and Regulatory Challenges in Psychophysiology and Neuroscience-Based Technology for Determining Behavior](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/08989620903520271)

[Dilemmas in regulating brain-computer interface devices](https://www.medicaldevice-network.com/analysis/brain-computer-interface-devices-regulation/)

nodes.label: Specificity of Markers
nodes.desc:
A large part of the fluid biomarkers represents a general process rather than specificity for one or another disease. Eg. NSE or NFL for neuronal damage rather than specificity for one or another dementia. 

Specific markers are highly valuable and needed to improve diagnostics, treatment, and clinical trials.

nodes.label: Mobile Scanners
nodes.desc:
Mobile scanners are portable devices that can be used to non-invasively measure brain activity. These include devices such as mobile electroencephalography (EEG), functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) and magnetoencephalography (MEG) systems. These devices are important for the future of neuroscience because they allow researchers to conduct studies in real-world settings, and to collect data from individuals in their natural environments. This can provide a more realistic view of brain function and can reveal new insights into the neural mechanisms underlying behavior and cognition.

Additionally, mobile scanners could be used for clinical purposes, such as in remote monitoring of patients or assistive devices for patients with neurological conditions. As mobile technology continues to advance, mobile scanners are becoming smaller. If mobile scanners for other imaging technologies become available  this could democratise diagnostics and treatment

nodes.label: Novel Imaging Markers
nodes.desc:
Machine learning-based analysis of imaging data: This involves using machine learning algorithms to automatically analyze data from imaging studies and identify patterns that are associated with specific disorders. This approach is being used to analyze data from MRI, fMRI, and PET scans, among others, and has the potential to improve diagnostic accuracy and speed.

High-resolution MRI: Advances in MRI technology have made it possible to acquire images with higher spatial resolution, which allows for more detailed views of the brain structure. This can be used to detect subtle changes in brain structure that may be associated with disorders such as schizophrenia, depression, and dementia.

Network-based analysis: This is a computational approach that uses graph theory and complex network analysis to study the brain as a complex network of interconnected regions. This technique can be used to identify patterns of connectivity in the brain that are disrupted in certain disorders.

Advanced functional connectivity : Using sophisticated techniques like dynamic functional connectivity, temporal and spatial ICA, graph theory and more, to detect not only the strength but also the patterns of connections and interactions between different regions in the brain.

Quantitative susceptibility mapping (QSM): is a novel MRI-based technique that allow for the quantification of iron concentration within the brain. Iron concentration is modulated by many pathological conditions, therefore QSM could be a powerful biomarker for disease diagnosis, prognosis and therapy response monitoring.

These are some of the most recent and novel neuroimaging biomarkers that are currently being developed and validated. Keep in mind that these biomarkers are still in early stages and further research is needed to fully understand their diagnostic capabilities and to be translated into clinical practice.

nodes.label: Sleep quality assessment & staging
nodes.desc: Sleep quality analysis and sleep staging remain one of the biggest questions in sleep research. Once a portable and reliable device is developed, it will unlock the possibility of remote monitoring and at home treatments.

nodes.label: Mental Wellbeing Planning
nodes.desc:
Mental wellbeing planning is the concept of proactively taking steps to promote positive mental health and prevent the onset of mental health issues. While it is difficult to predict the future with certainty, it is likely that advances in technology and science will make it possible to improve mental wellbeing planning in the future.

One way that technology could play a role in mental wellbeing planning is through the development of more advanced screening tools. For example, advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning could lead to the development of more sophisticated mental health assessments that can detect early signs of mental health issues and help identify individuals who may be at risk.

Another way technology could improve mental wellbeing planning is through the use of mobile health applications that provide individuals with access to mental health resources and support. Mobile apps, for example, can be programmed to deliver tailored interventions, such as cognitive behavioral therapy and mindfulness practices, that can help individuals to manage stress and improve mood.

Additionally, with the increasing understanding of the underlying neural mechanisms of mental health disorders, it may be possible to develop new treatments and interventions that can target specific neural pathways and mechanisms, leading to more effective and personalized treatments.

It's important to note that while technology can play a role in mental wellbeing planning, it is not a panacea. It is crucial that mental wellbeing planning also includes social support, a healthy lifestyle, access to mental health care, and addressing systemic issues that contribute to mental health problems such as poverty, discrimination, and lack of social inclusion.

nodes.label: Early Diagnostics
nodes.desc:
Early diagnosis of brain disorders is seen as a crucial aspect of improving outcomes for individuals with these conditions. Early diagnosis allows for earlier intervention and treatment, which can slow the progression of the disorder and reduce the impact it has on an individual's life.

One potential future for early diagnosis of brain disorders is the use of biomarkers. Biomarkers are measurable indicators of a disease, such as a specific protein in the blood or a certain pattern of brain activity. Advances in technology, such as imaging techniques, and in our understanding of the underlying neural mechanisms of brain disorders, could lead to the development of new biomarkers that can be used to identify individuals at risk of developing a disorder.

Another potential future is the use of AI and machine learning techniques to analyze data collected from wearable devices and other sources to detect early signs of brain disorders. This could involve using data from sensors to detect patterns in an individual's behavior or physiological data that could indicate an increased risk of developing a disorder.

Additionally, another way to improve early diagnostics is to involve patients and caregivers in the process, through screening questionnaires, self-report assessments and other means, to detect signs and symptoms of brain disorders.

It's important to note that early diagnosis is just one step in the process of improving outcomes for individuals with brain disorders, and it should be followed by appropriate treatment and support. Additionally, it's important to ensure that the diagnostic process is valid, reliable and does not lead to unnecessary tests, treatments or stigmatization of individuals.

nodes.label: Functional Neuroimaging
nodes.desc:
Functional neuroimaging is the use of neuroimaging technology to measure an aspect of brain function, often with a view to understanding the relationship between activity in certain brain areas and specific mental functions.

Usually, an experiment is performed in the scanner. While the participant is performing a task, his brain activity is recorded using the functional MRI technique. The oxygenation of brain areas responsible for certain functions (so-called BOLD signal) increases and is measured during the task.

nodes.label: Neuropsychology
nodes.desc:
Neuropsychology is the discipline which investigates the relations between brain processes and mechanisms on one hand, and cognition and behavioral control on the other.

[Neuropsychology Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuropsychology#:~:text=Neuropsychology%20is%20a%20branch%20of,affect%20cognitive%20and%20behavioral%20functions.)

[Goals of Neuropsychology](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/neuropsychology)
[Neuropsychology as a Profession](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fpsyg.2020.559134/full)"

nodes.label: Pain Perception
nodes.desc: "Pain perception arises from a complex interaction between a nociceptive stimulus and different emotional and cognitive factors, which appear to be mediated by both automatic and controlled systems." [Source: Decreased Pain Perception by Unconscious Emotional Pictures](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fpsyg.2016.01636/full#:~:text=Pain%20perception%20arises%20from%20a,both%20automatic%20and%20controlled%20systems.)

nodes.label: Memory and Learning
nodes.desc:
"Learning and memory are closely related concepts. Learning is the acquisition of skill or knowledge, while memory is the expression of what you’ve acquired."


[Source: APA](https://www.apa.org/topics/learning-memory)

nodes.label: Music Performance
nodes.desc:
"Musical performances caused increases in oxygenated blood flow to areas of the brain related to understanding patterns, interpersonal intentions, and expression."

[Source: Scientific American](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/music-synchronizes-the-brains-of-performers-and-their-audience/)

nodes.label: Movement and Sport Performance
nodes.desc:
Starting with the neurophysiology of muscle development and movement and progressing through the use of imagery and cognitive training,  the variety of neurobiological processes involved in athletic performance. 

Adapted from [Neuroscience of Movement and Athletic Performance](https://psychandneuro.duke.edu/courses/neuroscience-movement-and-athletic-performance)

nodes.label: Neuromarketing
nodes.desc:
Neuromarketing is a commercial marketing communication field that applies neuropsychology to market research, studying consumers' sensorimotor, cognitive, and affective responses to marketing stimuli.[1][2][3] The potential benefits to marketers include more efficient and effective marketing campaigns and strategies, fewer product and campaign failures, and ultimately the manipulation of the real needs and wants of people to suit the needs and wants of marketing interests. 

[Source: Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuromarketing)

nodes.label: Digital Therapies
nodes.desc:
"Digital therapeutics is an evidence-based intervention using high-quality software, with the sole purpose of treatment."

[Source: Digital Therapeutics: Emerging New Therapy for Neurologic Deficits after Stroke](https://www.j-stroke.org/journal/view.php?doi=10.5853/jos.2019.01963)

nodes.label: Personalized Exercise
nodes.desc:
“The end goal is to be able to provide an exercise “prescription” that is optimal for each person, so they can gain the most benefit,” 

[Source: Personalized Exercise?
How Biology Influences Fitness](https://newsinhealth.nih.gov/2020/07/personalized-exercise)

nodes.label: Bilingualism
nodes.desc:
"Bilingualism (multilingualism) refers to the coexistence of more than one language system within an individual, as contrasted to monolingualism." 

[Source: Bilingualism](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/bilingualism)

nodes.label: FDA and EMA Approval
nodes.desc:
"Monitoring patient safety during clinical trials is a critical component throughout the drug development life-cycle. Pharmaceutical sponsors must work proactively and collaboratively with all stakeholders to ensure a systematic approach to safety monitoring. The regulatory landscape has evolved with increased requirements for risk management plans, risk evaluation and minimization strategies."

[Source: Safety Monitoring in Clinical Trials](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3834937/)

[EU: Reporting safety information on clinical trials](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/human-regulatory/research-development/clinical-trials/reporting-safety-information-clinical-trials)

[USA: Clinical Trials Guidance Documents](https://www.fda.gov/regulatory-information/search-fda-guidance-documents/clinical-trials-guidance-documents)

nodes.label: Brain Computer Interfaces and Direct Communication with Technology
Non-Invasive BCI's
nodes.desc:
" Noninvasive BCIs record information from sensors placed on or very close to the head. No surgery is required to implant recording devices, and noninvasive BCIs do not use any painful or hazardous methods." 

[Allison & Krusienski, Noninvasive Brain-Computer Interfaces, Encyclopedia of Computational Neuroscience, 2014](https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007%252F978-1-4614-7320-6_707-1.pdf)

nodes.label: Semi-Invasive BCI's
nodes.desc: Electrocorticography uses electrodes placed on the exposed surface of the brain to measure electrical activity from the cerebral cortex. It has been used for the first time in the 1950s at the Montreal Neurological Institute. It is called semi-invasive but it still requires a craniotomy to implant the electrodes. For this reason, it is used only when surgery is necessary for medical reasons (epilepsy for example).

nodes.label: Invasive
nodes.desc:
Brain stimulation is a common term for various techniques. The main goal of brain stimulation is to cause an activation of brain areas using invasive or non/invasive methods. 

At the moment, a number of brain stimulations have shown clinical effects and were approved for clinical use in depression, Parkinson's disease, and essential tremors. Clinical trials in other disorders (obsessive-compulsive disorder) are performed at various stages.

nodes.label: Software and Data Science
nodes.desc:
Neuroscience and neurotech methods rely heavily on software for signal amplification, feature extraction, filtering, cleaning, etc. 

Coding skills and data science are essential for cognitive neuroscientists.

nodes.label: Utah Array
nodes.desc:
"Microelectrode arrays (MEAs) (also referred to as multielectrode arrays) are devices that contain multiple (tens to thousands) microelectrodes through which neural signals are obtained or delivered, essentially serving as neural interfaces that connect neurons to electronic circuitry. There are two general classes of MEAs: implantable MEAs, used in vivo, and non-implantable MEAs, used in vitro.

Utah arrays are 3-D, consisting of 100 conductive silicon needles. However, in a Utah array, signals are only received from the tips of each electrode, which limits the amount of information that can be obtained at one time. Furthermore, Utah arrays are manufactured with set dimensions and parameters while the Michigan array allows for more design freedom. Flexible arrays, made with polyimide, parylene, or benzocyclobutene, provide an advantage over rigid microelectrode arrays because they provide a closer mechanical match, as the Young's modulus of silicon is much larger than that of brain tissue, contributing to shear-induced inflammation"

[Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microelectrode_array)

nodes.label: Endovascular
nodes.desc:
Endovascular brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) are a type of BCI that are inserted into the brain through a vein, rather than through direct surgical implantation. This approach allows for less invasive access to the brain and potentially less damage to the surrounding tissue.
Endovascular BCIs consist of a small catheter that is inserted into a vein in the neck or head, which is then guided through the blood vessels to the brain. At the end of the catheter is a small probe containing electrodes that can record neural activity. This activity is then transmitted to an external controller, similar to implanted microelectrodes BCIs, which processes the signals and sends commands to a computer or other device.

nodes.label: Implanted Microelectrodes
nodes.desc: Implantable microelectrodes for brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) are devices that are surgically placed into the brain in order to record neural activity and translate it into a form that can be used to control a computer or other external device. These microelectrodes are typically made of materials such as silicon or metal and are designed to be as small and flexible as possible in order to minimize damage to brain tissue. They are connected to a device outside the skull, called an "external controller" which receives the neural signals, processes them, and sends commands to the computer or other devices.

nodes.label: Stentrode
nodes.desc:
An optical fiber bundle is a collection of optical fibers that are held together in a compact and organized way. The fibers are usually arranged in a specific pattern and are often encased in a protective sheath to prevent damage. Optical fibers are thin strands of glass or plastic that are used to transmit light over long distances.

Optical fiber bundles can be used in brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) as a way to transmit neural signals from within the brain to an external device. In this application, the optical fibers in the bundle would be used to carry signals from a small probe or device implanted in the brain, which would contain sensors to record neural activity. This activity would then be converted into light signals and transmitted through the optical fibers in the bundle to an external device, where the signals would be processed and used to control a computer or other device.

Optical fiber bundles have several advantages for BCI applications, including high data transmission rates, low loss of signal and immunity to electromagnetic interference. Additionally, optical fibers are biocompatible which means that they can be safely used in the body.

Optical fiber bundle BCIs are still in the research stage, but they have shown promising results in animal studies. The main challenge for this technology is to develop miniaturized and reliable probes that can be inserted into the brain without causing damage.

nodes.label: Optical Fiber Bundle
nodes.desc:
An optical fiber bundle is a collection of optical fibers that are held together in a compact and organized way. The fibers are usually arranged in a specific pattern and are often encased in a protective sheath to prevent damage. Optical fibers are thin strands of glass or plastic that are used to transmit light over long distances.

Optical fiber bundles can be used in brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) as a way to transmit neural signals from within the brain to an external device. In this application, the optical fibers in the bundle would be used to carry signals from a small probe or device implanted in the brain, which would contain sensors to record neural activity. This activity would then be converted into light signals and transmitted through the optical fibers in the bundle to an external device, where the signals would be processed and used to control a computer or other device.

Optical fiber bundles have several advantages for BCI applications, including high data transmission rates, low loss of signal and immunity to electromagnetic interference. Additionally, optical fibers are biocompatible which means that they can be safely used in the body.

Optical fiber bundle BCIs are still in the research stage, but they have shown promising results in animal studies. The main challenge for this technology is to develop miniaturized and reliable probes that can be inserted into the brain without causing damage.

nodes.label: Cortical visual prosthesis
nodes.desc:
"Cortical visual prosthetics spurred a renewed interest these last years, thanks to wireless and technological
advances. As we saw it, compared to the retina, the optical nerve, or the LGN, the visual cortex presents a
large surface of stimulation and remain usually intact after visual impairments. In this study, we focused on
the electrical stimulation of the visual cortices and related aspects. We showed that despite several developments, there is still a knowledge gap concerning the safe parameters of electrical stimulation for multiphosphene induction. To fill this gap and reach a complete clinical efficiency of the electrode-based cortical
visual prosthesis seems key for the future."

Exempt from:  [Pio-Lopez at al., Visual cortical prosthesis: an electrical perspective, JOURNAL OF MEDICAL ENGINEERING & TECHNOLOGY 2021](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03091902.2021.1907468?journalCode=ijmt20)

nodes.label: Passive BCI's
nodes.desc:
"passive BCIs provide a promising channel for prediction of user's cognitive and affective state for development of a user-adaptive interaction..." 

[Source](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/frobt.2020.00125/full)

nodes.label: Non-pharma Treatments
nodes.desc: Over half century of psychopharmacotherapy has shown its inability to cure brain diseases.  Therefore, in the last 20 years non-pharmacological treatments became more and more of interest. The aim of these treatments is to circumvent the gap of knowledge of molecular mechanisms of brain diseases and treat the brain using brain stimulation, brain-computer interfaces, and various natural methods.

nodes.label: Neuroimaging
nodes.desc:
"Neuroimaging is a discipline that studies the structure and function of the nervous system by means of imaging technology, and where the images of the brain can be obtained in a non-invasive way. It explores a series of mechanisms such as cognition, information processing, and brain changes in the pathological state. In recent years, the neuroimaging has developed rapidly and become a powerful tool for medical research and diagnosis.“
[Zhang et al., Advances of Neuroimaging and Data Analysis, Front Neurol, 2020](https://doi.org/10.3389/fneur.2020.002570)

nodes.label: Emotion
nodes.desc:
In neuropsychology, two types of emotions are distinguished: basic emotions and complex emotions. 

Basic emotions include anger, surprise, disgust, enjoyment, fear, and sadness.

Complex emotion is an aggregate of two or more basic ones. Examples of complex emotions include shame, guilt, and pride. 

Knowing the brain region responsible for certain emotions allows us to measure it using brain signals and change it via brain stimulation.

nodes.label: Active BCI's
nodes.desc:
a user of an active BCI controls an application explicitly, via conscious control of his or her brain activity (Zander and Kothe, 2011)1. These BCIs have to compete with the manual input devices (keyboard, mouse, touchscreen) and emerging touchless alternatives (voice-, gesture- and gaze-based), as playing the same role in human-computer interaction (HCI) 

[Source] (https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnins.2022.859887/full_

nodes.label: Invasive BCI's
nodes.desc: Invasive BCIs rely on the implantation of electrodes beyond the surface of the brain and allow targeted localization of sensors in specific brain regions. Invasive BCI require surgical intervention to implant electrodes and systems, and are therefore more difficult to access than other BCIs. The technology also allows for Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS), where stimulation therapies have been developed for disorders such as essential tremors, Parkinson’s, and others, where surface electrodes do not provide targeted stimulation of brain regions.

nodes.label: Hardware
nodes.desc: Hardware development is the most significant for the development of electrodes for semi-invasive and invasive BCIs. In the field of brain prosthetics microelectrodes are the core technologies for brain prostheses.

nodes.label: Structural MRI
nodes.desc: Structural MRI uses T1 sequences in order to visualize gray and white matter. Based on this imaging one can measure cortical thickness and volume, density, gyrification, and area. The main goal is to assess atrophy or increased volume/density in case of learning

nodes.label: Digital monitoring & Digital therapies
nodes.desc:
Mobile apps and VR offer broad opportunities for scalability, remote monitoring of patients' states, and digital therapeutics. 

The biggest challenge for these solutions is surviving through the regulatory process, proving their claims in clinical trials, and integrating them into the reimbursement system.

nodes.label: Enhancement of Human Performance and Communication
Population-Specific Norms
nodes.desc: Different populations often produce different average test scores. Therefore appropriate normative information is required for the proper assessment of test performance.

nodes.label: MEG
nodes.desc:
Magnetoencephalography (MEG) is a non-invasive neuroimaging method. MEG has good temporal resolution. MEG is a magnetic imaging methods where the fluctuations in magnetic fields generated by electrical currents in the brain are measured.

Very sensitive magnetometer sensing elements are required given the electrical currents of the brain are very small. SQUIDs (superconducting quantum interference devices) are commonly used in MEG BCI design. As magnetic fields are common in the environment, MEG systems require proper shielding to avoid signal corruption. 

MEG systems essentially combine the temporal resolution of EEG with the spatial resolution of fMRI, making it a power imaging method to investigate the brain. Additionally, MEG is less susceptible to motion artefacts from test subjects than fMRI.

nodes.label: fMRI
nodes.desc:
Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) is a non-invasive neuroimaging method that measures the oxygenation of blood flowing in the brain. fMRI is based on the blood-oxygen-level dependent (BOLD) contrast method. Increased neural activity is related to the increased need for oxygenation, and therefore fMRI signals are essentially capturing relative neuronal activity throughout the brain. This results in a high spatial resolution image of the 3D brain and internal tissue structures.

When the brain is exposed to different stimuli, the resulting change based on fMRI can be captured, providing spatial information on how the brain changes between different states. fMRI can provide high spatial resolution of the brain, however, due to signal acquisition speed MEG has a lower temporal resolution than EEG and MEG.

nodes.label: fNIRS
nodes.desc:
Functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS) is a non-invasive neuroimaging method that functions similar to fMRI, however fNIRS utilizes changes in light absorption to characterize changes in blood oxygenation (hemoglobin species). Since near-infrared spectrum light source and imaging elements are used, the sensor elements can be packaged in a small size and placed in an array over the head and scalp.

fNIRS is very promising for combining mobility and neuroimaging accuracy for longitudinal and long-term monitoring applications and studies. Additionally, new BCI designs combine EEG and fNIRS in one system, allowing the advantages of both systems to be used seamlessly.

nodes.label: Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR)
nodes.desc:
Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) is an MRI sequence with an inversion recovery set to null fluids. For example, it can be used in brain imaging to suppress cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) effects on the image, so as to bring out the periventricular hyperintense lesions, such as multiple sclerosis (MS) plaques.
[Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluid-attenuated_inversion_recovery)

nodes.label: Brain Stimulations
nodes.desc:
Brain stimulation is a common term for various techniques. The main goal of brain stimulation is to cause an activation of brain areas using invasive or non/invasive methods. 

At the moment, a number of brain stimulations have shown clinical effects and were approved for clinical use in depression, Parkinson's disease, and essential tremors. Clinical trials in other disorders (obsessive-compulsive disorder) are performed at various stages.

nodes.label: Electro-convulsive therapy (ECT)
nodes.desc: "Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is a psychiatric treatment where a generalized seizure (without muscular convulsions) is electrically induced to manage refractory mental disorders." [Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electroconvulsive_therapy)

nodes.label: Light Therapy
nodes.desc:
Light therapy, also known as phototherapy, is the use of specific wavelengths of light to treat a variety of conditions. Some of the effects of light therapy include:

# Regulating circadian rhythm: 
Light therapy is commonly used to treat circadian rhythm disorders, such as seasonal affective disorder (SAD) and jet lag. By exposing individuals to bright light during the day, light therapy can help to reset the body's internal clock and regulate the sleep-wake cycle.

# Improving mood: 
Light therapy has been shown to be an effective treatment for certain mood disorders, such as major depressive disorder (MDD) and bipolar disorder. By increasing the levels of certain neurotransmitters in the brain, such as serotonin, light therapy can help to improve mood and reduce feelings of depression and anxiety.

nodes.label: Structural Connectivity
nodes.desc:
"Structural connectivity is defined as the existence of white
matter tracts physically interconnecting brain regions and
is typically measured in vivo in humans using diffusion
weighted imaging."

[Source: Complex relationships between structural and
functional brain connectivity](https://www.cell.com/trends/cognitive-sciences/pdf/S1364-6613(13)00215-5.pdf)

nodes.label: EEG, MEG, fNIRS
nodes.desc:
"An electroencephalogram (EEG) is a recording of brain activity.

During this painless test, small sensors are attached to the scalp to pick up the electrical signals produced by the brain." [Source: NHS](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/electroencephalogram/#:~:text=An%20electroencephalogram%20(EEG)%20is%20a,looked%20at%20by%20a%20doctor.)

" Magnetoencephalography (MEG) is a non-invasive medical test that measures the magnetic fields produced by your brain's electrical currents. It is performed to map brain function and to identify the exact location of the source of epileptic seizures."  [Source: Radiopaedia](https://www.radiologyinfo.org/en/info/meg#:~:text=Magnetoencephalography%20(MEG)%20is%20a%20non,the%20source%20of%20epileptic%20seizures.)

"Functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) is an optical brain monitoring technique which uses near-infrared spectroscopy for the purpose of functional neuroimaging.[1] Using fNIRS, brain activity is measured by using near-infrared light to estimate cortical hemodynamic activity which occur in response to neural activity. Alongside EEG, fNIRS is one of the most common non-invasive neuroimaging techniques which can be used in portable contexts." [Source: Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_near-infrared_spectroscopy)

nodes.label: Functional MRI
nodes.desc:
"Functional magnetic resonance imaging or functional MRI (fMRI) measures brain activity by detecting changes associated with blood flow.[1][2] This technique relies on the fact that cerebral blood flow and neuronal activation are coupled. When an area of the brain is in use, blood flow to that region also increases."

[Source: Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_magnetic_resonance_imaging)

fMRI is one of the tools that helped to non-invasively map brain functions. Thus, it allowed selecting of target regions for BCI electrodes.

nodes.label: Fluid Biomarkers
nodes.desc:
Some of the fluid biomarkers of brain diseases are already identified. Such as serum NSE, NFL, or S100b for traumatic brain injury or CSF Amyloid-beta and Tau/phospho-Tau for Alzheimer's disease. 

Nevertheless, the early biomarkers are still missing and their specificity remains an issue.

nodes.label: Cerebrospinal Fluid
nodes.desc:
## Articles

[CSF Biomarkers for Alzheimer's Disease Diagnosis](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2915796/)

[CSF biomarkers for dementia](https://pn.bmj.com/content/22/4/285)

nodes.label: Blood
nodes.desc:
## Articles

[Blood biomarkers for memory: toward early detection of risk for Alzheimer disease, pharmacogenomics, and repurposed drugs](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41380-019-0602-2)

nodes.label: Measurement Standardization
nodes.desc: All biomarker measures highly depend on the sample preparation protocol and essays used for the analysis. The standardization of the protocols is crucial for the comparability of the studies and for faster implementation in the clinic.

nodes.label: Harmonizing analytical pipelines
nodes.desc:
Often neuroimaging findings aren't reproducible and rarely analysis pipelines are identical. 

Thus there's a need to harmonize pipelines to improve reproducibility and clinical translation of findings.

nodes.label: Molecular Mechanisms of Disease
nodes.desc: For the large part of neurological and, especially, psychiatric disorders the knowledge of molecular mechanisms remains scarce. Although BCIs and brain stimulations circumvent the lack of molecular knowledge by using physical methods, understanding the complete picture of molecular processes leading to brain disfunction remains a central goal of the field.

nodes.label: Diagnostic Methods
nodes.desc:
In order to improve some of the brain functions one needs to know the baseline. Diagnostic methods in this context stand for a number of questionnaires, tests, and performance tasks specific to each category. 

These methods construct the core for digital phenotyping and interventions.

nodes.label: Perception
nodes.desc:
"The vast topic of perception can be subdivided into visual perception, auditory perception, olfactory perception, haptic (touch) perception, and gustatory (taste) perception." [PERCEPTION
Recognizing Patterns
and Objects](https://www.sagepub.com/sites/default/files/upm-binaries/53259_ch_3.pdf)

nodes.label: Personality
nodes.desc:
"Personality refers to individual differences in characteristic patterns of thinking, feeling and behaving. The study of personality focuses on two broad areas: One is understanding individual differences in particular personality characteristics, such as sociability or irritability. The other is understanding how the various parts of a person come together as a whole." 
[Source: APA](https://www.apa.org/topics/personality#:~:text=Personality%20refers%20to%20individual%20differences,such%20as%20sociability%20or%20irritability.)

nodes.label: Cognitive Psychology
nodes.desc: "Cognitive Psychology is the science of how we think. It’s concerned with our inner mental processes such as attention, perception, memory, action planning, and language. Each of these components are pivotal in forming who we are and how we behave." [Source: What is Cognitive Psychology?](https://imotions.com/blog/cognitive-psychology/)

nodes.label: Motivation and Reward
nodes.desc:
Motivation and reward systems in the brain are intrinsic to all the other processes. They are tightly related to dopamine synthesis in the ventral tegmental area, processing in the prefrontal cortex and amygdala. 
[Source:FOUNDATIONS OF NEUROSCIENCE, MSU](https://openbooks.lib.msu.edu/neuroscience/chapter/motivation-and-reward/)

nodes.label: Language
nodes.desc:
From the neuroscience perspective language is a complex neuropsychological concept, consisting of verbal fluency, phonemic and semantic components, as well as grammar and prosody. 

Language can both be a biomarker and a target for intervention.

nodes.label: Cognitive Behavioral Models
nodes.desc:
"Theory-driven approaches, in contrast, use models that instantiate prior knowledge of, or explicit hypotheses about disease mechanisms, possibly at multiple levels of analysis and abstraction. " 

[Adapted from Computational psychiatry as a bridge from neuroscience to clinical applications](https://www.nature.com/articles/nn.4238)

nodes.label: Invasive BCI's
nodes.desc: Invasive BCIs rely on the implantation of electrodes beyond the surface of the brain and allow targeted localization of sensors in specific brain regions. Invasive BCI require surgical intervention to implant electrodes and systems, and are therefore more difficult to access than other BCIs. The technology also allows for Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS), where stimulation therapies have been developed for disorders such as essential tremors, Parkinson’s, and others, where surface electrodes do not provide targeted stimulation of brain regions.

nodes.label: Replicability
nodes.desc:
"The replication crisis (also called the replicability crisis and the reproducibility crisis) is an ongoing methodological crisis in which it has been found that the results of many scientific studies are difficult or impossible to reproduce. Because the reproducibility of empirical results is an essential part of the scientific method,[2] such failures undermine the credibility of theories building on them and potentially call into question substantial parts of scientific knowledge."

[Source: Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replication_crisis)

nodes.label: EEG
nodes.desc:
Electroencephalography (EEG) is a non-invasive neuroimaging method to image brain activity by measuring electrical potential changes at the surface of the scalp. EEG is temporal with sampling frequencies from 125 - 2000 Hz often used.

Electrodes are place around the scalp, generally following the 10-20 standard EEG montage. Traditionally gold-cup electrodes with conductive gel are used, but dry electrode technology is currently advancing to make EEG setup easier.

EEG voltage signals are time-based, digitized by a biopotential amplifier. Signal processing and feature extraction are performed to characterized EEG signals.

nodes.label: Scalp Microelectrodes
nodes.desc:
To improve upon the limitations of wet conductive and dry electrodes for EEG measuring signals at the scalp surface, microelectrodes have been developed. By utilizing micro-sized needles, electrodes can penetrate the surface of the skin without discomfort, as the needle electrodes do not interact with nerve endings.

Microelectrods can provide improved signal quality for EEG without the complexity and surgical procedure associated with semi-invasive electrodes.

nodes.label: ECoG
nodes.desc:
Electrocorticography (ECoG), or intracranial electroencephalography (iEEG), is a type of electrophysiological monitoring that uses electrodes placed directly on the exposed surface of the brain to record electrical activity from the cerebral cortex. In contrast, conventional electroencephalography (EEG) electrodes monitor this activity from outside the skull. ECoG may be performed either in the operating room during surgery (intraoperative ECoG) or outside of surgery (extraoperative ECoG). Because a craniotomy (a surgical incision into the skull) is required to implant the electrode grid, ECoG is an invasive procedure. 

[Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrocorticography)

nodes.label: Pain Management
nodes.desc:
"Pain occurs as a result of nerves stimulated due to injury, repetitive or abrupt motion, or other conditions. When a negative or painful stimulus occurs on the skin, muscle/joint, or internal organ, a nociceptor fiber sends a signal to the receptors in the spine and brain. The dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC) is the area in the brain that is activated when an injury occurs and is responsible for processing pain. Thus, the neuroscience of pain includes a complex communication among several parts of the human body."

[Neuroscience and Pain Management](https://segurapaincenter.com/neuroscience-pain-center/neuroscience-and-pain-management/#:~:text=By%20studying%20the%20nervous%20system,abrupt%20motion%2C%20or%20other%20conditions.)

nodes.label: Ethics
nodes.desc: [Mind control and human rights](https://www.lawgazette.co.uk/practice-points/mind-control-and-human-rights/5113880.article)

nodes.label: Saliva
nodes.desc:
Salivary biomarkers belong to the easiest possible biomarker measurements. Therefore these biomarkers are of high interest from the translational point of view.  So far salivary biomarkers have been most promising for stress, anxiety, and depressive disorders. 

## Articles
[Salivary Biomarkers of Stress, Anxiety, and Depression](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7867141/#:~:text=PMID%3A%2033535653-,Salivary%20Biomarkers%20of%20Stress%2C%20Anxiety%20and%20Depression,-Sylwia%20Chojnowska%2C)

nodes.label: Writing to the brain/ Brain stimulation
nodes.desc:
Brain stimulation is a common term for various techniques. The main goal of brain stimulation is to cause an activation of brain areas using invasive or non/invasive methods. 

At the moment, a number of brain stimulations have shown clinical effects and were approved for clinical use in depression, Parkinson's disease, and essential tremors. Clinical trials in other disorders (obsessive-compulsive disorder) are performed at various stages.

nodes.label: Cranial Electrotherapy Stimulation
nodes.desc:
"Cranial electrotherapy stimulation (CES) represents a non-traditional, non-invasive brain stimulation technique, and involves the application of a small amount of current, usually less than 1 mA, through the head via ear clip electrodes. Its analgesic action has been demonstrated in various anti-nociception models. The mechanism of action of CES in humans is not fully understood, but it has been shown to “normalize” neurotransmitter homeostasis and increase beta-endorphins in patients with chronic back pain. CES has been found to be effective in controlling central pain, but a recent meta-analysis of four studies that enrolled patients with neuropathic pain failed to show statistically significant difference between active and sham stimulation."

Adapted from:   [Nardone et al., Invasive and non-invasive brain stimulation for treatment of neuropathic pain in patients with spinal cord injury: A review; J Spinal Cord Med. 2014 ](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4066547/)

nodes.label: Intraocular/ Epi- & Subretinal Implants
nodes.desc:
"Most groups, though, focus on the eye and employ an intraocular implant. Some designs for the implant are quite new, for example, employing an optoelectronic system that theoretically could give a stimulating pixel density of up to 2500 pix/mm2 (Palanker et al., 2005). Others have taken novel surgical approaches. In this regard, Tokuda et al. (2007) have implanted a multichip stimulator into a scleral pocket to achieve suprachoroidal transretinal stimulation. They were able to elicit electrically evoked potentials (EEPs) in the visual cortex using this device. The use of localized chemical release (e.g., neurotransmitters) from the implanted device has been proposed (Peterman et al., 2004) as well as a neural interface that utilizes vertically aligned multiwalled carbon nanotube pillars as microelectrodes (Wang et al., 2006). Many other approaches from groups in different countries are under investigation but a summary of these activities is outside the scope of the present article. Most groups of researchers, however, have taken a more direct approach with the implantation of more conventional electrodes directly on the retina using a subretinal or epiretinal approach. In the subretinal approach, the electronic implant is placed in the subretinal space between the pigment epithelial cells and the dead/dying photoreceptors. In the epiretinal approach, the implant is placed on the front surface of the retina, i.e., the ganglion cell layer. Applicability of such approaches has been reviewed in several publications including Zrenner (2002); Weiland et al. (2005), Winter et al. (2007) and the recent book by Humayun et al. (2007)."

[Source: Chader et al., 2009](https://pubmed-ncbi-nlm-nih-gov.browser.cbs.mpg.de/19660665/)

nodes.label: Functional Ultrasound
nodes.desc:
"Functional ultrasound takes advantage of neurovascular coupling:  using the detection of small blood volume changes as a surrogate for brain activity" Source: Deffieux et al., 2021 Functional Ultrasound Imaging: A New Imaging Modality for Neuroscience.

## FORESIGHT SEMINAR
[Sumner Norman | What To Expect From The Next Generation Of Brain-Computer Interfaces](https://foresight.org/summary/sumner-norman-what-to-expect-from-the-next-generation-of-brain-computer-interfaces/)

nodes.label: Eye tracking
nodes.desc: Eye-tracking is a technology that uses sensors to track the movement and position of a person's eyes. It can be used in research to study visual attention and perception, in human-computer interaction to control interfaces, or in medical applications to diagnose certain conditions such as strabismus or amblyopia. The technology typically involves a device, such as a camera, that is placed near or on the person's head to track the movement of the eyes in relation to the head and the visual scene. Data can then be analyzed to determine where the person is looking, how long they are looking at a particular area, and how their gaze changes over time.

nodes.label: Parameter estimation
nodes.desc:
Estimation of number inputs and noise 

Are the measurements enough to create a reliable model of neural code

nodes.label: Complexity of brain systems
nodes.desc:
The complexity of the brain and nervous system can be a challenge for drug discovery in several ways. Here are a few examples:
