#### 1. Identifying potential drug targets: 
The brain and nervous system are made up of billions of cells that interact in complex ways. This complexity can make it difficult to identify specific targets for drug intervention.

#### 2. Understanding the mechanisms underlying conditions: 
Many neurological and psychiatric conditions are not fully understood and the mechanisms underlying these conditions are often complex. This can make it difficult to develop effective treatments.

#### 3. Predicting side effects: 
The brain and nervous system are involved in many different functions and processes, and drugs that target specific neurotransmitter systems or pathways may have unintended effects on other functions and processes. This can make it difficult to predict the side effects of a drug and to ensure that it is safe for use.

#### 4. Developing animal models: 
In the early stages of drug development, researchers often use animal models to test potential drug candidates. However, it can be challenging to find animal models that accurately reflect the complexity of human neurological and psychiatric conditions.

Overall, the complexity of the brain and nervous system can make it challenging to develop effective treatments for neurological and psychiatric conditions. However, advances in our understanding of the brain and nervous system, as well as in drug development technologies, are helping to overcome these challenges.

nodes.label: Lack of animal models
nodes.desc:
The lack of animal models that accurately reflect human neurological and psychiatric conditions can be a challenge for drug discovery in several ways. Here are a few examples:

#### 1.Testing potential drug candidates: 
In the early stages of drug development, researchers often use animal models to test potential drug candidates. However, if the animal model does not accurately reflect the condition being treated in humans, it may be difficult to predict whether the drug will be effective in humans.

#### 2. Predicting side effects: 
Animal models can be used to predict potential side effects of a drug. However, if the animal model does not accurately reflect the condition being treated in humans, it may be difficult to predict the side effects that a drug will have in humans.

#### 3. Understanding the mechanisms underlying conditions: 
Studying animal models can help researchers to understand the mechanisms underlying neurological and psychiatric conditions. However, if the animal model does not accurately reflect the condition being treated in humans, it may be difficult to apply these findings to the human condition.

Overall, the lack of animal models that accurately reflect human neurological and psychiatric conditions can make it challenging to develop and test potential drug candidates for these conditions. However, advances in our understanding of the brain and nervous system, as well as in animal modeling technologies, are helping to overcome these challenges.

nodes.label: Challenges of gene therapy
nodes.desc:
Gene therapy is a promising approach to the treatment of genetic disorders and other conditions, but it also faces several challenges. Here are a few examples:

#### Delivery: 
One of the main challenges of gene therapy is delivering the therapeutic gene to the appropriate cells in the body. Researchers are working on various approaches to deliver genes, including using viruses to carry the gene into cells, using liposomes to deliver the gene, and using physical methods such as electroporation to introduce the gene into cells. However, these approaches can be inefficient and may have limitations.

#### Immune response: 
The immune system may recognize the viral vectors or other delivery vehicles used in gene therapy as foreign and mount an immune response against them. This can limit the effectiveness of gene therapy and may cause side effects.

#### Off-target effects: 
Gene therapy may have unintended effects on other genes or pathways in the body, known as off-target effects. These off-target effects may cause unwanted side effects or may interfere with the desired therapeutic effect.

#### Long-term effects: 
It is not always clear how gene therapy will affect an individual in the long term. Some gene therapies may have long-term effects that are not immediately apparent, and it is important to carefully monitor individuals who have received gene therapy to ensure the safety and effectiveness of the treatment.

Overall, gene therapy is a promising approach to the treatment of genetic disorders and other conditions, but it also faces several challenges. Researchers are working to overcome these challenges and to develop gene therapies that are safe and effective.

nodes.label: Targeting neuroinflammation
nodes.desc:
Targeting neuroinflammation as a therapeutic strategy involves using drugs or other therapies to reduce inflammation in the brain and nervous system. Neuroinflammation is the inflammation of the cells, tissues, and molecules of the brain and nervous system. It is thought to play a role in the development and progression of various neurological and psychiatric conditions, including Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis, and depression.

There are several ways in which neuroinflammation may be targeted as a therapeutic strategy. For example, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen may be used to reduce inflammation. Other approaches may involve the use of immune modulators, such as corticosteroids, or the use of specialized proteins called cytokines to regulate the immune response.

Targeting neuroinflammation as a therapeutic strategy is an emerging area of research that has the potential to improve the treatment of various neurological and psychiatric conditions. However, it is important to note that the relationship between neuroinflammation and these conditions is complex and is not fully understood. Further research is needed to determine the most effective approaches to targeting neuroinflammation as a therapeutic strategy.

nodes.label: New drug classes
nodes.desc:
There is a pressing need for new drugs in the field of neurology and psychiatry. Many existing medications for neurological and psychiatric disorders have significant side effects, which can make it difficult for patients to take them consistently. In addition, many patients with neurological and psychiatric disorders do not respond well to existing medications, and may require alternative treatment options.

Furthermore, our understanding of the underlying causes of neurological and psychiatric disorders is constantly evolving, and new targets for treatment may be identified as a result. Developing new drugs that specifically target these targets may lead to more effective treatments for these conditions.

In addition, as the population ages and the prevalence of neurological and psychiatric disorders increases, the demand for effective treatments will also rise. New drugs that are more effective and have fewer side effects will be essential in meeting this demand and improving the lives of patients suffering from these conditions.

nodes.label: Challenges of brain stimulation
nodes.desc:
Brain stimulation is a medical treatment that involves the use of electrical or magnetic fields to stimulate specific areas of the brain. It is used to treat a variety of neurological and psychiatric conditions, including depression, Parkinson's disease, and chronic pain. While brain stimulation can be an effective treatment for these conditions, it also has a number of challenges and limitations.

One challenge of brain stimulation is that it requires the use of specialized equipment, which can be expensive and may not be widely available. In addition, the effectiveness of brain stimulation can vary from person to person, and it may not work for everyone.

Another challenge is that brain stimulation can have side effects, including headache, dizziness, and muscle twitching. In some cases, brain stimulation may also cause more serious side effects, such as seizures or cognitive changes.

Finally, brain stimulation may not be appropriate for everyone. It may not be safe for people with certain medical conditions, such as bleeding disorders or heart problems. It may also not be an effective treatment for certain individuals.

Overall, while brain stimulation can be a useful treatment for certain neurological and psychiatric conditions, it is important to carefully consider the potential risks and benefits of this treatment before proceeding with it.

nodes.label: Challenges of Neurorobotics
nodes.desc:
These are the main challenges facing researchers in the field of neurorobotics. They include understanding the complex nature of the nervous system, being able to replicate it in robots and dealing with the complexity and uncertainty of the real-world environment. Additionally, integrating different levels of control, dealing with scalability and robustness, and working across multiple disciplines are also challenges. Finally, ethical concerns related to the impact of this technology on society and the definition of humanity and consciousness are major challenges that needs to be addressed.

#### Complexity of the nervous system

#### Real-world complexity

#### Scalability

#### Robustness

#### Integrating different levels of control

#### Interdisciplinary nature

####  Ethical concerns

nodes.label: Assisttive and Rehabilitation robots
nodes.desc: Assistive and rehabilitation robots of the future are expected to be highly adaptable and personalized to the needs of the individual, with the ability to learn and adjust to the user's abilities and goals. They will likely utilize advanced sensors and AI algorithms to detect and respond to changes in the user's behavior and environment, allowing them to provide more effective and efficient support. Additionally, these robots will likely be mobile and able to navigate the user's living environment, allowing the user to move around more independently. The robots will also be able to communicate with other devices, such as smartphones or smart home systems, to provide a more seamless and integrated experience for the user. Overall, the aim of these robots is to enhance the quality of life for people with disabilities or impairments, by providing them with more independence and access to their environment.

nodes.label: Focused Ultrasound Stimulation
nodes.desc:
Focused ultrasound is a rapidly evolving, noninvasive therapeutic technology using ultrasonic energy to target tissue deep in the body without incisions or radiation. 

With focused ultrasound, an acoustic lens is used to concentrate multiple intersecting beams of ultrasound on a target deep in the body with extreme precision and accuracy. 

Currently, clinical research is ongoing for the treatment of brain tumors, essential tremor, and Parkinson’s disease.

Source: Focused ultrasound Foundation, Learn about ongoing clinical trials [here](https://www.fusfoundation.org/diseases-and-conditions/category/neurological/)

Robotic Surgery
nodes.desc:
"Robotic surgery, also called robot-assisted surgery, allows doctors to perform many types of complex procedures with more precision, flexibility and control than is possible with conventional techniques. Robotic surgery is usually associated with minimally invasive surgery — procedures performed through tiny incisions. It is also sometimes used in certain traditional open surgical procedures." nodes.label: Cognitive adverse effects
nodes.desc:
As psychiatric side effects, temporary disorientation and postictal delirium may occur, and may be accompanied by anterograde or retrograde amnesia, but usually temporary and recovers over time.

Recently, it is evolving toward reducing cognitive side effects and maximizing therapeutic effects. During the ECT procedure, the location of the electrode and the physical properties of the stimulation influence the seizure threshold, which is related to the therapeutic effect and cognitive adverse effects. Generally, right unilateral ECT gets less severe cognitive impairment than bilateral ECT but needs a high dose (6 times seizure threshold) for the efficacy of treatment...

[Source](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7897863/)

Ensuring safety and ethical use
nodes.desc: Ensuring the safety and ethical use of neurorobotic systems: As with any technology, there are concerns about the safety and ethical use of neurorobotic systems. For example, if a robot is used in a healthcare setting, there must be safeguards in place to ensure that it does not harm patients.

nodes.label: Realistic and efficient movements
nodes.desc: Building robots with realistic and efficient movements: To be effective, neurorobotic systems need to be able to move and interact with the environment in a way that is similar to how humans or animals do. This requires developing advanced control systems and sensors that can accurately mimic human or animal movements.

nodes.label: Integration  with the nervous system
nodes.desc: Integration of robotics with the nervous system: One of the ultimate goals of neurorobotics is to create robots that can be controlled directly by the human nervous system, for example through brain-machine interfaces. This requires a deep understanding of how the nervous system works and how it can be connected to robotics.

nodes.label: Managing the complexity
nodes.desc: Managing the complexity of neurorobotic systems: Neurorobotic systems can be complex, involving a combination of hardware, software, and biological components. Managing this complexity can be a challenge, as it requires coordinating the development of all these different components and ensuring that they work together effectively.

nodes.label: Exercise
nodes.desc:
Exercise has a number of beneficial effects on the nervous system, including:

# Improving Mood and Cognitive Function: 
Regular physical activity has been shown to increase the production of chemicals in the brain that promote a sense of well-being and can improve cognitive function.

# Reducing Stress and Anxiety:
 Exercise can help to reduce the levels of stress hormones in the body, which in turn can help to decrease feelings of anxiety and improve mood.

# Improving Sleep Quality:
Regular physical activity can help to promote better sleep, which is important for overall nervous system health.

# Enhancing Neuroplasticity: 
 Exercise increases blood flow to the brain and releases growth factors that promote neuroplasticity, which is the brain's ability to adapt and change in response to new experiences or injury. This can help to protect the brain and improve the symptoms of certain neurological disorders.

# Delaying age-related neurodegeneration: 
Exercise has been known to help in slowing down the process of certain neurodegenerative disorders, specially in aging population.

For specific disorders like Parkinson's, regular physical activity has been shown to improve motor symptoms such as tremors, stiffness, and balance. In multiple sclerosis, exercise can help to improve muscle strength, endurance, and balance. In addition, it can have positive effect on fatigue and depression which are common in the disease.

It's important to note that while exercise is beneficial for the nervous system, it's also important to consult with a healthcare professional before starting an exercise program, especially if you have a specific neurological disorder or other medical conditions.

nodes.label: Brain Tissue Replacement
nodes.desc:
The idea here is to replace the brain one section at a time.  You can't do a complete brain transplant (or... some people might be open to that?) but you can try to [ship of theseus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ship_of_Theseus) your way to a new brain by replacing it in sections.

Labs:  
[Hebert Lab](https://www.einsteinmed.edu/faculty/9069/jean-hebert/)  
[Gaillard Lab](https://cbpr.georgetown.edu/william-d-gaillard/)

nodes.label: Body Enhancement
nodes.desc: The strategy of body enhancement is to simply bypass the current degradation and build all new organs.  You don't need to fix the heart if you can just build two new hearts and attach them to your body.  We may even be able to build organs that perform photosynthesis, generate sugar, and pump it directly into the bloodstream.  Custom organs and organ redundancy may yield even better results than attempting to repair things as they break.

nodes.label: Body Replacement
nodes.desc:
If we can replace the body, we can avoid death from aging by replacing aging components as they deteriorate.  Whether at the molecular, cellular, tissue, organ, or whole body scale, replacement strategies seem very straightforward.  If a part breaks or is degrading, replace it.

A combination of organ construction, cryogenic storage, and advanced surgery could allow us to functionally replace our entire bodies.

nodes.label: Reduce Rate of Damage Accumulation
nodes.desc: Diet seems to be at the root of accelerated aging.

nodes.label: Preserved Organs
nodes.desc:
Organ preservation is the supply line for organ transplantation. Currently, the liver, pancreas, and kidney can be successfully preserved for up to two days by flushing the organs with the University of Wisconsin (UW) organ preservation solution and storing them at hypothermia (0-5 degree C).

nodes.label: Preserved Body
nodes.desc:
Cryonics is the low-temperature freezing (usually at −196 °C or −320.8 °F or 77.1 K) and storage of human remains, with the speculative hope that resurrection may be possible in the future.  Cryonics is regarded with skepticism within the mainstream scientific community.

nodes.label: Preserved Cells
nodes.desc:
Cryopreservation is the use of very low temperatures to preserve structurally intact living cells and tissues. Unprotected freezing is normally lethal and this chapter seeks to analyze some of the mechanisms involved and to show how cooling can be used to produce stable conditions that preserve life.

nodes.label: Parabiosis
nodes.desc:
Parabiosis is the surgical union of two organisms, developing a single, shared physiological system. Through surgically connecting two animals, it can be proven that a secreted factor in one animal impacts the physiology of a second animal through their shared circulatory system.

[Parabiosis modeling: protocol, application and perspectives](

nodes.label: Hibernation
nodes.desc:
Hibernation is a state of minimal activity and metabolic depression undergone by some animal species. Hibernation is a seasonal heterothermy characterized by low body-temperature, slow breathing and heart-rate, and low metabolic rate. It most commonly occurs during winter months.

nodes.label: Germline Biology
nodes.desc:
The ovary is a highly organized composite of germ cells (oocytes or eggs) and somatic cells (granulosa cells, thecal cells, and stromal cells) whose interactions dictate formation of oocyte-containing follicles, development of both oocytes and somatic cells as follicles, ovulation, and formation of the corpus luteum (the endocrine structure that forms from the ovarian follicle after ovulation and is required for establishing and maintaining pregnancy)

nodes.label: The Microbiome
nodes.desc:
The microbiome is the collection of all microbes, such as bacteria, fungi, viruses, and their genes, that naturally live on our bodies and inside us. Although microbes are so small that they require a microscope to see them, they contribute in big ways to human health and wellness. They protect us against pathogens, help our immune system develop, and enable us to digest food to produce energy.

Advanced glycation end products (AGEs) are proteins or lipids that become glycated as a result of exposure to sugars. nodes.label: Autophagy
nodes.desc:
Autophagy is the body’s way of cleaning out damaged cells, in order to regenerate newer, healthier cells. 
 “Auto” means self and “phagy” means eat. So the literal meaning of autophagy is “self-eating.”

nodes.label: Cold Shock Response
nodes.desc:
Cold exposure elicits the release of norepinephrine into the brain and may activate the cold shock protein RBM3. Some studies suggest that cold exposure may improve mood and cognition, decrease depression, and protect against neurodegenerative disease.

nodes.desc:
The heat shock response (HSR) is a cell stress response that increases the number of molecular chaperones to combat the negative effects on proteins caused by stressors such as increased temperatures, oxidative stress, and heavy metals.

nodes.label: Proteostasis
nodes.desc:
Protein homeostasis or ‘proteostasis’ is the process that regulates proteins within the cell in order to maintain the health of both the cellular proteome and the organism itself.  Proteostasis involves a highly complex interconnection of pathways that influence the fate of a protein from synthesis to degradation.

nodes.label: Telomeres
nodes.desc:
A telomere is a region of repetitive DNA sequences at the end of a chromosome. Telomeres protect the ends of chromosomes from becoming frayed or tangled. Each time a cell divides, the telomeres become slightly shorter. Eventually, they become so short that the cell can no longer divide successfully, and the cell dies.

nodes.label: Senescence
nodes.desc:
Senescence or biological aging is the gradual deterioration of functional characteristics in living organisms. The word senescence can refer to either cellular senescence or to senescence of the whole organism. Organismal senescence involves an increase in death rates and/or a decrease in fecundity with increasing age, at least in the latter part of an organism's life cycle.

nodes.label: Circadian Rhythm

One example of a light-related circadian rhythm is sleeping at night and being awake during the day.

nodes.label: Extracellular Matrix
nodes.desc:
The extracellular matrix (ECM) is a complex network of biopolymers and structural proteins that supports and surrounds cells within tissues and organs. ECM plays a crucial role in tissue architecture, cell adhesion, migration, differentiation, and homeostasis (Hynes, 2009; Järveläinen et al., 2009; Schaefer and Schaefer, 2010). The ECM is composed of various macromolecules, including proteoglycans, glycosaminoglycans, elastin, and collagen, which are secreted by cells and assembled into a dynamic and hierarchical structure (Frantz et al., 2010; Hynes, 2009; Järveläinen et al., 2009; Schaefer and Schaefer, 2010). While ECMs distant from cells are more static, accumulate age-related damage, and are not remodeled, ECM attached to cells can be continuously remodeled and regulated by a range of enzymes, such as matrix metalloproteinases and their inhibitors, during development, tissue repair, and aging (Bonnans et al., 2014; Lu et al., 2011). During the aging process, the ECM undergoes various changes, including decreased synthesis, altered composition, and impaired crosslinking, which can lead to tissue dysfunction and diseases such as cancer, fibrosis, and atherosclerosis (Birch, 2018; Ewald, 2020; Statzer et al., 2022a). The ECM can also serve as a diagnostic tool and biomarker for various diseases, as it reflects the biochemical and mechanical changes in tissues and organs (Brunton-O’Sullivan et al., 2021; Komosinska-Vassev et al., 2022). For instance, the measurement of ECM components, such as collagen and elastin, can be used to diagnose and monitor fibrosis and cardiovascular diseases (Andriani et al., 2018; Brunton-O’Sullivan et al., 2021; Petersen et al., 2020). Modulating the composition and structure of the ECM can also be utilized as a therapeutic target to improve tissue function and repair (Harisi and Jeney, 2015; Huang et al., 2021; Walraven and Hinz, 2018).

nodes.label: Glymphatic System
nodes.desc:
The glymphatic system is a recently discovered macroscopic waste clearance system that utilizes a unique system of perivascular tunnels, formed by astroglial cells, to promote efficient elimination of soluble proteins and metabolites from the central nervous system. Besides waste elimination, the glymphatic system also facilitates brain-wide distribution of several compounds, including glucose, lipids, amino acids, growth factors, and neuromodulators. Intriguingly, the glymphatic system function mainly during sleep and is largely disengaged during wakefulness. The biological need for sleep across all species may therefore reflect that the brain must enter a state of activity that enables elimination of potentially neurotoxic waste products, including β-amyloid.

Labs:  
[Nedergaard Lab](https://www.urmc.rochester.edu/labs/nedergaard.aspx)

nodes.label: Bioprinting
nodes.desc:
Bioprinting is an additive manufacturing process similar to 3D printing – it uses a digital file as a blueprint to print an object layer by layer. But unlike 3D printing, bioprinters print with cells and biomaterials, creating organ-like structures that let living cells multiply.

[Volumetric](https://volumetricbio.com/)

nodes.label: Neuro Tree
