nodes.label: Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycan
nodes.desc:
Heparan sulfate proteoglycans (HSPGs) belong to the glycoproteins as a cell-surface ECM, which are adapted through the addition of glycosaminoglycan (GAG) chains. The location of the HSPGs in the plasma membrane works as a gatekeeper of ECM-cell signaling. And on the cell surface, HSPGs serve as a docking point to matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) (Yu and Woessner, 2000). This strategic location allows HSPGs to act as a cell directory through the ECM and promote invadopodia (Kelly et al., 1994).

HSPG core proteins–glypican and syndecan–have been observed in the developmental signaling mediation. Syndecans modulate axon pathfinding activity of the Slit-Robo pathway (Häcker et al., 2005). In  Drosophila melanogaster, glypicans regulate embryonic development via Wnt, Hh, and Dpp/TGFβ pathways (Nybakken and Perrimon, 2002). In C. elegans, mutations in HSPGs can affect normal lifespan and are required for longevity (Ewald et al., 2016; Teuscher et al., 2022).

nodes.label: Prevent RAGE Activation
nodes.desc:
Preventing RAGE activation is a subcategory of reducing inflammation.  AGE's can create inflammation several different ways, but directly antagonizing the RAGE receptors is one of them.  It's theorized that RAGE is not actually meant to detect AGE's, but instead it detects them by accident and induces inflammation.  This is important when trying to understand AGE biology.

[RAGE (Receptor for Advanced Glycation Endproducts), RAGE Ligands, and their role in Cancer and Inflammation](https://translational-medicine.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1479-5876-7-17)

nodes.label: Data on AGE accumulation over time
nodes.desc: There is no data on AGE accumulation over time in the human body.  Therefore, no therapy can be tested and statements about AGE toxicity cannot be validated.

nodes.label: Reduce AGE's in Body
nodes.desc: Reducing AGE's in the body should lead to a reduction in systemic inflammation.

nodes.label: Reducing AGE's
nodes.desc: Generally, for aging purposes, we want to remove AGE's because they build up in our bodies over time.  Higher AGE's means older - so how do we get rid of them?

nodes.label: Atherosclerosis
nodes.desc: Atherosclerosis is caused in part by macrophage apoptosis, which is stimulated by the accumulation of AGE's in the bloodstream.

nodes.label: Dietary AGE's
nodes.desc: Ingesting AGE's are the fastest way of introducing them to the body.

nodes.label: Discovery (1912)
nodes.desc:
Advanced glycation endproducts (AGE's) are a product of the Maillard reaction, which was first outlined in 1912

[Maillard Reaction](https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=umn.31951d00015504w&view=1up&seq=74)

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc:
How do we measure AGE's?

[Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs): Biochemistry, Signaling, Analytical Methods, and Epigenetic Effects](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7104326/)

There is currently no standardized AGE test, so results are hard to compare against each other.

nodes.label: Creating AGE's
nodes.desc: Sounds weird, but I bet some AGE's are beneficial.  Very specific AGE's might have good effects in the right context and we should know how to create them and possibly use them as therapeutics.

nodes.label: Which AGE's are good?
nodes.desc: The number of potential AGE permutations is incomprehensibly vast, there are probably good AGE's that perform useful functions in there somewhere.  It may turn out to be similar to ROS where some of the AGE's are extremely helpful.

nodes.label: Skin Autofluorescence
nodes.desc:
This one is interesting - it's a noninvasive, fast, cheap method of measuring skin glycation.  However, first we need to figure out all the confounding variables before using it as a standard to test efficacy of interventions.

[AGE Reader](https://www.diagnoptics.com/age-reader/)

nodes.label: Standardized AGE test
nodes.desc: There is no standard - and here's a question, should there even be a standard?  At the very least, we need some method of accurately determining AGE accumulation in the body that is fast and cheap.

nodes.label: Modifying AGE's
nodes.desc: So we can measure it.  How do we change them?

nodes.label: Reduce Dietary AGE intake
nodes.desc:
Dietary intake of AGE's contributes to inflammation and can be avoided via eating less fast food.

[Advanced Glycation End Products in Foods and a Practical Guide to Their Reduction in the Diet](https://www.jandonline.org/article/S0002-8223(10)00238-5/fulltext)

Although there's some contention that western diet contributes to inflammation, [life expectancy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy) doesn't seem to have an east or west bias.

nodes.label: Nanotech Tree
nodes.desc: https://foresight.org/ext/ForesightNanotechTree/

nodes.label: Collagen Receptors
nodes.desc: Collagen receptors–including integrins and discoidin domain receptors (DDRs)–are transmembrane proteins that bind to collagen, a major component of the ECM. Collagen receptors play important roles in cell adhesion, migration, and signaling, and are involved in the development and maintenance of tissues.

nodes.label: Collagen Remodelers
nodes.desc: Collagen remodelers are enzymes that break down and rebuild collagen in the body. These enzymes, known as collagenases and collagen remodeling enzymes, play a key role in maintaining the structural integrity of the ECM and in regulating the turnover of collagen. Dysregulation of collagen remodelers can lead to a variety of health issues, including skin aging, cancer, and fibrosis (Baaijens et al., 2010; Bonnans et al., 2014).

nodes.label: Senogenics
nodes.desc: Senogenics induce senescence

nodes.label: Modifying Senescence
nodes.desc: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28682291/

nodes.label: How to Stop Senescence in Vivo
nodes.desc: We don't know how to stop senescence in vivo

nodes.label: Oncogene Activation
nodes.desc: This is where p52 and other proteins are involved.

nodes.label: Proteoglycans
nodes.desc: Proteoglycans contribute to the construction of ECM by hydrating cells and tissues with their heavily glycosylated hydrophilic properties. And experiments using knockout mice implicate proteoglycans to be the stabilizer in the collagen-elastin network (Danielson et al., 1997; Maccarana et al., 2009). Therefore, it is not surprising to find that connective tissue diseases attributed to the disruption in proteoglycan formation are caused by genetic mutations that affect the synthesis, structure, or degradation of proteoglycans. These mutations result in an abnormal composition of ECM, leading to a range of symptoms, including skeletal and cardiovascular anomalies, joint hypermobility, and skin fragility manifested in diseases such as Marfan, Ehlers-Danlos, Hunter, Morquio, and Sanfilippo syndromes (Batzios et al., 2013; Benetó et al., 2020; Byers and Murray, 2014; de la Fuente-Alonso et al., 2021; Iozzo and Schaefer, 2015; Järveläinen et al., 2009; Walimbe and Panitch, 2020).

nodes.label: Collagen
nodes.desc:
It has been postulated that collagen is the most abundant protein in mammals, accounting for approximately one-third of their total protein content (Di Lullo et al., 2002). However, total collagen over total protein assessments in mice showed that collagens make up 12-17% of total protein (Tarnutzer et al., 2022). The collagen family comprises 29 distinct members, all of which possess a signature triple-helical domain structure (Owczarzy et al., 2020; Ricard-Blum, 2011; Shenoy et al., 2022) and has been extensively reviewed by Ricard-Blum and others (Owczarzy et al., 2020; Ricard-Blum, 2011; Shenoy et al., 2022). Quantitative ECM-enriched proteomics of entire mice revealed collagen type I as the most prevalent form of collagen (Tarnutzer et al., 2022).

Collagen, a fibrous protein that forms long, thin fibers, imparts tensile strength and elasticity to the ECM, enabling it to withstand mechanical forces such as those generated by the movement and contraction of surrounding cells and tissues. Collagen is also a major component of the ECM of connective tissues, such as skin, tendons, and ligaments, where collagen fibers are organized into complex, regular patterns that give these tissues their characteristic mechanical properties (Mouw et al., 2014; Rozario and DeSimone, 2010). In addition to its structural role, collagen also plays a key role in the signaling and regulation of ECM functions. Collagen can interact with various molecules, such as growth factors, enzymes, and other ECM components, to modulate their activity and regulate their effects on surrounding cells (Bonnans et al., 2014; Lu et al., 2011).

nodes.label: ECM Glycoproteins
nodes.desc: Glycoproteins are proteins with carbohydrate chains. They enable the ECM to regulate migration, differentiation, and proliferation by connecting structural molecules to cells and each other–forming a cohesive molecular network.

nodes.label: Discovery (1957)
nodes.desc:
[Endogenous Rhythms in Insects and Microorganisms](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2458417)

Wikipedia states that the discovery happened in 1935, but the earliest documentation I could find is from 1957.  This is when circadian rhythms were first defined in fruit flies.

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc: How is circadian rhythm measured?

nodes.label: Melatonin
nodes.desc: Dim Light Melatonin Onset

nodes.label: SIRT1 Agonist
nodes.desc: While SIRT1 is well studied and appears to have a lot of evidence for it's affect on circadian rhythm, there are no effective activators/deactivators of SIRT1.  Sirtris, a company that tried to make one, folded after being acquired by GSK for $750m and failing to produce a viable product.

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc: https://www.illumina.com/techniques/popular-applications/epigenetics.html

nodes.label: Lung Failure
nodes.desc: The lung ECM is comprised of complex networks of glycoproteins, proteoglycans, glycosaminoglycans, and fibrous proteins. Besides providing architectural support, the lung ECM conditions cell behavior through changes in the stiffness and composition of its proteins (Burgess et al., 2016; Gilpin et al., 2017; Herrera et al., 2022). The pathology of lung fibrosis is then associated with the loss of ECM homeostasis and the breakdown of its environment–creating a positive feedback loop to enforce fibrogenesis (Deng et al., 2020; Hackett and Osei, 2021). It is, therefore, self-evident that any impairment due to lung fibrosis requires interventions to recapture ECM homeostasis.

nodes.label: Heart Failure
nodes.desc:
Cardiac fibrosis is a cardiac muscle scarring event, defined by the production of myofibroblasts through activation and differentiation of cardiac fibroblasts and increased collagen tiI deposition (Disertori et al., 2017). These transitions in pathology usher increased matrix stiffness that leads to undesirable cardiac function (Hinderer and Schenke-Layland, 2019). 

The ECM network provides structural integrity, promotes force transmission, and relays crucial signal transduction to vascular and interstitial tissues and cardiomyocytes. Any changes in the cardiac ECM homeostasis are therefore critically felt and may cause reduced ejection fraction, heart arrest, and/or myocardial matrix stiffening, disturbance in electric conductance, and possibly death (Frangogiannis, 2019a; Hinderer and Schenke-Layland, 2019). 

Because the prognosis of cardiac fibrosis is often deleterious, exploiting matricellular proteins has been proposed as a possible therapy to modify the events of adverse remodeling. While studies on TSP-1 and SPARC showed promise in protection against these detrimental remodeling (Frangogiannis et al., 2005; Frangogiannis, 2019a; Schellings et al., 2008; Xia et al., 2011), formidable challenges lie ahead due to the overwhelming complexities of the matricellular proteins (Frangogiannis, 2019b). 

Cardiac regeneration through ECM manipulation has also been proposed as a moonshot therapy goal, and in vivo study of neonatal mice implicates ECM composition impact on myocardium regeneration activation (Frangogiannis, 2019b). The more attainable goal of engineering a bioartificial heart through stem cell-induced cardiomyocyte proliferation by using cardiac matrices as a scaffold is yet in its infancy (Ott et al., 2008; Taylor et al., 2018).

nodes.label: Liver Failure
nodes.desc:
Chronic damage to the liver and ECM protein accumulation results in liver fibrosis (Friedman, 2003). When the symptoms of liver fibrosis become acute, it can result in cirrhosis leading to portal hypertension and liver failure, which frequently necessitates a liver transplant (Bataller and Brenner, 2005). In industrialized nations, liver fibrosis is often caused by hepatitis C infection, alcohol, and fatty liver--also known as nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) (Bataller and Brenner, 2005).

ECM dysregulation is often attributed as the characteristic of fibrosis, with loss of homeostasis leading to impaired wound healing. ECM dysregulation causes alteration in the biomechanics and architecture of the lungs (Walraven and Hinz, 2018). Even though the liver is renowned for its regenerative abilities, persistent irritation can lead to fibrosis (Michalopoulos, 2007; Ortiz et al., 2021). When the injury is unabated, wound healing fails to function effectively, and fibrosis ensues. Fibrosis causes massive ECM deposition and scar formation, which leads to hepatic stellate cell failure (Marra, 1999).
 
Many therapeutic strategies have been emerging to inhibit fibrosis from developing. These include anti-inflammatory liver protection, hepatic stellate cell inhibitors, suppressor of ECM production, and or targeting ECM degradation. Gene therapy is also in the pipeline to target fibrosis (Tan et al., 2021).

nodes.label: Cancer
nodes.desc: Cancer is a group of diseases characterized by uncontrolled proliferation of abnormal cell growth. In 2020 alone, cancer affected approximately 18.1 million globally (WCRF International, 2022). The ECM plays a crucial role in the formation of the cancer microenvironment (Bissell and Hines, 2011). Increased ECM deposits and crosslinks have been linked to tumorigenesis and metastasis by providing the chemical and physical signals that are necessary for tumor development and invasion (Kim et al., 2011; Provenzano et al., 2008). Moreover, tumor cells have been found to influence the deposition of fibronectin, collagen, and tenascin C (Kii et al., 2010; Xiong and Xu, 2016), and a growing body of evidence suggests that ECM deposition promotes tumorigenesis and metastasis by helping cancer cells to proliferate and survive (Aoudjit and Vuori, 2012).

nodes.label: Loss of Identity
nodes.desc:
The loss of cellular identity is a phenomenon that occurs when cells lose their characteristic features and become more similar to each other (Yuan et al., 2019). This can happen during the development of cancer when cells undergo a process known as epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) (Scott et al., 2019). During EMT, cells lose their epithelial characteristics and acquire mesenchymal traits, such as increased motility and invasiveness. This allows them to break away from the primary tumor and migrate to other parts of the body, where they can form secondary tumors or metastases (Ribatti et al., 2020). The ECM plays a crucial role in the loss of cellular identity during EMT (Kim et al., 2017). In the context of cancer, the ECM can provide the physical and chemical cues that are necessary for EMT to occur (Walker et al., 2018). For example, certain ECM molecules, such as fibronectin, can promote EMT by activating signaling pathways that drive the loss of epithelial characteristics and the acquisition of mesenchymal traits (Lamouille et al., 2014). Additionally, the ECM can provide mechanical cues that can drive EMT by stretching and deforming the cells, which can activate signaling pathways that promote the loss of cellular identity (Miller et al., 2020). However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms by which tumor cells produce ECM and its role in remodeling the microenvironment in order to develop targeted cancer treatments (Venning et al., 2015).

As people age, the dermis also undergoes remodeling of the ECM and impaired cellularity (Badi, 2019; Tigges et al., 2014). However, it is unclear whether these changes are due to changes in fibroblasts. Salzer et al. studied whether different diets affected dermal fibroblasts in mice and their impact on lifespan. They found that as time passed, the definition of old fibroblasts became blurred, and even when present on the youthful dermis, fibroblasts were still indistinguishable. Old fibroblasts also showed decreased expression of genes involved in ECM formation (Salzer et al., 2018). Paradoxically, these old fibroblasts gained adipogenic traits similar to those in the neonatal state. When placed on a caloric restriction, these negative effects were either reversed or reduced. By contrast, a high-fat diet exacerbated the negative effects of aging. These results suggest that loss of cell identity may be one of the underlying mechanisms of aging (Fontana and Partridge, 2015; Salzer et al., 2018; Sedej, 2018).

Stiffened ECM can also drive the pathogenic expression of matricellular proteins by fibroblasts, leading to the conversion of muscle stem cells into fibrogenic cells. This process, known as a fibrogenic conversion, can contribute to sarcopenia, which is the age-related loss of muscle mass and strength. This occurs through the activation of the YAP/TAZ signaling pathway, which is triggered by the stiffened ECM. Overall, the ECM plays a key role in the loss of cellular identity during EMT, which is an essential step in the development of cancer and its metastasis, as well as in the development of sarcopenia (Stearns-Reider et al., 2017).

nodes.label: Stem Cell Exhaustion
nodes.desc:
Stem cell exhaustion is a major contributor to age-related decline in tissue regeneration (López-Otín et al., 2013b; Neves et al., 2017). In-vivo stem cell induction has been shown to restore the age-related decline in mice (Lavasani et al., 2012; Rando and Chang, 2012; Ren et al., 2017), highlighting the important role that tissue stem cells play in maintaining homeostasis and tissue regeneration (Cai et al., 2022; Neves et al., 2017; Ren et al., 2017).

The ECM is critical in regulating stem cell pluripotency, differentiation, tissue repair, and regeneration (Gattazzo et al., 2014; Ge et al., 2020). Tenascin-C, specifically, is expressed by bone marrow niche cells, which promote the regeneration of hematopoietic stem cells (Nakamura-Ishizu et al., 2012). However, chronic mechanical stress can cause the ECM to stiffen, impairs mechanotransduction, and leads to stem cell exhaustion through ECM remodeling (Gattazzo et al., 2014). In this process, enzymes like matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) can break down ECM molecules and cause the ECM to stiffen, impairing stem cells' ability to respond to mechanical signals and maintain their proper functions (Freitas-Rodríguez et al., 2017).

These findings suggest that stem cell rejuvenation could potentially be enhanced for novel therapies by manipulating the mechanisms of the ECM (Cai et al., 2022; Watt and Huck, 2013).

nodes.label: Cell Death
nodes.desc:
Cell death is a critical process in the development of the body and in maintaining homeostasis to prevent the onset of disease (Yang et al., 2022). This process can be classified into two categories: non-programmed cell death (Non-PCD), also known as necrosis, which is the result of the irreversible cell damage caused by extreme physical or chemical environments (Majno and Joris, 1995), and programmed cell death (PCD), which can be further subclassified into lytic and non-lytic cell death (Jorgensen et al., 2017).

Lytic cell death includes necroptosis and pyroptosis (Jorgensen and Miao, 2015), while non-lytic cell death, such as apoptosis, is essential for maintaining tissue organization and ensuring the appropriate number of cells (Makino et al., 2000). The ability of the extracellular matrix (ECM) to remodel is crucial for regulating cell behavior (Lu et al., 2011), and apoptosis has been found to be involved in several diseases, including those affecting the kidneys (Savill, 1994; Thompson, 1995). Unlike necrosis, apoptosis does not elicit an inflammatory response, and phagocytes are responsible for removing the resulting apoptotic bodies (Fuchs and Steller, 2011; Yang et al., 2022). A study of rat kidneys found that glomerular cell apoptosis was associated with glomerular cell loss and accumulation of ECM, leading to glomerulosclerosis (Sugiyama et al., 1996). Additionally, it was found that mesangial cells were protected from apoptosis by the basement membrane matrix, which induced their survival. However, when the expression of β1 integrin was suppressed using antisense oligonucleotides, apoptosis of mesangial cells was increased (Makino et al., 2000). These findings suggest that the regulation of mesangial cells is dependent on the ECM surrounding them via integrins.

Given the close relationship between mesangial cell proliferation and apoptosis, there is potential for developing novel therapeutic strategies for renal diseases that involve manipulating apoptosis (Makino et al., 2000).

nodes.label: Loss of Mitochondrial Homeostasis
nodes.desc:
Mitochondria are multifunctional organelles that play essential roles in various cellular processes, including apoptosis, cell metabolism, proliferation, modulation of intracellular calcium homeostasis, and ATP production (Gause, 1969; Romani et al., 2022; Yanes and Rainero, 2022). Because of the diverse functions of mitochondria, any dysfunction in these organelles can have a significant impact on human health. 

There is a bidirectional relationship between the ECM and mitochondria. Cell-ECM interactions can directly or indirectly modulate mitochondria through the actin cytoskeleton (Fletcher and Mullins, 2010). This interaction is particularly relevant in the context of metastasis, where mitochondria serve as the primary energy source for cell migration (Yanes and Rainero, 2022). In turn, mitochondrial depolarization and oxidative phosphorylation can influence the ECM through cell-ECM adhesion and MMP-dependent ECM degradation (van Waveren et al., 2006). Mitochondrial homeostasis and adaptation (mitohormesis) are interlinked with ECM-integrin cytoskeleton remodeling in human stem cells and C. elegans important for lifespan extension (Ding et al., 2008; Munkácsy et al., 2016; Schinzel et al., 2019; Tharp et al., 2021)

nodes.label: Loss of Mechanotransduction
nodes.desc:
Mechanotransduction is a crucial process of translating physical forces into biochemical signals. . When this process fails, it can have significant negative consequences for cellular adaptation and homeostasis (Ewald, 2020). Impaired mechanotransduction can lead to a range of problems, including disrupted tissue development and function, tissue degeneration, and in some cases, the development of diseases such as fibrosis or cancer (Humphrey et al., 2014). Understanding the role of mechanotransduction in the ECM and how it can be disrupted is an important area of research with potential implications for the treatment of a variety of conditions.

Damages to ECM can be read out by changes in forces sensed by integrins as cell-surface ECM receptors. Integrins transduce these physical forces either through cytoskeleton remodeling linked to the nucleus or changing kinase cascades signaling into the nucleus to reprogram gene expression (Humphrey et al., 2014).  A moderate reduction of integrin-linked kinase (ILK) caused favorable function in increasing lifespan in C. elegans and D. melanogaster (Goddeeris et al., 2003; Kumsta et al., 2014). In particular, C. elegans showed an increased lifespan while preserving cytoskeletal integrity (Goddeeris et al., 2003). Further investigation through RNAi screening found pat-4/ILK and pat-6/Parvin depletion to be responsible for its increase (Goddeeris et al., 2003; Vitiello et al., 2021). In Drosophila, mortality, and behavioral aging delay were observed in the loss-of-function myospheroid gene mutations that encode for β1-integrin–the binding partner of the ILK (Hansen et al., 2005). Coronin-7 (Coro7), necessary for proper cytoskeletal functions, has been associated with prolonged lifespan in mice (Statzer and Ewald, 2020; Vitiello et al., 2021). Also, cytoskeleton remodeling has been known to be closely correlated to ECM remodeling. And ECM remodeling has a critical role in mechanotransduction and improved health span (Ewald, 2020; Ewald et al., 2015; Rapisarda et al., 2017).

nodes.label: Fibrosis
nodes.desc:
According to estimates, fibrotic disorders are responsible for approximately 45% of deaths in the United States (Wynn, 2004). Fibrosis refers to the stiffening of tissue that ultimately leads to organ failure. While universally occurring throughout the body with age, fibrosis is seen in accelerated forms both in fibrotic diseases and after injury. 

Many fibrotic disorders are caused by the loss of ECM homeostasis, which creates an imbalance in wound healing and causes irreversible structural damage to biophysical properties (Ortiz et al., 2021; Walraven and Hinz, 2018). As more than a third of the developed nations suffer from mortality due to fibrotic disorders (Rockey DC et al., 2015), understanding the mechanisms behind ECM maintenance is vital in extending the health span globally.

There are currently no reliable biomarkers for diagnosing fibrotic diseases, and the current non-invasive method for discovering these diseases is unreliable and often leads to a diagnosis too late when the damage is already irreparable (Gaudet and Popovich, 2014). To improve the prognosis for individuals with fibrotic diseases, it will be necessary to restore organ function and reverse fibrotic scarring (Gaudet and Popovich, 2014; Muñoz-Espín and Serrano, 2014).

nodes.label: Core Matrisome
nodes.desc: The matrisome is the compendium of all extracellular proteins that make up the ECM. Changes in matrisome composition play a critical role in maintaining the structural integrity and functional properties of tissues and organs (Ewald, 2020; Hynes and Naba, 2012; Naba et al., 2014, 2012). The matrisome can be divided into the core matrisome, which forms the actual ECM, includes proteins such as collagens, laminins, and proteoglycans, and the associated matrisome, which includes proteins such as ECM remodelers or proteins that associate with the matrix (Ewald, 2020; Hynes and Naba, 2012; Sacher et al., 2021). ECM receptors, such as integrins, play a crucial role in cell-ECM interactions and are involved in cell adhesion, migration, and signaling (Hynes, 2002; Schwartz, 2010). ECM remodelers, such as matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs), are enzymes that modify the ECM by degrading or synthesizing ECM components (Bourboulia and Stetler-Stevenson, 2010; Brew and Nagase, 2010; Visse and Nagase, 2003). These proteins are important for ECM remodeling during tissue development, repair, and remodeling processes. Given these ECM functions, not surprisingly, there is evidence that changes in the expression and activity of ECM proteins and ECM remodelers may contribute to age-related changes in tissue structure and function (Ewald, 2020; Lofaro et al., 2021; Statzer et al., 2021; Teuscher et al., 2022).

nodes.label: Kidney Failure
nodes.desc:
Kidney fibrosis is the last stage of chronic kidney disease manifestation.  It is identified by superfluous pathological aggregation and deposition of the ECM (Bülow and Boor, 2019), and is estimated that approximately 12% of the global population is affected by this disease with higher incidences of mortality (Hill et al., 2016; Neovius et al., 2014).

Kidney ECM comprises glycoprotein, proteoglycan, elastin, and collagen network and forges basal and interstitial matrices (Abdollahzadeh et al., 2022). Calcification of ECM in soft tissues, as in blood vessels, is one of the observable traits in chronic kidney disease patients (Toussaint, 2011).

Currently, kidney fibrosis is diagnosed by invasive biopsies. However, employing the highly regulatory nature of ECM homeostasis, it can be utilized to measure the ECM remodeling rate, which could then be used to indicate disease progression (Karsdal et al., 2013; Lu et al., 2011). Specifically, developing novel protein fingerprints to identify ECM neo-epitopes produced via proteases or other post-translational modifications can perhaps be used as a non-invasive biomarker (Genovese et al., 2014).

nodes.label: Produce Young ECM
nodes.desc: The Yamanaka factors, also referred to as OSKM (Oct4, Sox2, Klf4, and c-Myc), have the potential to significantly impact our understanding of aging and the possibilities of regenerative medicine. These transcription factors have been shown to reprogram adult cells into a pluripotent state, similar to that of embryonic stem cells (Takahashi and Yamanaka, 2006). Recent studies have demonstrated the ability of partial chemical reprogramming to improve key drivers of aging, such as genomic instability and epigenetic alterations (Macip et al., 2023; Ocampo et al., 2016; Schoenfeldt et al., 2022; Yang et al., 2023). Additionally, a study by Yang et al. has shown that aging can be driven in both directions by manipulating the epigenome using three of the four Yamanaka factors (Yang et al., 2023). While the mechanisms by which the Yamanaka factors induce the production of ECM proteins are not yet fully understood, it is believed that they may modulate the expression of genes involved in ECM production, such as collagens, fibronectin, and laminin (Meškytė et al., 2020; Murgai et al., 2017; Song et al., 2018, 2018; Wang et al., 2007). If this reprogramming process can be verified in a living organism, it will be a major breakthrough in the field of regenerative medicine and could redefine the concept of aging.

nodes.label: Small Molecules for ECM Homeostasis
nodes.desc:
Small molecules have been found to be a potential solution for treating diseases and aging by controlling the activity of proteases and the formation of bonds within the ECM. Proteases, such as MMPs, play a crucial role in ECM remodeling and are connected to various illnesses, including cancer and chronic inflammation (Manicone and McGuire, 2008). The regulation of protease activity and bond formation within the ECM through small molecules can be achieved by either stimulating or suppressing protease activity or promoting ECM bond formation (Skrzydlewska et al., 2005). This approach has the potential to target a wide range of diseases and aging-related conditions, including angiogenesis, tissue regeneration, and epidermal aging.

There is growing evidence that MMPs have a significant influence on angiogenesis beyond ECM remodeling. MMPs have been found to release ECM-bound angiogenic factors, detach pericytes from blood vessels, and degrade endothelial cell-cell adhesions (Rundhaug, 2005; Tang et al., 2005). For example, a study on mice infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) showed that treatment with Marimastat increased the number of blood vessels covered by pericytes while the total blood vessel number remained unchanged. Inhibiting MMP activity resulted in an increase in pericyte-covered blood vessel numbers and seemed to stabilize the integrity of the infected lung tissue. Additionally, increased delivery and/or retention of Marimastat was observed in treated mice, leading to improved drug efficacy (Xu et al., 2018).

Natural compounds, such as flavonoids and polyphenols, have also been found to control ECM homeostasis and longevity through different mechanisms (Statzer et al., 2022b). These compounds include melatonin, tea polyphenols, grape seed polyphenols, honokiol (Magnolia sp.), quercetin, sulforaphane, apocynin, aloe vera, turmeric (curcumin), silymarin (milk thistle), ginseng (Panax ginseng), algae, propolis, and others (Dunaway et al., 2018). Notably, Ramachandran et al. observed that both honokiol and modified citrus pectin induced dose-dependent antioxidant activity in a synergistic manner, inhibiting NF-kB and TNF-α (Ramachandran et al., 2017). Together, these mechanisms work to maintain the structural integrity of the ECM, promoting tissue regeneration and preventing epidermal aging (Dunaway et al., 2018).

nodes.label: COPD
nodes.desc:
World Health Organization has ranked Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) 3rd in the cause of mortality and morbidity, claiming 3.23 million deaths worldwide in 2019 (World Health Organization, 2022). 

COPD is caused by narrowed airways, limiting airflow in and out of the lungs. These obstructions are caused by several processes, such as inflammations, swellings, mucus buildups, and impairment of the airway lining (Rabe et al., 2007). Constant inflammation caused by smoking and air pollution is thought to be a major contributor to COPD pathogenesis (Finkelstein et al., 1995; World Health Organization, 2022).

The ECM plays a critical role in the architecture of the airway structure. In COPD patients, however, major deviations of the ECM components are observed in all of its lung recesses (Annoni et al., 2012). It is postulated that these deviations cannot be overcome in COPD patients and contributes to the lack of airflow into the lungs–further causing a deleterious impact on the patient's health (Annoni et al., 2012). Past findings of COPD have been characterized by the reduction of elastin and proteoglycan but an increase in collagen in the alveoli (Cardoso et al., 1993; Chrzanowski et al., 1980; van Straaten et al., 1999). However, we currently lack an understanding of the precise mechanism behind how ECM influences COPD. It is hoped that the transplanting of mesenchymal stromal/stem cells (MSC) may play a role by inducing the regeneration and reassembly of damaged lungs. Developing artificial scaffolds, instructed with cues to uphold the microenvironment, and finetuning biomechanics for optimal MSC curative properties may be the future direction of COPD treatment (Elowsson Rendin et al., 2021).

nodes.label: IPF
nodes.desc:
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common type of fibrosing interstitial pneumonia. IPF in elderly have a  prognosis of only 3 to 5 years of survival (King et al., 2014; Strongman et al., 2018). 

Key synthesizing agents of ECM are thought to be myofibroblasts in fibroblastic foci and activated fibroblasts (Kis et al., 2011). And while the exact pathology is unknown, IPF can be diagnosed based on disparate and cumulative subpleural fibrosis, and fibrotic foci with an assembly of myofibroblasts resisting apoptosis (Jones et al., 2016; Kis et al., 2011). The study of active ECM synthesis and remodeling showed an increase in hyaluronan, type I procollagen, tenascin-C, and versican expressions and decreased biglycan and decorin expression within fibroblastic foci (Estany et al., 2014). Estany et al. found that tenascin-C and versican–a chondroitin sulfate proteoglycan--are highly expressed in the lungs with defects in wound healing ability, leading ultimately to fibrosis (Estany et al., 2014). 

Since the advent of SARS-CoV-2, it has become imperative to understand better the mechanisms behind the maintenance or reverse engineering to induce ECM protein homeostasis (Uhler and Shivashankar, 2021).

nodes.label: Williams-Beuren Syndrome
nodes.desc:
Williams-Beuren syndrome (WBS), also known as Williams’ syndrome, is characterized by a multisystem developmental disorder that affects approximately 1 in 7,500 to 18,000 people (Pober, 2010). Often, WBS patients have skeletal, renal, and cardiovascular malformation, cognitive impairments, and distinctive facial features and personalities (Eronen, 2002; Marín-García, 2014; Wessel et al., 1994). 

WBS is caused by the loss of the Williams-Beuren syndrome critical region (WBSCR) in chromosome 7. In particular, a major component of ECM, Elastin (ELN) hemizygosity is attributed to arteriopathy in WBS patients (Ewart et al., 1993). Reduced elastin in those with WBS would therefore have their ability of elastic properties necessary for the normal function of arteries impaired (Collins, 2013; Grant et al., 2017; Kozel et al., 2014).

nodes.label: Arterial Stiffening
nodes.desc:
Arterial stiffness is attributed to the increased probability of major cardiovascular events by engendering pulse pressure increase and isolated systolic hypertension (Lacolley et al., 2020). 

Loss of ECM protein homeostasis is at the root of arterial stiffening (Wagenseil and Mecham, 2009). Collagen and elastin support the architecture of arterial biomechanics. These proteins constitute the majority of arterial wall structural makeup, and deterioration in either or both of these proteins can create havoc in arterial health (Briones et al., 2010; Kelleher et al., 2004). Therefore, any alteration in quantity or quality is a determinant factor in diseases often associated with aging, namely: diabetes, chronic renal failure, and hypertension (Briones et al., 2010; Lacolley et al., 2017).

Cardiovascular and renal drugs currently available in the market have yet to capture the elusive mechanisms underlying the structural components of the disease. Further investigations and therapeutic interventions targeting the structural maintenance of the ECM will therefore result in a reduction in the aforementioned diseases and increase the quality of life of the aging population (Lacolley et al., 2017).

nodes.label: Osteoporosis
nodes.desc:
Constitutional or compositional changes occur in the bone with the progression of age. Osteoporosis–an ailment of the bone–impacts largely the elderly female population, leaving the bone porous and thereby elevating the risk of bone fracture.

Osteoclasts and osteoblasts concert tightly with the bone ECM in regulating and regenerating bone formation. In the bone ECM, collagen constitutes the majority of its makeup. And with the progression of time, collagen undergoes a decline in quality due to AGEs and causes abnormalities in bone remodeling (Shiraki et al., 2008). While higher levels of AGEs were observed in patients who have had fractures, correlation does not necessitate causation (Dyer et al., 1991). 

New findings suggest that noncollagenous proteins (NCPs) may consort with collagen in the structural and mechanical properties of the bone matrix. It is thought that through crystal nucleation and orientation, NCPs contribute to bone health by functioning as a scaffold to collagen fibrils and thereby increasing bone strength (Qiu et al., 2004).

nodes.label: Osteoarthritis
nodes.desc:
Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most prevalent degenerative joint disease, with an estimated prevalence of over 50% in individuals over the age of 65 (Dillon et al., 2006; Rahmati et al., 2017). OA is characterized by abnormal bone remodeling and degeneration of the articular cartilage, leading to pain and physical and financial impairments in the elderly population (Blagojevic et al., 2010; Goldring, 2012; Neogi and Zhang, 2013; Sandell and Aigner, 2001).

While aging is considered a major risk factor for the development of OA, the exact mechanisms of its pathogenesis remain poorly understood (Lotz and Loeser, 2012). Aging has been shown to disrupt the homeostasis of the ECM, resulting in loss of integrity and deterioration of its architecture. These changes are thought to contribute to the development of OA, with its associated increased inflammatory expression, loss of tissue regenerative capacity, and cellular senescence. Chondrocytes, which are quiescent cells responsible for cartilage formation, are believed to play a central role in the initiation and progression of OA (Rahmati et al., 2017). During the progression of the disease, chondrocytes have been observed to promote ECM malformation, forming clusters (Lotz et al., 2010). As aging progresses, chondrocytes also affect proteoglycan synthesis and disrupt their composition (Buckwalter et al., 1993), leading to biomechanical modifications of the ECM and further disrupting its homeostasis.

There is also evidence suggesting sex differences in the pathogenesis of OA. Women have a higher prevalence of OA than men, particularly after menopause (Buckwalter and Martin, 2006; Srikanth et al., 2005). Hormonal changes that occur during menopause, such as reduced levels of estrogen, may play a role in the increased susceptibility of women to OA (Roman-Blas et al., 2009; Stachenfeld, 2014). Additionally, women may have differences in their ECM composition and structure compared to men, which may contribute to their increased susceptibility to OA (Peshkova et al., 2022). For example, studies have shown that women have lower levels of collagen and proteoglycans in their articular cartilage compared to men (Hernandez et al., 2021). These differences in ECM composition and structure may make women more susceptible to the development of OA and its associated ECM changes (Li and Zheng, 2021). Further research is needed to fully understand the underlying mechanisms behind these sex differences in the pathogenesis of OA.

nodes.label: Cognitive Impairment
nodes.desc:
Blood vessels become stiffer with advancing age due to elastin loss and accumulation of crosslinks in the ECM of a vessel wall. Pulse Wave Velocity (PWV) - a measure of arterial stiffness - is significantly associated with cognitive status (Hanon et al., 2005). PWV appears significantly higher in subjects with vascular dementia or Alzheimer's disease than in those without cognitive impairment. Moreover, PWV was higher in subjects with mild cognitive impairment than in those without cognitive impairment. The causality of this relationship was confirmed in a mice study where vascular stiffness was induced by the topical application of calcium chloride on the adventitial region of the carotid artery (Sadekova et al., 2013) which resulted in an increase in the production of cerebral superoxide anion and neurodegeneration.

Integrating all findings, Iulita et al. draw the hypothesis that increased arterial stiffness and the subsequent excessive pulsatility, through mechanisms involving oxidative stress and inflammation, affect the brain microcirculation and lead to blood-brain-barrier disruption. With compromised cerebral perfusion, the delivery of nutrients and the clearance of toxic products is disrupted, leading to neurodegeneration and cognitive dysfunction (Iulita et al., 2018).

In addition, Baidoe-Ansah et al. examined the expression levels of genes related to the neural ECM in the brains of young, aged, and very-aged mice and found that ECM gene expression was downregulated with age, despite the accumulation of ECM proteoglycans. The most significantly downregulated gene was carbohydrate sulfotransferase 3 (Chst3), which is responsible for modifying proteoglycans. Baidoe-Ansah et al. also found that changes in ECM-related gene expression were associated with a decline in cognitive performance. At the individual level, they found a negative correlation between Chst3 expression and cognitive performance in very aged mice. A trade-off between positive gene effects on certain cognitive tasks and negative effects on others was also observed. Despite an increase in CHST3 protein expression in glial cells, there was no change in the absolute level of chondroitin 6-sulfation (C6S) modification and a decrease in C6S in certain areas of the ECM (Baidoe-Ansah et al., 2022).

nodes.label: Skin Aging
nodes.desc:
As we age, our skin loses its elasticity and firmness due to a decline in the activity of fibroblasts, the cells responsible for producing collagen and other components of the ECM. This loss of ECM leads to systemic inflammaging, which is characterized by increased levels of inflammatory cytokines such as Il-1 and TNF-α. Studies have shown that even using hydrating lotions can help to mitigate this effect by reducing the levels of these inflammatory cytokines in elderly individuals (Ye et al., 2019).

A key driver of skin aging is the reduced activity of fibroblasts and their loss of adherence to the ECM. In younger skin, fibroblasts are anchored to the ECM, but this becomes increasingly disorganized with age (Fisher et al., 2009). This can lead to a decline in collagen production and a loss of skin firmness and elasticity. To address this, dermatologists often prescribe medications such as all-trans retinoic acid (tretinoin), which has been shown to increase collagen production by up to 80% in the dermis, resulting in a rejuvenated appearance of the skin (Griffiths et al., 1993). Treating C. elegans with tretinoin promotes collagen homeostasis that, is normally lost during aging, and is sufficient to increase lifespan (Statzer et al., 2021). Additionally, other products have been shown to stimulate the production of ECM proteins in skin tissue. For example, glucosamine has been shown to improve hyaluronic acid protection (Gueniche and Castiel-Higounenc, 2017), and heparan sulfate can be used to enhance glycosaminoglycan levels in the skin (Gallo et al., 2015). Both glucosamine and hyaluronic acid supplementation are sufficient to promote collagen homeostasis and longevity in C. elegans (Statzer et al., 2021; Weimer et al., 2014). 

Another factor that contributes to skin aging is the increased activity of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), which degrade collagen. This is a result of fragmentation that occurs with the fibrils and dysregulated MMP activity which exacerbates the dysfunction of fibroblasts (Xia et al., 2013). UV damage accelerates skin aging in part due to increased MMP activity from the damage response, the abnormal MMP activity also occurs with intrinsic aging.

Rapamycin, an FDA-approved drug targeting the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) complex (Li et al., 2014), has been demonstrated to have anti-aging properties on the human epidermis in a clinical trial (Chung et al., 2019). The trial recruited participants older than 40 years of age who exhibited age-related photodamage and dermal atrophy. The results of the study revealed a statistically significant decrease in the levels of the p16INK4A protein, which is indicative of cellular senescence, and an increase in type VII collagen, a crucial component for the basement membrane's structural integrity. Additionally, the study observed an improvement in the clinical appearance of the skin, as well as an improvement in the histological appearance of the skin tissue. These findings suggest that rapamycin may be a promising anti-aging therapy that has been validated for efficacy in human subjects (Chung et al., 2019).

The future of treatments against skin aging may hinge on the development of effective and stable messenger RNA (mRNA) delivery systems. A recent study by You and colleagues found that extracellular vesicles (EVs) produced from human dermal fibroblasts and encapsulating mRNA encoding for ECM α1 type-I collagen (COL1A1) induced the formation of collagen-protein grafts and reduced wrinkle formation in the skin of mice with photoaged skin. Additionally, the study found that intradermal delivery of the mRNA-loaded EVs via a microneedle array led to the prolonged and more uniform synthesis and replacement of collagen in the animals' skin. These findings suggest that intradermal delivery of EV-based COL1A1 mRNA may be an effective protein-replacement therapy for the treatment of photoaged skin (You et al., 2023).

nodes.label: Age Related Changes
nodes.desc: The ECM appears to be affected by a large number of insults that degrade or stiffen it.  However, only one of these causes seems to be ‘native’ to the ECM category itself, all the others are a product of systemic issues upstream.

nodes.label: Control ECM Turnover
nodes.desc: The ECM is a dynamic and essential component of the human body, responsible for providing structural support and regulating cellular behavior. However, the turnover of the ECM that is not attached to cells is a relatively slow process, and the accumulation of modified crosslinks with age can result in a decline in the overall quality and quantity of the ECM. To mitigate this decline and preserve the youthful integrity of the ECM, strategies aimed at increasing the rate of ECM turnover and reducing the formation of age-related modifications may prove beneficial. These strategies may include the modulation of specific enzymes involved in ECM turnover, as well as the implementation of lifestyle factors known to promote overall cellular health and vitality. Ultimately, the successful implementation of such strategies may hold significant implications for the maintenance of tissue integrity and the prevention of age-related pathologies.

nodes.label: Glycation Crosslinking Breakers
nodes.desc:
Advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) are a group of compounds that contribute to the loss of tissue integrity due to crosslinking with age. The most abundant crosslinks in this group are glucosepane and pentosidine (Monnier et al., 1999; Sjöberg and Bulterijs, 2009). While it has yet to be clinically proven, it is hypothesized that the accumulation of these crosslinks may be a causal factor in the development of various age-related pathologies. It is believed that their selective breakdown could potentially improve a wide range of ECM-related aging pathologies, including skin atrophy, arterial stiffening, and systemic fibrosis. However, other AGEs may matter more if it turns out that disturbed cell-ECM interactions (e.g., an AGE binding to a RAGE-receptor) are a major driving force behind clinical pathologies within current lifespans (Sainio and Järveläinen, 2020).
Despite the potential importance of glucosepane and pentosidine as AGE crosslinks, it remains to be fully elucidated whether they are major causes of aging. This is because no experiments have been conducted in humans to demonstrate the selective removal of these crosslinks. Glucosepane is by far the most abundant crosslink observed in aged human tissue and is over 100 times more abundant than any other crosslink; subsequently, it is of interest to biotech companies. The formation of glucosepane is a well-known chemical reaction, the Amadori reaction, where the amino acid lysine reacts with D-Glucose forming an Amadori product that degrades and gets bound to arginine, forming the final product (Ansari and Dash, 2013; Biemel et al., 2002; Monnier et al., 1999).
Several biotech companies have been founded on the assumption that crosslinks can be broken down, and that such an approach would also restore elasticity as well as the functionality of tissue. One such technology is a glucosepane-breaking enzyme for multiple age-related indications. Conditions, where an effect from removing glucosepane could be anticipated to be observed, would include elasticity of blood vessels, and subsequently, hypertension, pulmonary fibrosis, and the gradual decrease in the respiratory capacity that occurs with age. It would also be important for skin and cartilage aging, as well as presbyopia, which is secondary to the stiffening of the eye lens that occurs almost universally with age (Rungratanawanich et al., 2021).
Specific challenges for clinical translation into humans include finding an enzyme or small molecule that can break down these crosslinks without damaging other vital molecules in the ECM. An enzymatic approach has been pursued so far since enzymes are better at catalyzing the breakdown of substances. However, extracellular enzymes must also be able to penetrate well into the ECM and have a sufficient energy source (such as enough ATP to perform their actions) to effectively break down glucosepane and pentosidine. The need for further research in this area is evident as the selective removal of AGEs such as glucosepane and pentosidine could potentially lead to the development of novel therapeutic interventions for age-related pathologies.

nodes.label: AMD
nodes.desc:
It is striking that in genome-wide association studies, many ECM and matrisome genes, such as VEGFA, TIMP3, MMP9, COL4A3, COL8A1, VTN, HTRA1) are associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD) (Fritsche et al., 2016). These polymorphisms might alter ECM integrity in the eye. For instance, polymorphisms found in the promoter region of HTRA1, a secreted serine protease, lead to its overexpression. Transgenic mice overexpressing HTRA1 from retinal pigment epithelial cells resulted in the degradation of fibronectin, fibulin 5, and tropoelastin, thereby fragmenting the ECM (Bruch’s basement membrane) (Vierkotten et al., 2011). Neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD) is a type of age-related macular degeneration and a major cause of blindness caused by the growth of new blood vessels in the choroid, which can eventually turn into a fibrous plaque or scar (Lim et al., 2012). The subretinal fibrosis in nAMD shares similar molecular processes as fibrosis found in other organs such as the lung, liver, kidney, heart, and skin (Friedlander, 2007).

Although there are no fibroblasts in the retina tissue, the initiation of neovascularization can result in the recruitment of additional inflammatory cells, the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition of retinal pigment epithelial cells or macrophage to myofibroblasts transdifferentiate, which serve as a direct or indirect source of myofibroblasts (Little et al., 2018). These cells produce ECM, proliferate, and migrate over the basal layers to repair and regenerate damaged tissue. However, in cases of repeated injury or chronic inflammation, fibrotic scarring persists (Ishikawa et al., 2016).

Sinclair and his team demonstrated that expressing the Oct4, Sox2, and Klf4 genes (Yamanaka factors) in mouse eye retinal ganglion cells restored youthful epigenetic marks and gene expression, promoting axon regeneration after injury and reversing vision loss in glaucoma and aged mice in vivo (Lu et al., 2020). As a corollary, Yamanaka factors may also play a significant role in inducing and influencing ECM regeneration in macular degeneration. Adding weight to the claim are findings such as Oct4 modulating the expression of collagens, which are major components of the ECM (Song et al., 2018). Similarly, Klf4 has been shown to regulate the expression of MMPs, which are enzymes involved in ECM degradation and remodeling (Murgai et al., 2017).

nodes.label: Control Downstream Signaling
nodes.desc:
YAP1 (Yes-associated protein 1) is a transcriptional co-activator that plays a key role in the regulation of cell proliferation, differentiation, and survival, as well as responding to age-related stiffening of the ECM (Elosegui-Artola et al., 2017; Harvey et al., 2013; Pan, 2010; Zanconato et al., 2016; Zhao et al., 2011). In humans, the stiffening of the ECM with age can lead to dysregulation of YAP1 and cellular senescence (He et al., 2019; Xie et al., 2013). This can cause hindrance in the conversion of mechanical stimuli into cellular responses and altering stem cell differentiation (Pelissier et al., 2014). However, YAP1 activation has also been shown to promote tissue regeneration, but its hyperactivation has been observed in human cancers (Calvo et al., 2013), indicating a need for careful regulation in regenerative medicine (Moya and Halder, 2019).

The decline in YAP/TAZ activity during physiological aging in stromal cells has been linked to accelerated aging, whereas preserving YAP function has been seen to rejuvenate old cells and suppress senescence-associated inflammation (Sladitschek-Martens et al., 2022). The GMP–AMP synthase (cGAS)–stimulator of interferon genes (STING) pathway, a crucial component of innate immunity, is regulated by YAP/TAZ (transcriptional co-activator with PDZ-binding motif) through the preservation of nuclear envelope integrity and regulation of lamin B1 and Actin-related protein 2. Maintaining YAP/TAZ mechanosignaling or inhibiting STING could be potential strategies for promoting healthy aging, as the control of cGAS-STING signaling by YAP/TAZ drives aging (Sladitschek-Martens et al., 2022). In C. elegans, the yap-1 gene is essential for longevity and maintains collagen homeostasis (Teuscher et al., 2022).

nodes.label: Lipofuscin blocks autophagy
nodes.desc:
[Lipofuscin accumulation and autophagy in glaucomatous human lamina cribrosa cells](https://doi.org/10.1186/1471-2415-14-153)

"Lipofuscin, the formation of which is driven by reactive oxygen species (ROS), is an intralysosomal, non-degradable, auto-fluorescent macromolecule which accumulates with age and can affect autophagy - the lysosomal degradation of a cell’s constituents"

nodes.label: Autophagy Initiation
nodes.desc:
It's pretty well known how to induce autophagy, even though we can't directly measure it in vivo.

[An Overview of the Molecular Mechanism of Autophagy](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2832191/)

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc:
[Monitoring and Measuring Autophagy](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5618514/pdf/ijms-18-01865.pdf)

How do we see autophagy happening?

nodes.label: Measure Autophagy in Vivo in near realtime
nodes.desc:
[Measurement of autophagic flux in humans: an optimized method for blood samples](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8525931/pdf/KAUP_17_1846302.pdf)

There is no good way to measure autophagy in humans, but someone is working on a method for blood that might prove useful in this regard.

nodes.label: Modifying Autophagy
nodes.desc: How can we change rates of autophagy?

nodes.label: Lipofuscin Degradation
nodes.desc: It might be possible to break apart lipofuscin in the body, but so far nobody has figured it out.

nodes.desc:

Christian de Duve coined the term autophagy in 1974

nodes.label: Mitophagy Initiation
nodes.desc:
[Sirtuins' control of autophagy and mitophagy in cancer](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0163725820302795)

Mitophagy refers to the process of degrading and reconstituting mitochondria in cells.

nodes.label: Macular Degeneration
nodes.desc:
Accumulation of lipofuscin in the retinal cells creates problems for vision.  Ablating lipofuscin would probably cure macular degeneration.

[Lipofuscin and macular degeneration](https://academic.oup.com/nutritionreviews/article/61/10/342/1833038?login=false)

nodes.desc: https://sci-hub.hkvisa.net/10.1373/clinchem.2019.303248

nodes.label: Shortest Telomere Length
nodes.desc: It's possible to measure shortest telomere length, but it's not used as the standard right now.  It is suggested that this is a better approximation for telomere length and that it will give better data.

nodes.label: Telomerase
nodes.desc: https://www.cell.com/cell/pdf/0092-8674(85)90170-9.pdf?_returnURL=https%3A%2F%2Flinkinghub.elsevier.com%2Fretrieve%2Fpii%2F0092867485901709%3Fshowall%3Dtrue

nodes.label: Stop Telomere Shortening in Stem Cells
Discovery (1938)
nodes.desc:
Muller, H. J. (1938). The remaking of chromosomes. The Collecting 
Net-Woods Hole 73, 181-198.

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc:
[Telomere Length: A Review of Methods for Measurement](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4292845/pdf/nihms592942.pdf)

Currently there is no baseline data for how telomeres should look over the course of a lifespan.

nodes.label: Safe Telomere Lengthening
nodes.desc: It is currently possible to lengthen telomeres using Telomerase, but there are serious cancer/tumor risks.

nodes.label: State Change Dependent Fasting
nodes.desc: Currently, people fast and just assume good things are happening.  We have no easy biomarker to tell that you've fasted for the correct amount of time.  We need some kind of measurable state change to determine when we should stop fasting.

nodes.label: Modulate FOXO
nodes.desc:
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4783344/pdf/ACEL-15-196.pdf

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41573-020-0088-2

nodes.label: Discovery
nodes.desc: Unknown - it's almost impossible to tell when people began to modify diet for health reasons.  Probably as old as time.

nodes.label: No fasting-autophagy data in humans
nodes.desc: There is no published literature showing that fasting induces autophagy in humans.  All sources come from animal models, mostly from mice which have much faster metabolisms.

nodes.label: Dog Aging Project
nodes.desc: The [Dog Aging Project](https://dogagingproject.org/about-project/) is collecting genetic and lifestyle information to determine what factors affect the natural variance of aging.  Dietary information is a large part of this project, and can be useful for helping develop diagnostic information to modulate aging in humans.

nodes.label: Immunosenescence
nodes.desc: [Immunosenescence: A systems-level overview of immune cell biology and strategies for improving vaccine responses](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31201918/)

nodes.label: Thymic Involution
nodes.desc:
[Thymic involution and rising disease incidence with age](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29432166/)

The thymus is responsible for housing major immune system components.  It naturally atrophies with age.

nodes.label: Discovery (1974)
nodes.desc:
[Towards a network theory of the immune system](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/4142565/)

Immunology is thousands of years old, but the conception of an immune system is relatively new, only being theorized in 1974 by Niels Jerne.

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc:
[Measuring the immune system: a comprehensive approach for the analysis of immune functions in humans](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00204-016-1809-5)

How is the immune system measured?

nodes.label: Discovery (ancient)
nodes.desc: I can't find a source for this but I assume the observation has been ancient.

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc: How is hibernation measured?

nodes.label: Inducing Hibernation in Humans
nodes.desc: As far as people know, there's no hibernation mechanism in humans.

nodes.label: Engineer Hibernation in Humans
nodes.desc:
It could be a cell therapy, gene modification, or maybe even a custom organ.  Something that induces hibernation in humans could be developed, causing a body-wide slowdown of metabolism and aging.  This might have applications for space travel.

[Be cool to be far - exploiting hibernation for space exploration](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0149763421002645)

nodes.label: Recovery from Surgery
nodes.desc: Mastering hibernation could help with surgery recovery by allowing you to induce hibernative, low energy states during surgery to minimize ischemic damage or possibly use the metabolic 'restart' that occurs after hibernation in a restorative capacity for post-surgery.

nodes.label: Temperature
nodes.desc: Obviously.

nodes.label: Sleep
nodes.desc: Sleep, quiescence, torpor, or whatever other term you want to use to describe the myriad of low-energy states an organism can be in.

nodes.label: Hibernation in Mammals
nodes.desc:
Ground squirrels are the favored model organism for investigating hibernation in mammals.

[How the gut and liver hibernate](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1095643320302282)

nodes.label: Cell specific and Universal gene therapy
Diagnostics
nodes.desc: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006349519308628

nodes.label: How to freeze cells
nodes.desc: [Preservation of stem cells](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2781093/)

nodes.label: Optogenetic Silencing
nodes.desc: Lasers are used to [silence a portion](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41592-021-01212-5) of the brain.

nodes.label: Engineered Tissue
nodes.desc: Combining engineered cells with constructed ECM should allow us to build engineered tissue - it has already been [done in rats successfully](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05277-w).

nodes.label: Cure Brain Trauma
nodes.desc: Brain Trauma is a sort of mini-stroke.

nodes.label: Cure Dementia
nodes.desc: Dementia is caused by degradation of the brain - replacing brain tissue with younger tissue would solve this.

nodes.label: Brain Tissue Silencing
nodes.desc: The theory is that optogenetic silencing will cause information to migrate out of a specific portion of the brain.  Once that portion is inactive, it can be removed and replaced.

nodes.label: Build Brain Tissue Constructs
nodes.desc: Engineered neural cells can be used to build brain tissue constructs in vitro.  These brain tissue constructs could be used as diagnostic tools or as drug testing tools for a variety of neurotech applications.

nodes.label: Brain Tissue Replacement
nodes.desc: The silenced portion of the brain is then replaced by newly engineered tissue - possibly fetal tissue - to create a younger portion of the brain.  This process is then repeated until the brain gets completely regenerated.

nodes.label: Cure Stroke
nodes.desc: Stroke is a product of a large portion of the brain dying out.  In fact, this was one of the inspirations for the brain tissue replacement concept because it was observed in certain stroke victims that information moved out of damaged portions instead of being lost.

nodes.label: Cure Alzheimers
nodes.desc: It's not quite known what causes Alzheimer's, especially now that the whole plaque and tangle theory is called into question.  However, having new brain sections would definitely remove any accumulated damage.

nodes.label: Cure Epilepsy
nodes.desc: Silencing portions of the brain might be enough to cure epilepsy - at the very least making [hemispherectomies](https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/treatments/17092-hemispherectomy) obsolete.

nodes.label: Cure Schizophrenia
nodes.desc: Certain forms of schizophrenia are caused by hyperactivity of portions of the brain.  Controlled silencing could lead to better treatments.

nodes.label: ECM Scaffold
nodes.desc: A scaffold of extracellular matrix (ECM) is a necessary component for brain tissue and for tissue replacement.  We can't build this yet.

nodes.label: Engineered Cells
nodes.desc: Cells can be engineered through cellular reprogramming to construct whatever neuronal cell types are necessary.  Glia, astrocytes, neurons, etc.

nodes.label: Neuro Tree
nodes.desc: https://foresight.org/ext/ForesightNeurotechTree/

nodes.label: Blood For Surgery
nodes.desc: Having more access to blood for surgery means faster and more reliable surgery procedures.

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4878336/

nodes.label: Unstable In Vitro Life Support
nodes.desc: It's difficult to get certain types of cells to stay alive in vitro - how can we improve this?

nodes.label: Blood Storage
nodes.desc:
While we don't have lab grown blood yet, we do know how to store blood via freezing and centrifugation.

[Red-Cell Storage Duration Study](https://www.nih.gov/news-events/nih-research-matters/storing-blood-transfusion)

nodes.label: Mobile Organ Life Support
nodes.desc: It's not currently possible to keep an organ alive in a backpack, carrying it around with you while you travel.

nodes.label: Unstable Septa
nodes.desc: Moving blood into and out of the body in a sterile fashion is difficult.  The closest we have right now is a glucose monitor that uses interstitial fluid, rather than full on blood flow via veins.  It's not yet possible to reroute veins out of the body, through an external organ, and then back into the body.

nodes.label: Organoid Life Support
nodes.desc: We are able to keep organoids alive in a lab, outside of the body.

nodes.label: Discovery (1980)
nodes.desc: [Human gene therapy: a brief overview of the genetic revolution](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24471251/)

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc: How do we see what we are doing?

nodes.label: Gene Replacement
nodes.desc:
[Gene therapy: advances, challenges and perspectives](https://www.scielo.br/j/eins/a/cPw3g6fGY8srqk5hs83dDKR/?format=pdf&lang=en)

How do we replace genes in order to repair the genome?

nodes.label: Targeting
nodes.desc: The problem right now is that there is no way to accurately target specific cells for gene therapy.  You just sort of inject a whole bunch of the therapy carrier, whether it be lipid vesicles or viruses, and assume they will get distributed through the body.  There is no way to target specific cells for gene therapy.

nodes.label: Blood Vessel Problem
nodes.desc: When removing a head from a body, blood vessels must be cut.  This prevents blood from getting to the head, which many see as deleterious to the health of the head.

nodes.label: Immune Rejection
nodes.desc: The immune system will attack foreign objects it detects, including the head of another organism.  If a head transplant is to succeed, it needs to solve the immunity problem.

nodes.label: Spinal Cord Fusion
nodes.desc: Severing the nerves in the spinal cord stops the head from regulating the rest of the body.

nodes.label: Head Transplant
nodes.desc: A head transplant would effectively 'reverse' damage over the entire body.

nodes.label: Fusogens
nodes.desc: Fusogens are a class of proteins that can initiate the fusion of cell membranes, combining multiple cells together.

nodes.label: Immunosuppressants
nodes.desc: In the mid-20th century, immunosuppressants were discovered which could shut off the immune system.

nodes.label: Blood Vessel Suturing
nodes.desc: In the early 20th century, a man working at the Rockefeller Institute with extremely questionable ethical views (Alexis Carrel) discovered how to suture blood vessels together.

nodes.label: Robotic Surgery
nodes.desc: Robotic surgery may make it possible to perform extremely complex tasks, like fusing dozens or hundreds of nerves together in a limited time window.

nodes.label: Limb Reattachment
nodes.desc: Prior to blood vessel reconstruction, it was impossible to save severed limbs.  Now we consider it standard practice to reattach an arm or a leg if it is in good enough condition.

nodes.label: Organ Transplantation
nodes.desc: Immunosuppressants allow the temporary operation of incompatible organs in a host that would have rejected them.   It's not a permanent solution (it makes the host vulnerable to disease) but it does technically work.

nodes.label: Spinal Complexity
nodes.desc: The spinal cord can be thought of as a bundle of wires that must be connected to another bundle of wires, each one needs to attach correctly or else communication fails.  The constraints of surgery time and limited diagnostic tools makes it nearly impossible to perform this task in a practical sense.

nodes.label: Discovery (1900)
nodes.desc: Many people ascribe the origin of head transplantation to Alexis Carrel, at the start of the 1900's.  However, I read somewhere that shortly after the French Revolution there was an abundance of... test matter that sparked the idea of head transplants.  No physical evidence exists to corroberate this idea though, so the official timeline will be c. 1900.

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc: https://www.cdc.gov/labstandards/pdf/hs/HoSt_Brochure.pdf

nodes.label: Human Organ Donors
nodes.desc: We use organs from a willing organ donor for transplants as long as key biomarkers line up to prevent rejection or complications.

nodes.label: Organ Reconstruction
nodes.desc: Stem cells are used to repopulate a depleted ECM scaffold, building an organ.

nodes.label: Cheap, fast reproductive health diagnostic panel
Inevitable Oocyte Attrition
nodes.desc: Oocytes are lost continuously throughout the lifespan.

nodes.label: Alleviate symptoms of menopause
nodes.desc: Hormone Replacement Therapy alleviates symptoms of menopause without changing the underlying condition.

nodes.label: Menopause
nodes.desc: Menopause describes the cessation of menstruation and the associated health decline that comes with it.

nodes.label: Andropause
nodes.desc: Andropause describes the male cessation of reproductive potential and the associated health decline

nodes.label: Human Germline Stem Cells
nodes.desc: There is questionable evidence for the existence of human germline stem cells in adult humans.  But that wouldn't stop us from engineering them if we knew how germline biology worked.

nodes.label: Hypoxia Inducible Factor
nodes.desc: HIF-1 Induces proteolysis

nodes.label: PROTACS
nodes.desc:
[Proteolysis Targeting Chimera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proteolysis_targeting_chimera)

This is an emerging field that is creating a lot of value right now, it uses the ubiquitin system to tag any type of molecule - protein, DNA, RNA, etc. - for degradation.  You can target things that no other knockout method can target to see gene knockouts without completely removing the gene from the cell.  Very cool stuff.

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc: [Measuring activity in the ubiquitin-proteasome system: From large scale discoveries to single cells analysis](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3758771/)

nodes.label: Controlling Proteolysis
nodes.desc: How do we modulate proteostasis to increase turnover of damaged cells without disrupting normal function?

nodes.label: Using proteolysis against specific target
nodes.desc: It's one thing to increase proteolysis wholesale, but what about using it against specific targets?

nodes.label: Discovery (1951)
nodes.desc:
I can't find the origin of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in scientific literature.  Dan Harman is often cited as the origin for the term as related to theories on aging.

[Aging - A theory based on free radical and radiation chemistry](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/sageke.2002.37.cp14)

nodes.label: Electron Paramagnetic Resonance
nodes.desc:
All three of the methods here have the same source:

[Guidelines for measuring reactive oxygen species and oxidative damage in cells and in vivo](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9711940/)

nodes.label: Diagnostics
nodes.desc: How do we measure ROS?

nodes.label: Modulate ROS
nodes.desc: How do we affect the problem?

nodes.label: Control Reactive Oxygen Species
nodes.desc: If we can control ROS we can mitigate damage while simultaneously annihilating bacterial infections and maintaining cell signaling pathways.

nodes.label: Oxidative Damage
nodes.desc:
All three of the methods here have the same source:

[Guidelines for measuring reactive oxygen species and oxidative damage in cells and in vivo](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9711940/)

nodes.label: Probe Molecules
nodes.desc:
All three of the methods here have the same source:

[Guidelines for measuring reactive oxygen species and oxidative damage in cells and in vivo](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9711940/)

nodes.label: Antioxidants
nodes.desc:
Antioxidants have long been touted to reduce ROS.  It does make sense, but often antioxidants that are eaten don't make it into the body intact.  The major methods of natural ROS mitigation are glutathione (often written as GSH, or G-SH where SH represents the sulfur functional group) or selenoproteins.  Interestingly, GSH is regenerated via a pathway that relies on vitamin E and C, which is why they are so critical to health.

[Image](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/282243655/figure/fig3/AS:532640961961989@1504002909082/LA-and-DHLA-regenerate-endogenous-antioxidants-such-as-vitamins-C-and-E-and-GSH-The.png)

nodes.label: Antibiotics
nodes.desc: The immune system uses ROS against microbial invasion.  Upregulating ROS in specific contexts may reduce disease caused by bacteria.

nodes.label: Create ROS
nodes.desc: Sometimes ROS are useful - they are necessary for cell signaling and are used by the immune system to attack invading bacteria.  Maybe we also want to be able to create ROS when necessary?

nodes.label: Remove ROS
nodes.desc: How do we remove ROS?

nodes.label: Specific Removal
nodes.desc:

nodes.label: Vitrification

[Cryopreservation of organs by vitrification](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15094092/)

When water freezes into ice, it expands.  This expansion destroys cells and damages proteins on a molecular level.  By adding in specific chemicals, you can get water to freeze without forming crystals.  This process is called vitrification.
