nodes.label: Matreotype - ECM composition changes
nodes.desc: The matreotype is a way to analyze and understand changes in the matrisome or ECM that occur with aging and disease (Ewald, 2020). The matreotype is defined as the molecular and structural signature of an ECM composition or snapshot associated or caused by a phenotype or cellular status (Ewald, 2020), and can be measured using techniques such as mass spectrometry or immunohistochemistry (Byron et al., 2013; Goddard et al., 2016; Liu and Modo, 2018). The ECM is a dynamic network of molecules that surrounds and supports cells in tissues and organs, and the matreotype concept recognizes it as a modular, heterogeneous system rather than a static entity. By measuring the levels of different ECM molecules and their spatial distribution, a "fingerprint" of the ECM can be generated to track changes over time (Ewald, 2020). The matreotype concept has several potential advantages, including being able to comprehensively characterize the ECM, detecting subtle changes, and applying it to a wide range of tissues and organs (Ewald, 2020). Research on the role of the matreotype in cancer, specifically ovarian high-grade serous carcinoma, suggests that understanding the matreotype may help in developing more effective cancer treatments (Pietilä et al., 2021). Further research is needed to fully realize the potential of the matreotype to develop reliable measurement methods.

nodes.label: ECM Post-translational changes
nodes.desc: Post-translational modifications of the ECM serve a vital role in regulating cellular behavior and maintaining tissue homeostasis—which may alter the physical and biological properties of the ECM and modulate their interactions with cells and other ECM components (Lu et al., 2011).

nodes.label: Pathological ECM Deposition
nodes.desc: Pathological ECM deposition is a process in which excessive quantities of ECM components, such as collagen, are deposited in a tissue, causing fibrosis and malfunction. This process is mediated by the activation and proliferation of fibroblasts, which create and deposit ECM proteins. The underlying causes of pathological ECM deposition are complicated and multifaceted, involving signaling pathway dysregulation and aberrant activation of inflammatory and immune cells. Furthermore, genetic and epigenetic variables play an important role in the regulation of pathogenic ECM deposition. This degenerative process is a characteristic of many chronic illnesses, including fibrotic disorders, cancer, and cardiovascular disease, and it leads to the gradual loss of organ function as well as the development of clinically significant morbidity and mortality. Methods for detecting a pathological ECM are discussed below.

nodes.label: Calcification/Mineralization
nodes.desc:
Vascular calcification pathology is identified as abnormal calcification of elastic arteries or muscular vessel walls. The mechanism of vascular calcification is similar to bone metabolism. While the exact mechanism remains elusive, integrity maintenance of vascular ECM and calcification are correlated (Uto et al., 2021). Age-related pathologies such as type 2 diabetes, atherosclerosis, chronic kidney disease, and increased risk of cardiovascular events are all attributed in part to vascular calcification (Budoff et al., 2011; Ngai et al., 2018). Vascular intima diffuse calcification is associated with matrix vesicles. As part of the ECM component, matrix vesicles are derived from cell budding, cartilage cell, osteoblast, and odontoblast. Matrix vesicles also part from cells to initiate organelle self-governance. These ECM components provide adequate nucleation for calcium crystal formation, and network scaffolding for their calcium deposit is provided by elastins in its vascular walls (Wang et al., 2021).

Furthermore, ECM elastin fibers participate in the calcification of arterial walls. Studies using histochemistry and electron microscopy have divulged two distinct calcification of elastic fiber in the plaques of human atherosclerosis. While structural changes were not detected in the type I calcification, type II showed significant structural changes in the elastin (Bobryshev, 2005). And Khavandgar et al. demonstrated that in matrix Gla protein (MGP)-deficient and ELN haploinsufficient (MGP–/–; ELN±) murine, calcification was found to be dependent upon the presence of elastin. This led to a significant reduction in arterial calcium deposition in the case of elastin haploinsufficiency (Khavandgar et al., 2014).

nodes.label: Inflammation
nodes.desc:
Inherent to many autoimmune diseases are chronically inflamed tissues (Sorokin, 2010). Damages to tissues generate inflammation, and the ECM undergoes degradation by proteases and cytokines that produce and direct functions by penetrating leukocytes (Agrawal et al., 2008; Metzemaekers et al., 2016; Nourshargh et al., 2010). 

Upregulation of Interferon-gamma (IFNγ) and Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) occur at the site of inflammation. These cytokines modify interstitial matrix synthesis and turnover. And the cytokines also induce matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) secretion and or activation (Sorokin, 2010). As zinc-dependent endopeptidase, MMPs site-specifically cleave ECM and other proteins (Malemud, 2006; Yong, 2005). Hyaluronan fragmentation increases the activity of MMP during inflammation (Sugahara et al., 2003; Yong, 2005). MMPs increase due to the inflammation release of fragments of tenascin and sulfated proteoglycans--ECM-derived DAMPs (damage-associated molecular patterns) (Brule et al., 2006; Gaudet and Popovich, 2014), resulting in a vicious cycle that fragments ECM. Tissue-remodeling processes facilitated by anomalous ECM fragments are able to modify immune cells and their immune responses in chronically inflamed tissues (Gaudet and Popovich, 2014).

nodes.label: Senescence
nodes.desc:
Previously, senescence was defined as an end-point to stress, causing cells to lose their proliferative ability [Muñoz-Espín 2014]. Our understanding has since grown to include senescence as an ancillary to integrin-signaling complex components in C. elegans and D. melanogaster. Experiments have shown integrin-linked kinase (ILK) deletion to be fatal. However, a moderate reduction of ILK caused favorable function in increasing lifespan in these model organisms [Kumsta, Goddeeris]. In particular, C. elegans showed an increased lifespan while preserving cytoskeletal integrity [Kumsta]. Further investigation through RNAi screening found pat-4/ILK  pat-6/Parvin depletion to be responsible for its increase [Kumsta, Hansen]. In Drosophila, mortality and behavioral aging delay were observed in the loss-of-function myospheroid gene mutations that encode for β1-integrin--the binding partner of the ILK [Goddeeris]. Coronin-7 (Coro7), necessary for proper cytoskeletal functions, has been associated with prolonged lifespan in mice [Vitiello et al.]. Also, cytoskeleton remodeling has been known to be closely correlated to ECM remodeling. And, ECM remodeling has a critical role in mechanotransduction and improved health span [Ewald 2015, Ewald 2019, Statzer and Ewald 2020]. In addition, senescence was perforced by the β3 integrin via the transforming growth factor (TGF)–β pathway, and the converse held true with its knockdown besting senescence [Rapisarda]. These findings suggest improved targeting precision in the down-regulation of integrin signaling mechanisms as the potential therapy for senescence [Shin].

- Cecilia Park

nodes.label: UV Damage
nodes.desc:
Ultraviolet radiation (UVR) is attributed to vitamin D production in humans and may assist in cardiovascular health through nitric oxide synthesis (Watson et al., 2014). While vitamin D halts pro-inflammatory programs of TH1 cells (Chauss et al., 2022; Minton, 2022), chronic UVR exposure can also increase the probability of photocarcinogenesis by incurring damage to fibroblasts and dermis and accelerating phenotypical aging (Budden et al., 2021; Gilchrest et al., 1999; Watson et al., 2014).

The quantity of available collagen in the ECM has been attributed to melanoma behavior modifications (Ahmadzadeh et al., 2017; Budden et al., 2021). And it has been shown that collagen-cleaving matrix metalloprotein-1 (MMP1) expression is upregulated by UVR-induced fibroblast damage (Levental et al., 2009). However, malignant behavior is also induced by the decreased deposition of collagen (Arnold et al., 2010), suggesting that collagen has a role in carcinogenesis beyond the scaffolding function normally associated with this protein (Budden et al., 2021).

Even though remodeling of the compositional architecture of the ECM induced by prolonged UVR exposure has been attributed to premature skin aging, the exact pathway requires further investigation (Watson et al., 2014). In particular, photodegrading downstream effects of fibronectin and fibrillin and their induction on tissue homeostasis are less understood (Watson et al., 2014).

nodes.label: Advanced Glycation Endproducts
nodes.desc: Advanced Glycation End-products (AGEs) are non-enzymatically formed on proteins such as collagens and elastins. Lysine and arginine residues frequently become glycated after prolonged exposure to sugars causing age-dependent modifications (Schmidt et al., 1994; Vijg and Campisi, 2008). Matrix stiffening occurs as a result of cross-linking of these AGEs and the steric hinders of enzymatic cleavages required for remodeling. As a response, protease levels are increased, triggering yet another cascade of further damage to the ECM (Ewald, 2020) by causing unrestrained protease activity and collagen deposition (Fisher et al., 2009). Thus, AGE accumulations and their crosslinks modify the mechanical properties of the ECM with the procession of time and increase the risk of many diseases caused by oxidative stress and inflammation: diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure, kidney failures, premature aging, Alzheimer's, and fibrosis (Ahmed, 2005; Gautieri et al., 2016; Glenn and Stitt, 2009; Pertyńska-Marczewska et al., 2009; Semba et al., 2009; Singh et al., 2010).

nodes.label: Loss of Proteolysis
nodes.desc:
The breakdown of proteins (proteolysis) controls ECM assembly, modification, and endocytosis of superfluous ECM materials, bioactive fragments, and growth factors (Solomonov et al., 2016; Werb, 1997). Proteolysis is also critical in ECM structure reassembly, tissue repair, pathological processes, morphogenesis, and cell death (Solomonov et al., 2016; Werb, 1997). Hence, any changes made by proteolysis to the cell surface and ECM can have an immediate and irrevocable impact (Solomonov et al., 2016). 

Maintaining a homeostatic balance of proteolysis is critical in maintaining healthspan as either overproduction or deficiency can lead to disease progressions. The Matrix Metalloproteinases (MMPs) and their closely related A Disintegrin and Metalloproteinases (ADAMs) possess proteolytic properties and are critical contributing factors in various physiological processes and pathologies such as cancer progression and inflammation (Shimoda, 2019). For example, the key component of wound healing is the degradation of provisional ECM produced by the fibrin clot caused by the wound. Injury is repaired by the keratinocytes migration that produces Urokinase Plasminogen Activators (uPAs) and MMPs to close the wound through its interaction with dermal fibroblast. Mice lacking the plasminogen gene, keratinocytes are unable to migrate, and the wound is not healing, indicating the importance of proteolysis homeostasis (Bugge et al., 1996).

Additionally, Kuzuya et al. demonstrated loss of proteolysis is a consequence of the accumulation of crosslinks in the collagen, which is a common feature of aging by showing smooth muscle cells grown on collagen fibrils activated pro-MMP-2 and was accompanied by increased expression of MT1-MMP and suppressed production of TIMP-2. However, when the smooth muscle cells were grown on glycated collagen fibrils, MMP-2 activation was inhibited, and expression of MT1-MMP was reduced without affecting TIMP-2 production. This suggests that the suppression of MT1-MMP expression may be involved in inhibiting MMP-2 activation on glycated collagen fibrils. The inclusion of aminoguanidine, a cross-linking inhibitor, during collagen glycation restored MMP-2 activation, indicates that cross-links may play a role in the inhibition of MMP-2 activation (Kuzuya et al., 2001). Crosslinking reduces the flexibility and elasticity of collagen, making it more resistant to proteolytic degradation (Bourne et al., 2014; DeGroot et al., 2001; Kuzuya et al., 2001), leading to the accumulation of senescent ECM, which can impair tissue function and contribute to age-related diseases (Bourne et al., 2014; DeGroot et al., 2001). And Col1a1r/r mice, with their type I collagen resistance to collagenase cleavage, exhibited accelerated aging, a host of age-related pathologies, and a dramatic acceleration of senescent cell accumulation (Vafaie et al., 2014). Furthermore, Mmp24-deficient mice exhibit reduced levels of Aβ and APP and decreased glial reactivity and IL-1β levels, the pivotal function of MT5-MMP (MMP-24) in Alzheimer's disease progression, as evidenced by its capacity to cleave APP and regulate neuronal activity in the hippocampus (Freitas-Rodríguez et al., 2017; Willem et al., 2015)–highlighting the crucial role of proteolysis in regulating various age-related pathologies (Baranger et al., 2016; Freitas-Rodríguez et al., 2017). Therefore, maintaining a balance of proteolysis is crucial for maintaining the healthspan of tissues and preventing age-related diseases.

nodes.label: Herovici Staining
nodes.desc:
Herovici staining is a histological staining method that is used to visualize the immature and mature collagen of tissues. It is based on the reaction of the ECM with a solution of toluidine blue, which results in the formation of a blue dye that can be seen under a microscope. Herovici staining can be used to visualize the collagen type I and III in various tissues, including skin, heart, and lung, and it can provide valuable information about the structure and composition of the ECM (Badylak, 2002; Fitzgerald et al., 1996; Herovici, 1963; Teuscher et al., 2019).

Herovici staining can potentially be used as a biomarker of aging, as the ECM undergoes changes in its composition and structure with aging. These changes can affect the mechanical properties and functions of the ECM, and they can contribute to various age-related diseases, such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease. To use Herovici staining as a biomarker of aging, tissue samples can be obtained from a range of ages and processed for histological staining using the Herovici method. The stained samples can then be examined under a microscope, and the changes in the ECM can be quantified and compared between different ages (Badylak, 2002). This can provide a measure of the changes in the ECM that occur with aging, and it can be used as an indicator of the age-related changes in the ECM. This method can provide valuable insights into the mechanisms of ECM aging and can potentially be used to develop interventions that can slow or reverse these changes.

nodes.label: ECM Enriched Proteomics
nodes.desc:
ECM-enriched proteomics involves the isolation and purification of ECM proteins, followed by the identification and quantification of these proteins using mass spectrometry-based techniques (Byron et al., 2013; Naba et al., 2012). This allows researchers to systematically analyze the ECM proteome and understand the specific proteins that are present and their relative abundance (Byron et al., 2013; Naba et al., 2012). Examples of different approaches to tackle these problems are described below:

Naba et al. used a combination of computational and experimental techniques to define and characterize the ECM proteome in normal and tumor tissues. They used in-silico (computational) methods to identify and predict the ECM proteome and then validated their predictions using in-vivo (experimental) techniques, such as mass spectrometry. The authors found that the ECM proteome is highly dynamic and can vary significantly between different tissues and under different physiological conditions. They also identified several ECM proteins that are differentially expressed in normal and tumor tissues and identified several ECM proteins that may be potential therapeutic targets for cancer. Overall, the study highlights the importance of the ECM in normal and pathological processes and the potential for ECM-targeted therapies to improve human health (Naba et al., 2012).

SWATH (Sequential Window Acquisition of All Theoretical Fragment Ion mass spectrometry) is a mass spectrometry-based technique that may be used for the quantitative profiling of the matrisome (Collins et al., 2017; Gillet et al., 2012). In SWATH mass spectrometry, samples are first digested into peptides using proteases, and the resulting peptides are then analyzed by mass spectrometry. During the analysis, the mass spectrometer sequentially scans through a range of m/z (mass-to-charge) values, acquiring fragment ion spectra for each m/z value. This allows the acquisition of data from a wide range of peptides in a single experiment (Krasny et al., 2018). One of the key advantages of SWATH mass spectrometry is its ability to provide highly sensitive and reproducible quantitation of large numbers of proteins, making it an ideal tool for the quantitative profiling of the matreotype (Krasny et al., 2018). Additionally, the technique does not require the use of stable isotope-labeled standards, which can be expensive and time-consuming to produce (Krasny et al., 2018; Tabata et al., 2007). Overall, SWATH mass spectrometry is a powerful tool for the quantitation of the matrisome and can provide valuable insights into the composition and function of the ECM in normal and pathological conditions (Krasny et al., 2018). OpenSWATH is a highly advanced analytical pipeline designed to unravel the complex interplay between the liver proteome, molecular variations, and metabolic traits. By harnessing the power of mass spectrometry, this pipeline generated an extensive inventory of quantified proteomic data from 662 mice to determine the connections between diet, aging, and gene expression. A major signature of aging was the matrisome (Williams et al., 2022).

Hiebert et al. investigated that the activation of the Nrf2 signaling pathway leads to the reprogramming of fibroblasts and the induction of cellular senescence. They also found that this process is mediated by the targeted modification of the matreotype, specifically through the downregulation of ECM proteins such as collagens and the upregulation of ECM-degrading enzymes such as MMPs (Hiebert et al., 2018). Their study demonstrated the potential for targeting matrisome as a therapeutic strategy for diseases associated with fibroblast dysfunction (Hiebert et al., 2018).

Tissue engineering is a field of medicine that seeks to repair or replace damaged or diseased tissues using a variety of approaches, including the use of scaffolds to support the growth of new cells (Caddeo et al., 2017; Hill et al., 2015). Scaffolds are three-dimensional structures that provide physical support for cells to grow and differentiate (Caddeo et al., 2017; Hill et al., 2015). Hill et al. quantified the levels of ECM proteins in a rat lung scaffold and used this information to provide a molecular readout for tissue engineering by using mass spectrometry to quantify the levels of ECM proteins. They found that the scaffold contained a variety of ECM proteins, including collagens, laminins, and proteoglycans. They also found that the levels of these proteins varied depending on the stage of scaffold development–suggesting that the quantification of ECM proteins may be useful as a molecular readout for tissue engineering applications (Hill et al., 2015).

Li et al. used a combination of spatial quantitative proteomics, decellularization, laser capture microdissection, and mass spectrometry to construct a hierarchical map of the proteome in human skin tissue. They analyzed the specific functions of different structures of normal skin tissue and tissue with dermatologic disease. They then identified the ECM glycoprotein transforming growth factor-beta (TGFβ)-induced protein ig-h3 (TGFBI) in the basement membrane (BM), a thin layer at the top of the dermis, which plays a role in the growth and function of epidermal stem cells (EpSCs) and promotes wound healing. These findings provide insights into the way in which ECM proteins contribute to the function of EpSCs in the BM and may have potential clinical applications in the treatment of skin ulcers or diseases with refractory lesions that involve epidermal cell dysfunction and impaired re-epithelialization (Li et al., 2022).

ECM-enriched proteomics is a powerful tool for studying the ECM and its role in various biological processes, including tissue development, maintenance, and repair (Byron et al., 2013; Lindsey et al., 2012; Naba et al., 2012). It is also useful for studying the ECM in the context of diseases, as the ECM is often altered in the context of various diseases, including cancer and neurodegenerative diseases (Arteel and Naba, 2020; Iozzo and Gubbiotti, 2018; Naba et al., 2012; Sonbol, 2018). Understanding these changes may provide insights into the underlying pathological mechanisms and identify potential therapeutic targets.

nodes.label: ECM Biomarkers
nodes.desc: Collagen fragments, specifically those derived from the ECM, have been investigated as potential biomarkers in various pathological conditions. The degradation of ECM collagen has been shown to be indicative of matrix remodeling, which is a hallmark of several pathological states, including cancer and fibrosis. The following are examples of such fragments.

nodes.label: ECM Labeling
nodes.desc:
ECM labeling is a technique used to visualize and quantitatively analyze the ECM in biological tissues. This can be achieved through the use of various fluorescent dyes or antibodies that specifically bind to ECM components, such as collagens and glycosaminoglycans (Hu et al., 2022; Leonard et al., 2018). Alterations in the ECM composition can provide insight into the disease state, which may be utilized as a diagnostic tool for various pathologies, including cancer and fibrosis. 

Imaging probes GFPtpz and mCherry-tagged collagen fusion constructs were developed by Lu and his team for the live imaging of type I collagen assembly by replacing the α2(I)-procollagen N-terminal propeptide with GFPtpz or mCherry. These imaging probes were transfected into cells and were used to examine the dynamics of type I collagen assembly and its relationship to fibronectin. The fusion proteins were found to co-precipitate with α1(I)-collagen, remaining intracellular without ascorbate but forming α1(I) collagen-containing extracellular fibrils in the presence of ascorbate. The study demonstrates the utility of these imaging probes in providing new insights into the mechanisms of extracellular collagen assembly and its dependence on cell motion and fibronectin assembly–a critical step in understanding the complexities of ECM formation (Lu et al., 2018).

Fischer et al. employed a multifaceted approach to investigate the intricacies of the wound-healing process in internal organs. The ECM was labeled in different organs, specifically the mouse peritoneum, liver, and cecum, to reveal the transfer of preexisting matrix across organs in various injury models. The tissue of origin for the transferred matrix was found to dictate the outcome of the healing process, whether it resulted in scarring or regeneration. The transfer of matrix was found to be mediated by neutrophils, in a manner dependent on the HSF-integrin AM/B2-kindlin3 cascade, suggesting that pharmacological inhibition of this cascade could prevent the formation of peritoneal adhesions. These may provide a therapeutic window to mitigate scarring across a range of conditions, highlighting ECM labeling as a potential diagnostic tool in wound healing and regenerative medicine (Fischer et al., 2022).

nodes.label: ECM Aging Clocks
nodes.desc:
The field of aging research has undergone significant advancements in recent years, as evidenced by the accessible descriptions and measurements of aging (Horvath, 2013a; López-Otín et al., 2013a). These advancements have led to the proliferation of statistical and machine learning models, which have been employed to track age-related changes at the omic and phenotypic level (Consortium et al., 2021; Galkin et al., 2020; Lazarus et al., 2019; Newman et al., 2016; Rutledge et al., 2022; Schultz et al., 2020).

One key application of these models is the use of the so-called "Aging Clock" to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at extending lifespan, rather than waiting for the entire lifetime of study subjects (X. He et al., 2021; Johnson et al., 2022). Additionally, the availability of online services for DNA methylation analysis, such as DNA methylation age and the epigenetic clock (Horvath, 2013b) and SudoClock (“SudoClock,” n.d.), has further facilitated the use of aging clocks in research. Furthermore, consumer services have also started to offer age predictions based on these aging clocks.

However, despite these advances, there currently exists no "Aging Clock" that directly tracks changes within the ECM. This is particularly noteworthy given that a recent causal investigation of DNA methylation clocks has revealed changes in the ECM to be a major contributor to age-related adaptations (Ying et al., 2022). To evaluate interventions targeting the ECM, researchers must instead rely on individually tailored markers (Zaseck et al., 2016) or surrogate markers, such as differential expression of collagen genes (Chondronasiou et al., 2022) or methylomics of ECM organization promoters (Gill et al., 2022).

Recent efforts have been made to index ECM aging, including the use of modern computational methods. For example, Lehallier et al. used levels of ECM-associated proteins in blood plasma to predict age with relative accuracy (Lehallier et al., 2020). McCabe et al. compiled changes in skin ECM composition during aging and photoaging using quantitative and global proteomics, single harmonic generation, and two-photon autofluorescence imaging (McCabe et al., 2020). Li et al. used tandem mass spectrometry alongside bioinformatic analysis to produce skin proteome profiles and matrisome features at different ages (Li et al., 2021).

Given the unique influences of ECM aging on important medical practices, such as transplantation (Acun et al., 2021), the development of a standardized ECM aging clock would have a profound impact on medicine. However, until such a model is developed, numerous interesting scientific questions remain unanswered, including which features of the ECM would be most represented, whether they would be tissue-specific, and how closely they would correlate, precede, or follow other clock changes. Additionally, it remains to be seen whether these features could be slowed or reversed.

nodes.label: Tail Tendon Break Time
nodes.desc:
The tail tendon break time (TTBT) assay is a technique that is used to measure the mechanical properties of the ECM in tissues, such as stiffness and tensile strength (Haefke and Ewald, 2020; Sherman et al., 1985; Sloane et al., 2011; Stammers et al., 2020), and may be used as a diagnostic tool of aging (Haefke and Ewald, 2020; Sherman et al., 1985; Sloane et al., 2011; Stammers et al., 2020). A tail tendon of a rodent, such as a mouse or a rat, consists mainly of collagen and is isolated and attached to a weight, and then emersed in a urea water bath. The time it takes for the tendon to rupture due to the attached weight correlates with the crosslinking of the collagen in the tendon, which increases with age  (Haefke and Ewald, 2020).

TTBT has been used to study a wide range of conditions that affect tendon health, including aging, diabetes, and various forms of arthritis. It has also been used to evaluate the effectiveness of potential therapeutic interventions, such as exercise and various drugs (Haefke and Ewald, 2020; Sherman et al., 1985; Sloane et al., 2011; Stammers et al., 2020) and has been found to be a reliable and valid method for measuring tendon mechanical properties in rodent models. However, it is important to note that the results of the assay may not directly translate to humans, as the anatomy and physiology of tendons in rodents are not exactly the same as in humans. Additionally, the assay is destructive, so cannot be used to test the same tendon multiple times (Haefke and Ewald, 2020; Sloane et al., 2011).

nodes.label: Glycosylation
nodes.desc:
Glycosylation, the process of adding sugars to proteins or lipids to form glycans, is a fundamental aspect of cellular function and plays a key role in various physiological and pathological conditions (Miura and Endo, 2016; Reily et al., 2019; Rudman et al., 2019; Zaytseva et al., 2022). In particular, N-glycosylation, covalently attaches N-glycans to proteins at asparagine (Asn) residues (Stanley et al., 2022). N-glycan levels in the blood can be measured using techniques such as mass spectrometry or lectin-based assays, and changes in these levels over time may provide insight into the aging process and the risk of age-related diseases (Miura and Endo, 2016; Mkhikian et al., 2022; Zaytseva et al., 2022). Zaytseva et al. observed the relationship between changes in the N-glycosylation of immunoglobulin G (IgG) and 12 different diseases, including autoimmune, inflammatory, neurodegenerative, cardiovascular diseases, and some types of cancer, by utilizing Mendelian randomization to examine the causal relationship between IgG N-glycosylation and disease risks. It was found that there is indeed a positive causal effect of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) on the abundance of certain N-glycans in the total IgG N-glycome. These findings suggest this particular IgG glycosylation trait could potentially be used as a biomarker for SLE (Zaytseva et al., 2022).

Aging is also associated with impaired T-cell immunity, which can increase the risk of mortality from infectious diseases such as influenza, Salmonella, and COVID-19 (Mkhikian et al., 2022). Studies have shown that the branching of asparagine-linked glycans increases with age in females more than males, in naive T cells more than memory T cells, and CD4+ T cells more than CD8+ T cells. Interleukin-7 (IL-7) signaling increased in old female mice and triggered increased branching, which was also increased by the rate-limiting metabolite N-acetylglucosamine. Reversing elevated branching can rejuvenate T cell function and reduce the severity of Salmonella infection in old female mice. These findings suggest that IL-7 initially benefits immunity through naive T cells maintenance but inhibits naive T cells function through increased branching in combination with age-dependent increases in N-acetylglucosamine (Deriš et al., 2022; Mkhikian et al., 2022). These studies and others highlight the importance of understanding the role of glycosylation in aging and age-related diseases, as well as the potential for using N-glycosylation as a biomarker and developing interventions to improve T-cell immunity in aging individuals.

nodes.label: Elasticity
nodes.desc:
Elasticity is a mechanical property of materials that describes their ability to stretch and deform without breaking. In the context of the ECM, elasticity is a crucial property that affects the mechanical properties and functions of the ECM (Chaudhuri et al., 2020; Gattazzo et al., 2014; Muiznieks and Keeley, 2013). As the ECM ages, it undergoes changes in its composition and structure, which can affect its elasticity and its ability to maintain its proper functions (Chaudhuri et al., 2020; Gattazzo et al., 2014).

Elasticity can be used as a potential biomarker of ECM aging, as it is a sensitive and specific measure of the changes that occur in the ECM with aging (Kim et al., 2021; Marrese et al., 2017; McCabe et al., 2020). To measure elasticity as a diagnostic tool, tissue samples can be obtained from a range of ages and processed for mechanical testing. For instance, by probing the surface of cancer tissue biopsies with indentation-type atomic force microscopy, the stiffer tumor tissue can be detected (Plodinec et al., 2012). Furthermore, samples can be subjected to mechanical stress, and the resulting deformations can be measured using various methods, such as laser diffraction or atomic force microscopy (Marrese et al., 2017). This can provide a quantitative measure of the changes in elasticity that occur with aging, and it can be used as an indicator of age-related changes in the ECM. This method can provide valuable insights into the mechanisms of ECM aging and can potentially be used to develop interventions that can slow or reverse these changes.

nodes.label: Autofluorescence
nodes.desc:
Autofluorescence is a phenomenon in which cells or tissues emit fluorescence without the need for external staining or labeling (Croce and Bottiroli, 2014). This occurs because certain molecules within cells, such as proteins, nucleic acids, and lipids, naturally fluoresce when excited by light of a specific wavelength. Autofluorescence can be used as a biomarker for various cellular processes, including aging, and it can be measured using fluorescence microscopy or spectroscopy (Kolenc and Quinn, 2019).

One possible method to use autofluorescence as an ECM aging clock is to measure the autofluorescence of ECM molecules, such as collagen and elastin. These molecules are the major structural components of the ECM, and they play a key role in maintaining the mechanical properties and functions of the ECM. As cells and tissues age, the ECM undergoes changes in its composition and structure, which can affect its mechanical properties and functions (Croce and Bottiroli, 2014; McCabe et al., 2020). For example, aging can cause the ECM to stiffen, which can impair mechanotransduction and lead to stem cell exhaustion (Boers et al., 2018). The C. elegans cuticle, which is mainly composed of collagens, becomes autofluorescent and stiffens with aging, and longevity interventions are able to slow or prevent this age-related stiffening of the ECM in vivo (Davis et al., 1982; Rahimi et al., 2021; Teuscher et al., 2022). 

To measure the autofluorescence of ECM molecules as an aging clock, tissue samples can be obtained from a range of ages and processed for fluorescence microscopy or spectroscopy. The samples can be excited with light of a specific wavelength, and the emitted fluorescence can be measured and compared between different ages. This can provide a quantitative measure of the changes in autofluorescence that occur with aging, and it can be used as an indicator of the age-related changes in the ECM. This method can provide valuable insights into the mechanisms of ECM aging and can potentially be used to develop interventions that can slow or reverse these changes (Croce and Bottiroli, 2014; Wizenty et al., 2020).

nodes.label: Non-enzymatic Glycation
nodes.desc:
Non-enzymatic glycation, also known as the Maillard reaction, is a chemical process in which reducing sugars or α-dicarbonyl metabolites bind to amino or thiol groups of proteins, lipids, and nucleotides (Ye et al., 2014). This reaction leads to the formation of advanced glycation end products (AGEs), which have been implicated in the development of various age-related diseases, including cardiovascular disease, kidney disease, and neurodegenerative diseases (Ma et al., 2021; Robert and Labat-Robert, 2014; Zhang et al., 2009). 

To measure the levels of AGEs in tissues, scientists have developed various techniques, such as fluorescence-based assays, which can detect the accumulation of AGEs in proteins and other biomolecules. Other methods include ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) and HPLC (High-performance liquid chromatography), which measure the accumulation of specific AGEs. Autophagy, an evolutionarily conserved cellular process that maintains cellular homeostasis through the degradation and recycling of intracellular components, has been shown to be activated by AGEs (Huang et al., 2017; Takahashi et al., 2017). This observation has led to the postulation that targeting autophagic pathways may represent a novel therapeutic strategy for the mitigation of AGEs-induced morbidity and mortality (Sruthi and Raghu, 2021).

nodes.label: Amorphous Collagen Deposition
nodes.desc: Amorphous collagen deposition, also known as diffuse collagenous fibrosis, is a pathological condition characterized by the disorganized accumulation of collagen within ECM in the absence of a defined fibrotic lesion (Bielajew et al., 2020; Teuscher et al., 2019). Methods for detecting amorphous collagen depositions include Herovici staining, Masson’s trichrome staining, and second harmonic generation imaging.

nodes.label: Hydroxyproline
nodes.desc:
Hydroxyproline is an amino acid derived from the post-translational modification of collagen via prolyl-4-hydroxylase in the endoplasmic reticulum  (Gabr et al., 2017; Xu et al., 2019). The hydroxyproline at the third position of the characteristic (glycine-another amino acid-hydroxyproline) repreats is essential for stablizing the collagen triple helix (Ricard-Blum, 2011).
  
Ehrlich's reagent is a chemical reagent made with p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde (DMAB) mixed with concentrated hydrochloric acid. Primarily used to detect the presence of indoles such as tryptamines and serotonin (Kesava Reddy and Enwemeka, 1996; Knowlton et al., 2002), Ehrlich's reagent can also detect hydroxyproline in biological matrices such as tissue and bodily fluids with its intensity of the color produced directly proportional to the amount of hydroxyproline present in the sample. The reaction between Ehrlich's reagent and hydroxyproline can be quantified by measuring the absorbance of the colored product using a spectrophotometer at a specific wavelength between 540 and 570 nm  (Cissell et al., 2017). The absorbance can be then used to calculate the concentration of hydroxyproline in the sample by using a standard curve, which may serve as an accurate predictor of normal tissue or pathological fibrosis and an indicator of collagen metabolism (Cissell et al., 2017; Tarnutzer et al., 2022). 

High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is an analytical technique that utilizes a stationary phase packed in a column through which a sample is passed and separated based on the differential interactions of its components with the stationary phase. It is frequently employed to quantitatively assess the concentration of hydroxyproline in biological matrices such as tissues and bodily fluids (Green and Reagan, 1992). This technique is also commonly used to evaluate collagen synthesis (Stimler, 1984) and degradation in a variety of tissues, including skin, bone, and cartilage (Wang et al., 2018).

nodes.label: Modified Sircol
nodes.desc:
Since collagen is a prominent metabolic indicator, accurate determination of its content is essential for the creation of reproducible scaffolds and the investigation of tissue pathologies (Friess, 1998). There are numerous ways to determine collagen concentration, including radiolabeling, chromatography, and calorimetry, but none of them proved optimal (Lareu et al., 2010). The Sircol Collagen Assay (SCA) is based on the amino acid binding characteristic of Sirius Red (SR F3B; CI 35782), an anionic dye having sulfonated acid side-chain groups that react with the side-chain groups of basic amino acids (Constantine and Mowry, 1968; Sweat et al., 1964) and is frequently employed as a selective histochemical stain for collagen in normal and diseased tissue (Borges et al., 2007; Brotchie et al., 1999; Kratky et al., 1996). The SCA has almost exclusively been adopted as the quickest and most straightforward colorimetric method for determining collagen concentration in complex protein solutions (Lareu et al., 2010; Tarnutzer et al., 2022). 
Despite its prevalence, the SCA also dramatically overestimated collagen content by a factor anywhere from 3 to 24 folds—particularly grievous results arising in cell culture systems and tissue hydrates due to non-collagenous protein interference (Junqueira et al., 1979; Lareu et al., 2010). However, a purification technique including a pepsin digestion and column ultrafiltration step to accurately determine collagen content in various samples that eliminate these interfering proteins has been added to the current SCA approach to resolve this problem (Lareu et al., 2010). The modified Sircol Collagen Assay can therefore offer insight into the aging process and the efficacy of therapies through an accurate evaluation of collagen levels.

nodes.label: Masson's Trichome Staining
nodes.desc: Masson's trichrome staining is a technique used to differentiate and analyze collagen in various types of tissue, including muscle, heart, liver, and kidney tissue, as well as tumors in these organs (Bancroft and Layton, 2019; Hernández-Morera et al., 2016). It works by using a red acidic stain to label acidophilic components such as collagen fibers and then treating the tissue with Phosphotungstic Acid. The less permeable components, including collagen fibers, will retain the red stain, while the more permeable components will lose the red stain and be replaced with a light green dye (Bancroft and Layton, 2019; Leonard et al., 2018). The distinctive ability of this technique to differentiate collagen fibers has been widely utilized in numerous studies to investigate changes in collagen fibers that occur during development, aging, and disease–pathologies such as muscular dystrophy, infarct, cirrhosis, and glomerular fibrosis (Farris and Alpers, 2014; Gutpell et al., 2015; Krishna, 2013; Onoda et al., 2022).

nodes.label: Second Harmonic Imaging of Collagen
nodes.desc:
Second harmonic generation (SHG) imaging is a nonlinear optical technique that utilizes the intrinsic noncentrosymmetry of certain biomolecules to generate light at twice the frequency of the incident light (Cox and Kable, 2006; Leonard et al., 2018; Van Gulick et al., 2019). This process is efficient at high light intensities, such as those produced by a pulsed laser, and is selective with respect to the focal plane in a manner analogous to two-photon fluorescence excitation (Cox and Kable, 2006). Collagen, a highly organized and crystalline structural protein that is abundant in mammals, is the most potent source of SHG in animal tissue (Cox and Kable, 2006; Leonard et al., 2018; Van Gulick et al., 2019). Therefore, SHG imaging can be utilized as a powerful tool for visualizing collagen distribution in various biological samples, including cirrhotic liver, normal and carious teeth, and surgically repaired tendons (Cox and Kable, 2006). One notable advantage of SHG imaging is that it does not result in any energy loss, leading to the long-term stability of the generated SHG signal. Additionally, the shorter wavelength of the SHG signal allows for easy separation from multiple fluorescent probes, making it a valuable technique for multichannel imaging applications (Cox and Kable, 2006; Leonard et al., 2018).

Van Gulick et al. used polarized Raman spectroscopy and SHG to examine age-related changes in the molecular organization of type I collagen in rat tail tendons (Van Gulick et al., 2019). The results showed that certain bands related to proline and hydroxyproline were sensitive to polarization and age-related changes, while others were not. The anisotropy degree of the Raman bands increased from adult to old collagen, indicating a higher alignment of collagen fibers with the fascicle backbone axis in old tendons and a higher straightness of collagen fibers (Van Gulick et al., 2019). These findings were confirmed using SHG, which showed a more homogeneous spatial distribution of collagen fiber alignment in old tendons (Van Gulick et al., 2019). These results demonstrate the usefulness of SHG in studying age-related changes in collagen structure and the impact of these changes on the mechanical and physiological properties of organs (Van Gulick et al., 2019).

nodes.label: De-novo Synthesis of Collagen
nodes.desc:
De-novo collagen synthesis refers to the process by which cells produce collagen from scratch rather than simply remodeling or repairing existing collagen fibers (Last et al., 1989; Last and Reiser, 1989; McAnulty and Laurent, 1987; Onursal et al., 2021; Wang et al., 2007). De-novo collagen synthesis is important for tissue development and repair, and it is regulated by various signaling pathways and transcription factors (Last et al., 1989; Last and Reiser, 1989; Laurent, 1982; McAnulty and Laurent, 1987; Onursal et al., 2021; Wang et al., 2007). 

SILAC (Stable Isotope Labeling by Amino acids in Cell culture) is a mass spectrometry-based technique that uses labeled amino acids to distinguish newly synthesized proteins from pre-existing ones, providing insights into protein synthesis, turnover, and degradation processes (Rosmark et al., 2018). The in-vivo pulsed SILAC labeling methodology was used to quantify new protein incorporation into various tissues in mice (Ariosa-Morejon et al., 2021) and C. elegans (Dhondt et al., 2016; Teuscher et al., 2022; Vukoti et al., 2015), uncovering age-related molecular changes and identifying potential pathways implicated in disease. This approach provides dynamic protein data at a tissue level, enabling a deeper understanding of the underlying mechanisms involved in the regulation of protein synthesis (Rosmark et al., 2018).

Dendra is a photoconvertible fluorescent protein that enables visualization of de-novo synthesized collagen in living cells by being incorporated as a tag in collagen molecules, fluorescing when newly synthesized and permitting real-time tracking of collagen fiber formation and distribution (Gurskaya et al., 2006; Ihara et al., 2011). A study in C. elegans revealed a thickening of the basement membrane via the addition of newly synthesized EMB-9 collagen to old collagens, offering insight into collagen synthesis mechanisms and the role it plays in various biological processes (Teuscher et al., 2022).

Also, Oostendorp et al. developed a novel method for detecting and localizing newly synthesized collagen in ECM tissues by employing the use of an antibody called GD3A12, which specifically binds to dermatan sulfate, a component of proteoglycans that are associated with collagen (Oostendorp et al., 2016; Trowbridge et al., 2002). Critically, this method is universal–meaning it can be utilized to detect collagen produced by cells from any species and can be applied to any source of collagenous biomaterials (Oostendorp et al., 2016). It is designed to address the challenge of identifying collagen that has been produced de novo by cells in the presence of purified collagenous biomaterials, which is a common obstacle in the evaluation of tissue-engineered constructs and in the study of tumor dissemination (Gilkes et al., 2014; Oostendorp et al., 2016). The method has potential applications in regenerative medicine and cancer biology, including the investigation of tumor cell migration in collagen gels (Oostendorp et al., 2016). It is worth noting that dermatan sulfate may be associated with other structures, such as elastin and fibrillin-containing microfibrils, but it does not seem to be associated with elastic fibers in the tissues studied (Oostendorp et al., 2016; Zimmermann et al., 1994). Utilization of this method can potentially be an efficient, cost-effective, and straightforward technique for evaluating the presence and orientation of de-novo synthesized collagen fibrils in collagen-based biomaterials (Oostendorp et al., 2016).

Abnormalities in collagen synthesis and metabolism can lead to various diseases and conditions, such as fibrosis, scarring, and cancer. Understanding the mechanisms and regulation of de-novo collagen synthesis is an active and exciting area of research in many fields, including developmental biology, tissue engineering, and medicine.

nodes.label: DDR
nodes.desc:
The discoidin domain receptors (DDRs) are a family of dimeric receptor tyrosine kinases that regulate various cellular processes, including migration, adhesion, invasion, proliferation, differentiation, and ECM remodeling (Leitinger, 2014; Shrivastava et al., 1997; Vogel et al., 1997). The DDRs have a preference for damaged or degraded collagens and can stimulate the production and activity of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), which are enzymes that degrade ECM components (Olaso et al., 2002; Reel et al., 2015). 

Dysregulation of the DDRs has been linked to various human diseases, such as cancer, neurodegenerative disorders, fibrosis, and inflammatory conditions (Borza and Pozzi, 2014; Hebron et al., 2017). For example, over-expression of DDR1 and DDR2 has been observed in multiple forms of cancer, suggesting that they play a role in the proliferation and migration of tumor cells. Collagen, a major component of the ECM, undergoes extensive remodeling during tumor progression, and DDRs may contribute to this process by modulating MMP activity (Ford et al., 2007; Valiathan et al., 2012). Furthermore, Hebron et al. observed increased expression of DDRs in the brains of individuals who have passed away from Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease. Lentiviral shRNA was utilized to specifically reduce the expression of DDR1 and DDR2, which lead to decreased levels of α-synuclein, tau, and β-amyloid, and protected against cell death in both in-vivo and in-vitro settings. Additionally, inhibiting DDR1 and DDR2 appeared to modulate the immune response in the brain and reduce levels of TREM-2 and microglia. Based on these findings, targeting DDR1 and DDR2 may provide a novel strategy to clear neurotoxic proteins and reduce inflammation in neurodegenerative conditions (Hebron et al., 2017). Furthermore, machine learning and subsequent in-vitro assays identified DDR1 as a drug target for ameliorating fibrosis (Zhavoronkov et al., 2019). 

Therefore, DDRs play a critical role in the aging process and are involved in the development of many age-related diseases, although the precise mechanisms are not yet fully understood. Using mouse models with DDRs deletion has allowed us to gain more insights into their role in the progression of diseases. As a result, therapies that target DDRs, such as RNAi-based delivery, are being developed to treat diseases with limited treatment options (Leitinger, 2014).

nodes.label: Integrin
nodes.desc:
Integrins are composed of α and β subunits, with a total of 18 different α subunits and 8 different β subunits, leading to the formation of 24 distinct integrin heterodimers, each with unique ligand specificities and functions (Adorno-Cruz and Liu, 2018; Albelda and Buck, 1990; Barczyk et al., 2010; Hynes, 2002; Park et al., 2020). Integrins are transmembrane proteins that bind to ECM proteins, transmitting signals across the plasma membrane to the cytoskeleton and regulating cell adhesion, migration, and proliferation. In addition, they can bind to intracellular signaling proteins, modulating signaling pathways (Adorno-Cruz and Liu, 2018; Albelda and Buck, 1990; Barczyk et al., 2010; Hynes, 2002; Park et al., 2020).

The functional importance of integrins is highlighted by their involvement in a wide range of diseases, including cancer, inflammation, and cardiovascular disease (Desgrosellier and Cheresh, 2010; Park et al., 2020). Dysregulation of integrin expression and function has been linked to aging-related disorders such as osteoporosis, arthritis, and fibrosis (Lowin and Straub, 2011; Schnittert et al., 2018; Zhao et al., 2005). For instance, decreased expression of the α-ii subunit of integrin has been linked to age-related bone loss (Stange et al., 2013), while increased expression of the α-v subunit has been associated with age-related fibrosis in the lung (Henderson et al., 2013). Furthermore, the α-v subunit has been shown to be upregulated in senescent cells, and targeting this subunit has been demonstrated to improve age-related phenotypes in mice (Borghesan and O’Loghlen, 2017; Schaffner et al., 2013; van der Flier et al., 2010). 

Thus, integrins are critical transmembrane proteins that mediate various cell functions through their interactions with ECM proteins and intracellular signaling proteins. Their dysregulation has been implicated in the development of age-related disorders, which requires further attention.

nodes.label: MMP
nodes.desc:
Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) are a family of enzymes that play a key role in the breakdown of ECM proteins, such as collagen and elastin. MMP-mediated degradation of these structural proteins is essential for a variety of physiological processes, including tissue repair, and inflammation (Bonnans et al., 2014; Freitas-Rodríguez et al., 2017; Stamenkovic, 2003). MMPs are also involved in the turnover of ECM proteins during normal tissue homeostasis and they play a role in the activation of growth factors and other signaling molecules (Bonnans et al., 2014; Freitas-Rodríguez et al., 2017; Jabłońska-Trypuć et al., 2016; Stamenkovic, 2003).

MMPs have been implicated in the age-related changes that occur in various tissues and organs and have been shown to have both protective and detrimental effects on disease development (Freitas-Rodríguez et al., 2017). For example, MMP-2 and MMP-9 have protective roles, while MT1-MMP, MT3-MMP, and MT5-MMP have been implicated in disease progression. MT5-MMP, in particular, has been detected in amyloid plaques of Alzheimer's patients and appears to have a synergistic role with γ-secretase in disease progression. In mice lacking Mmp24, a reduction in the amyloid beta peptide (Aβ) and amyloid precursor protein (APP) levels in the cortex and hippocampus was observed, as well as a decrease in glial reactivity and interleukin-1β levels. MT5-MMP has also been categorized as an η-secretase due to its ability to cleave APP in vitro at a site consistent with the molecular mass of η-secretase processing products. In addition, η-secretase processing of APP has been shown to inhibit neuronal activity in the hippocampus, further highlighting the importance of this protease in the development of Alzheimer's disease (Freitas-Rodríguez et al., 2017).

nodes.label: Lysyl Oxidase Family of Enzymes
nodes.desc:
The lysyl oxidase family of enzymes is responsible for the formation of covalent bonds between the collagen fibers, which gives the ECM its strength and stability. The lysyl oxidase family of enzymes includes lysyl oxidase, lysyl oxidase-like (LOXL) 1 to 4 (Grau-Bové et al., 2015; Xiao and Ge, 2012).

The dysregulation of lysyl oxidase and other members of the lysyl oxidase family has been linked to a number of health issues. For example, over-expression of LOXL1 has been associated with the development of fibrosis in various tissues, including the lungs and liver (Zhao et al., 2018). Dysregulation of lysyl oxidase has also been linked to the development of aneurysms and hypertension (Remus et al., 2012). In addition, lysyl oxidase has been shown to play a role in cancer progression, as it has been observed to be upregulated in several types of cancer and has been linked to increased invasion and metastasis (Johnston and Lopez, 2018). Lysyl oxidase and the other members of the lysyl oxidase family are regulated by various factors, including hypoxia, oxidative stress, and inflammation (Martínez-Revelles et al., 2017). As such, there are drugs being developed that target LOXs for the treatment of various carcinomas and fibrosis, and there is evidence that increased levels of LOXs may contribute to neurodegeneration and metabolic dysfunction (Gilad et al., 2005). This makes LOXs and LOXs-mediated crosslinks a potential biomarker for a variety of diseases, and targeting these proteins may lead to new treatments for these conditions (Aronoff et al., 2021; Yang et al., 2020).

nodes.label: Transglutaminase
nodes.desc:
Transglutaminases (TGases) are a family of enzymes that catalyze the formation of covalent bonds between proteins through cross-linking. These enzymes play critical roles in various biological processes, including blood clotting, wound healing, and tissue remodeling (Griffin et al., 2002). Among the transglutaminase family members, Transglutaminase 2 (TG2), has been shown to form crosslinks between advanced glycation endproducts (AGEs) and other proteins (Collighan and Griffin, 2009; Marinucci et al., 2018; Rosenthal et al., 2009)  contributes to the development of age-related diseases such as cancer, diabetes, and atherosclerosis (Jones et al., 2006; Penumatsa et al., 2020). 

In addition to its potential role in aging, some studies have suggested that inhibition of TG2 may negatively affect cell survival, highlighting the need for further investigation in this area (Tatsukawa and Hitomi, 2021). TG2 has also been linked to the development of tissue stiffness in obesity and metabolic syndrome (Penumatsa et al., 2020). The concept that a TG2-related pathway may be responsible for heart diastolic dysfunction is supported by the discovery of higher TG2 expression and activity in organs from both a rat model of obesity/metabolic syndrome and a mouse model of aging (Penumatsa et al., 2020). Furthermore, the inhibition of TG2 has been shown to delay early age-induced endothelial dysfunction and microscopic aortic abnormalities, suggesting that TG2 may be a target for the development of new anti-aging and disease-modifying therapies (Armstrong et al., 2018; Brandes et al., 2005; Toda, 2012).

nodes.label: Elastin
nodes.desc: Present in many vertebrate tissues, elastin is a fibrous ECM glycoprotein that facilitates the maintenance of physiological functions by upholding structural integrity and contributing to the mechanical strength of tissues and their elasticity (Reichheld et al., 2019; Yeo et al., 2011). With age, however, elastin-degrading enzymes such as cathepsin and elastase levels increase. These increases lead to the unavailability or disarray of elastin and accelerate elastic fiber fragmentations. Such structural changes by genetic or environmental factors have been associated with skin aging and cardiovascular diseases (Cocciolone et al., 2018; Panwar et al., 2020).

nodes.label: Fibronectin
nodes.desc: Found in almost all tissues, fibronectin–as part of the glycoprotein family–is indispensable to ECM construction by binding to transmembrane proteins like the integrins and other ECM components such as glycosaminoglycans, proteoglycans, collagen I and III, and heparan sulfate proteoglycans (Singh et al., 2010). Mechanical forces stretch and unfold or relax and coil inwards the cryptic binding domains along the fibronectin protein, allowing these different ECM proteins to bind (Vogel, 2018). As a mediator of various ECM molecules and also between ECM and cells, it plays a critical role in cell differentiation, growth, adhesion, and migration (Pankov and Yamada, 2002). Prevalent as it is, when altered, fibronectin has been associated with fibrosis, Alzheimer's disease, and various forms of cancers (Pankov and Yamada, 2002; Vakonakis et al., 2007; White et al., 2008). In particular, Alzheimer's disease patients exhibited heightened fibronectin expressions (Lepelletier et al., 2017), and the accumulation of fibronectin mRNA has been attributed to in-vitro cellular senescence (Kumazaki et al., 1991). By contrast, downregulation was observed with collagen in hepatic stellate cell senescence (Krizhanovsky et al., 2008). These findings indicate fibronectin homeostasis as a critical component in healthspan.

nodes.label: Laminin
nodes.desc: Laminin is part of the glycoprotein family synthesized by muscle, epithelial, bone marrow cells, and neurons. Laminin is incorporated into the basal lamina, which functions as a structural sheet of ECM that segregates muscle and epithelial cells from the connective tissues. Laminin also contains domains of cellular surface interaction with integrins–influencing cellular behavior, such as migration, adhesion, and differentiation (Nieto, 2014; Sasaki et al., 2004; Timpl et al., 1979). Mutations in laminins, therefore, often lead to pathological conditions such as nephrotic syndrome and muscular dystrophy (Yurchenco and Patton, 2009). Upregulation of laminins has been observed in several aging tissues. Diabetic basement membranes, in particular, exhibited a strong correlation of laminin upregulation with its loss of integrity through the age-dependent increase in thickness (Kern et al., 1976; Labat-Robert, 2003).

nodes.label: Tenascin
nodes.desc:
The tenascin family, a highly enigmatic group of proteins, are known to play a significant role in the intricacies of supporting the structural integrity of cells and tissues, as well as regulating their growth and development in a manner that is not fully understood (Chiquet-Ehrismann and Chiquet, 2003). The tenascins are subdivided into several different classes, including tenascin-C, tenascin-R, and tenascin-X (Chiquet-Ehrismann and Chiquet, 2003).

Tenascin-C is found in the ECM of tissues and plays a role in the organization and development of cells and tissues (Midwood and Orend, 2009). In cancer, Tenascin-C has been shown to play a role in the growth, invasion, and metastasis of cancer cells, yet the underlying mechanisms remain obscure. It has also been found to promote angiogenesis, the process by which new blood vessels form, which is essential for tumor growth (Bhattacharyya et al., 2016; Giblin and Midwood, 2014; Lowy and Oskarsson, 2015; Midwood and Orend, 2009; Yoshida et al., 2015). In some cases, increased levels of Tenascin-C have been associated with poor prognosis in cancer patients (Nong et al., 2015). Tenascin-R and tenascin-X, on the other hand, are found in the central nervous system and are involved in the development and function of the brain and nervous system (Jang et al., 2020). 

Both tenascin-C and tenascin-X have been shown to play a role in the biological aging process (Choi et al., 2020; Kasprzycka et al., 2015; Tucker and Degen, 2022). For instance, Mi et al. discovered that tenascin-C immunoreactivity manifested as substantial extracellular deposits of a diffuse nature within the cortical grey matter, possessing diameters exceeding 100 µm (Mi et al., 2016). These tenascin-C plaques exhibited a complete overlap and encirclement of cored Aβ plaques (Mi et al., 2016). The tenascin-C plaques were also found to be in close proximity to reactive astrocytes, microglia, and dystrophic neurites comprised of phosphorylated tau, suggesting a key role for tenascin-C in the pathogenesis of Aβ plaques and highlight its potential as a valuable biomarker and therapeutic target (Mi et al., 2016). Meanwhile, subjects with low levels of tenascin-X may be protected from the typical onset of abnormal arterial stiffness associated with aging and its associated impact of an anomalously swift round-trip travel time of the pressure wave (Petersen and Douglas, 2013). Notably, Uiterwall et al. established that augmented joint motility and skin resilience correspond with a reduction in blood pressure and pulse pressure levels (Uiterwaal et al., 2003). As such, the absence of tenascin-X results in a perturbation of the standard ECM within the blood vessel walls. And subjects with tenascin-X insufficiency may be susceptible to a greater expansion of the internal elastic lamina, enabling larger atherosclerotic plaques to accumulate and ultimately lead to a reduction in the coronary lumen area (Petersen and Douglas, 2013).
